revision.text:
{{Infobox civil conflict | title = 2018 Oklahoma teachers' strike | side3= |partof = the [[2018 teachers' strikes in the United States]] | image = | caption = | date = {{Start date|2018|04|02}} – {{Start date|2018|04|12}} | place= [[Oklahoma]] | coordinates = | causes = * Ongoing education cuts | goals = * $10,000 salary raise for teachers * $1,250 salary raise for support staff | methods = * [[Occupation (protest)|Occupation]] * [[Demonstration (protest)|Demonstrations]] * [[Internet activism]] * [[Walkout]] | status = | result = * $6,000 salary raise for teachers * $1,250 salary raise for support staff * Increased public school funding through tobacco tax | side1= Oklahoma Education Association | side2= [[Government of Oklahoma]] | leadfigures1 = Alicia Priest | leadfigures2 = [[Mary Fallin]] | leadfigures3 = | howmany1 = | howmany2 = | howmany3 = | notes = }}
The '''2018 Oklahoma teachers' strike''' began on April 2, 2018, with teachers across the state walking out to protest low pay, overcrowded classrooms, and tax cuts that resulted in lower state-wide education spending. It was the first such action in Oklahoma since 1990.<ref name=intercept>{{cite web|url=https://theintercept.com/2018/03/06/oklahoma-teacher-strike-west-virginia/|title=TEACHER UNREST SPREADS TO OKLAHOMA, WHERE EDUCATORS ARE “DESPERATE FOR A SOLUTION”|last=Cohen|first=Rachel|date=6 March 2018|publisher=The Intercept|accessdate=6 April 2018}}</ref> The OEA declared an end to the strike on April 12 after an agreement to increase salaries and state funding for education was reached. The call to end the strike faced some objection from teachers and parents who do not believe that enough concessions were made by lawmakers.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2018/04/arizona-teachers-vote-statewide-strike-180420075924512.html|title=US: Arizona teachers vote for first-ever statewide strike|date=20 April 2018|publisher=Al Jazeera|accessdate=20 April 2018}}</ref>
Unlike the [[2018 West Virginia teachers' strike|similar action in West Virginia]], the strike was not a "[[wildcat strike action|wildcat]]" strike, as it received endorsement from union leadership, albeit only after pressure from teachers.<ref name=bloomberg>{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-04-02/teacher-strikes-are-spreading-across-america|title=Teacher Strikes Are Spreading Across America With No End in Sight|last=Eidelson|first=Josh|date=2 April 2018|publisher=Bloomberg|accessdate=6 April 2018}}</ref> The protest occurred concurrent with similar protests in [[2018 Arizona teachers' strike|Arizona]], [[2018 Kentucky teachers' strike|Kentucky]], North Carolina, and [[2018 Colorado teachers' strike|Colorado]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/nation/la-na-teachers-spending-20180402-story.html|title=Red-state revolt continues: Teachers strike in Oklahoma and protest in Kentucky|last=Pearce|first=Matt|date=2 April 2018|publisher=The Los Angeles Times|accessdate=6 April 2018}}</ref>
==Background== ===State of public education in Oklahoma=== Since 2008, education spending per student in Oklahoma has fallen 28%.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.newyorker.com/news/news-desk/striking-oklahoma-teachers-win-historic-school-funding-increase-and-keep-on-marching|title=Striking Oklahoma Teachers Win Historic School-Funding Increase and Keep On Marching|last=DenHoed|first=Andrea|date=4 April 2018|publisher=The New Yorker|accessdate=6 April 2018}}</ref> Due to the decrease in funding, twenty percent of schools run on four-day weeks, and many have eliminated art and language classes and shut down sports programs.<ref name=okturn>{{cite web|url=https://www.jacobinmag.com/2018/03/oklahoma-teachers-strike-west-virginia|title=It’s Oklahoma’s Turn to Strike|last=Blanc|first=Eric|date=30 March 2018|publisher=Jacobin|accessdate=6 April 2018}}</ref> Gains from last teachers' strike in Oklahoma, in 1990, which resulted in an agreement to lower class sizes, expand kindergarten programs, and increase teacher wages were later reversed due to budget cuts.<ref name=okturn/> The decline in funding and subsequent decline in the quality of public education has resulted in the expansion of [[charter schools]] in the state.<ref name=okturn/>
===Plans for a strike=== Support for a strike began to build in early March of 2018, after a proposal (dubbed the "Step Up" plan) failed to pass. The "Step Up" plan would have increased certain taxes and boosted teacher pay by $5,000.<ref name=intercept/> Both Democrats and Republicans voted against the bill. Some Democrats voted against as the plan did not go far enough to restore funding.
Plans for a strike beginning on April 2 were first floated in March. On April 2, schools throughout Oklahoma were scheduled to take standardized tests; preventing these tests from taking place could potentially jeopardize millions in federal funds allocated to Oklahoma.<ref name=intercept/> After Oklahoma governor Mary Fallin passed a limited budget increase on Friday, March 30, a strike beginning on the 2nd was announced.
==Strike== The strike lasted from April 2nd to April 12th.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.jacobinmag.com/2018/04/teachers-strikes-oklahoma-socialism-sanders-unions|title=Red Oklahoma|last=Blanc|first=Eric|date=13 April 2018|publisher=Jacobin|accessdate=13 April 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/04/12/us/oklahoma-teachers-strike.html|title=Oklahoma Teachers End Walkout After Winning Raises and Additional Funding|last=Goldstein|first=Dana|date=12 April 2018|publisher=The New York Times|accessdate=13 April 2018}}</ref> Teachers won greater school funding and salary increases, funded in part by taxes on tobacco sales, online shopping, and fracking<ref>{{cite web|url=http://nymag.com/daily/intelligencer/2018/08/teachers-strikes-oklahoma-gop-primaries-house-2018-elections.html|title=Oklahoma Teachers Just Purged the Statehouse of Their Enemies|last=Levitz|first=Eric|date=29 August 2018|publisher=Daily Intelligencer|accessdate=5 September 2018}}</ref> as well as other miscellaneous taxes. Strike leaders had called for the introduction of a capital gains tax to avoid a regressive tax, but the terms were nevertheless accepted.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://splinternews.com/teachers-win-again-in-oklahoma-as-strike-ends-1825235623|title=Teachers Win Again in Oklahoma as Strike Ends|last=Chang|first=Clio|date=13 April 2018|publisher=Splinter|accessdate=13 April 2018}}</ref>
===Salary demands=== Teacher salaries in Oklahoma are the lowest in the United States, resulting in some teachers and staffers working second or third jobs.<ref name=bloomberg/><ref name=okturn/> An initial offer of a $6,000 wage increase, ratified by the governor, was rejected, as the initial demands were for a $10,000 raise for teachers and a $1250 raise for support staff.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://splinternews.com/oklahoma-is-the-latest-red-state-where-teachers-are-ris-1824260223|title=Oklahoma Is the Latest Red State Where Teachers Are Rising Up|last=Osberg|first=Molly|date=2 April 2018|publisher=Splinter|accessdate=6 April 2018}}</ref>
==Reactions from state officials== Governor [[Mary Fallin]] likened teacher demands to "...teenager(s) wanting a better car”.<ref name=thehill>{{cite web|url=http://thehill.com/blogs/blog-briefing-room/news/381781-oklahoma-teachers-jingle-keys-chant-wheres-my-car-at-governor|title=Oklahoma teachers jingle keys, chant ‘Where’s my car?’ at governor|last=Gstalter|first=Morgan|date=5 April 2018|publisher=The Hill|accessdate=6 April 2018}}</ref> The quote was appropriated by teachers and used in chants during protests at the [[Oklahoma State Capitol]].
State representative Kevin McDugle, a Republican, indicated he would not pass any bill or measure to increase education spending due to the protests undertaken by the teachers.
==2018 primary season== Ten Republican representatives who opposed to tax raise to increase teacher salaries were up for re-election in 2018. Two, Scott McEachin and Chuck Strohm, were eliminated by other Republican nominees during the initial primary, while a further seven did not gain enough votes to win their primaries uncontested.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://theintercept.com/2018/08/29/oklahoma-arizona-primary-teachers/|title=IN OKLAHOMA AND ARIZONA, PRIMARY VOTERS REWARDED CANDIDATES WHO STOOD WITH TEACHERS|last=Jilani|first=Zaid|date=29 August 2018|publisher=The Intercept|accessdate=5 September 2018}}</ref> These seven faced runoff elections in August 2018, and six lost.
==See also== * [[Education in Oklahoma]] * [[2018 teachers' strikes in the United States]] * [[2018 West Virginia teachers' strike]]
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
{{2018 teachers' strikes in the United States}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Oklahoma teacher strike, 2018}} [[Category:2018 in Oklahoma]] [[Category:2018 labor disputes and strikes]] [[Category:Education strikes]] [[Category:April 2018 events in the United States]] [[Category:Labor disputes in Oklahoma]]

{{Infobox university | name = Aarhus University | native_name = Aarhus Universitet | image = Aarhus University seal.svg | image_alt = Seal of Aarhus University | caption = Seal of Aarhus University | latin_name = Universitas Arhusiensis<ref>See the university seal illustrated above</ref> | motto = ''Solidum petit in profundis'' ([[Latin]]) | mottoeng = Seek a firm footing in the depths | established = 1928 | type = [[Public university]] | budget = [[Danish krone|DKK]] 6.347 Billion ($1.124 Billion) <small>(2013)</small><ref>{{cite web | url = http://medarbejdere.au.dk/fileadmin/www.au.dk/om_au/profil/noegletal/121219_-_Budget_2013_netversion.pdf | title = Budget 2013 | accessdate = 2012-12-30 | author = Aarhus University | format = PDF | language = Danish}}</ref> | rector = Brian Bech Nielsen | students = 44,500 <ref name="medarbejdere.au.dk">http://medarbejdere.au.dk/fileadmin/www.au.dk/Rektors_taler_paa_AU/2011/DK_Rektors_juletale_Aarhus-15-12-2011.pdf</ref><ref name="au.dk">{{cite web|url=http://www.au.dk/om/profil/nogletal/studenterbestand/bestand-2011/|title=Bestand 2011|author=232549@au.dk|publisher=|accessdate=29 June 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130212215005/http://www.au.dk/om/profil/nogletal/studenterbestand/bestand-2011/|archivedate=12 February 2013|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.au.dk/om/profil/|title=Profil|first=|last=136957@au.dk|date=15 February 2018|website=www.au.dk|accessdate=29 March 2018}}</ref> | undergrad = 17,504 | postgrad = 16,395 | Master = 5,176 | staff = 11,550 | city = [[Aarhus]] | country = [[Denmark]] {{flagicon|Denmark}} | affiliations = [[European University Association|EUA]] Coimbra Group | website = [http://www.au.dk/en www.au.dk] | logo = Aarhus University logo.png }} '''Aarhus University''' ({{lang-da|Aarhus Universitet}}, abbreviated '''AU''') is a [[public university|public]] [[research university]] located in [[Aarhus]], [[Denmark]]. Founded in 1928, it is Denmark's second oldest university{{refn|The word "university" is used here in the traditional sense of an actual university. Today, the word is commonly used about all institutions of higher learning, including highly specialized institutions such as [[Technical University of Denmark|DTU]] and [[Copenhagen Business School|CBS]].<ref>{{cite encyclopedia | encyclopedia = Den Store Danske | title = universitet (Danmark) | url = http://www.denstoredanske.dk/Erhverv,_karriere_og_ledelse/P%C3%A6dagogik_og_uddannelse/Universiteter_og_h%C3%B8jere_l%C3%A6reanstalter/universitet/universitet_%28Danmark%29?highlight=aarhus%20universitet | accessdate = 2012-07-12 | publisher = Gyldendal}}</ref> Traditionally, a European university consisted of at least four faculties: theology, law, medicine and philosophy.<ref name="Albeck293">{{Harvnb|Albeck|1978|p=293}}</ref>|group="nb"}} and the largest, with a total of 44,500 enrolled students {{as of|2013|January|1|lc=y}}.<ref name="medarbejdere.au.dk"/><ref name="au.dk"/> Aarhus University is placed in the top 100 in most prestigious ranking lists of the world's best universities.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.shanghairanking.com/ARWU2017.html|title=ARWU World University Rankings 2017 {{!}} Academic Ranking of World Universities 2017 {{!}} Top 500 universities {{!}} Shanghai Ranking - 2017|website=www.shanghairanking.com|access-date=2018-07-22}}</ref><ref>QS Top Universities, [http://www.topuniversities.com/universities/aarhus-university"], ''Aarhus University'', 5 August 2013</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.au.dk/en/about/profile/rankings/|title=Rankings|last=118956@au.dk|date=2018-07-12|website=www.au.dk|language=en|access-date=2018-07-22}}</ref> The university belongs to the [[Coimbra Group]] and [[Utrecht Network]] of European universities and is a member of the [[European University Association]].<ref>{{Cite web|url =http://www.coimbra-group.eu/home/map|title =Coimbra group web page|date =|accessdate =|website =|publisher =|archive-url =https://web.archive.org/web/20160605170448/http://www.coimbra-group.eu/home/map|archive-date =2016-06-05|dead-url =yes|df =}}</ref> The university comprises four faculties in Arts, Science and Technology, Health, and Business and Social Sciences and has a total of twenty-seven departments and is home to over thirty internationally recognised research centres, including fifteen Centres of Excellence funded by the Danish National Research Foundation. The business school within Aarhus University, called Aarhus BSS, holds the [[EFMD]] (European Foundation for Management Development) [[European Quality Improvement System|Equis]] [[accreditation]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://bss.au.dk/profile/accreditations/ |title=Accreditations |publisher=Bss.au.dk |date=2013-02-15 |accessdate=2013-02-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130412110130/http://bss.au.dk/profile/accreditations/ |archivedate=2013-04-12 }}</ref> the [[Association to Advance Collegiate Schools of Business]] (AACSB)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://bss.au.dk/currently/news/news-item/artikel/bss-recieves-aacsb-accreditation/ |title=BSS receives AACSB accreditation |author=136057@au.dk |publisher= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150723002332/http://bss.au.dk/currently/news/news-item/artikel/bss-recieves-aacsb-accreditation/ |archivedate=2015-07-23 |df= }}</ref> and the [[Association of MBAs]] (AMBA). This makes the business school of Aarhus University one of the few in the world to hold the so-called Triple Crown accreditation. [[Times Higher Education World University Rankings|Times Higher Education]] ranks Aarhus University in the top 10 of the most beautiful universities in Europe.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.timeshighereducation.com/student/best-universities/10-most-beautiful-universities-europe|title=The 10 most beautiful universities in Europe|date=2018-01-22|work=Times Higher Education (THE)|access-date=2018-01-27|language=en}}</ref>
The university's alumni include [[Jørgen Vig Knudstorp]], the CEO of Lego, [[Margrethe II of Denmark|Queen Margrethe II of Denmark]], [[Frederik, Crown Prince of Denmark|Crown Prince Frederik of Denmark]], and [[Anders Fogh Rasmussen]], former Prime Minister of Denmark and a Secretary General of NATO. It has associations with three Nobel Laureates: [[Jens Christian Skou]] in Chemistry (1997), [[Trygve Haavelmo]] (1989) in Economics and [[Dale T. Mortensen]] in Economics (2010).<ref>{{Citation|title=List of Nobel laureates by university affiliation (from 1-10 laureates)|date=2018-07-21|url=https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=List_of_Nobel_laureates_by_university_affiliation_(from_1-10_laureates)&oldid=851362898|work=Wikipedia|language=en|access-date=2018-07-22}}</ref>
==History==
===Early developments=== [[File:Aarhus Universitets hovedbygning set fra parken.jpg|thumb|View of The Main Building overlooking the University Park. The building was finished in 1946 and holds the university assembly hall.]] Aarhus University was founded on 11 September 1928 as ''Universitetsundervisningen i Jylland'' ("University Studies in [[Jutland]]") with a budget of 33,000 [[Danish krone|Dkr]] and an enrollment of 64 students, which rose to 78 during the first semester. The university was founded as a response to the increasing number of students at the [[University of Copenhagen]] after [[World War I]]. Classrooms were rented from the Technical College and the teaching corps consisted of one professor of philosophy and four associate professors of Danish, English, German and French. Along with ''Universitets-Samvirket'' ("The University Association") which consisted of representatives of Aarhus' businesses, organisations and institutions, the municipality of Aarhus had fought since 1921 to have Denmark's next university located in the city.<ref name="au-history">{{cite web | url = http://www.au.dk/en/about/profile/history/history/ | title = History of The University of Aarhus | accessdate = 2012-07-08 | last = Trefzer | first = Sandra | date = 3 Oct 2011 | publisher = Aarhus University}}</ref><ref name="DSD-au">{{cite web | url = http://www.denstoredanske.dk/index.php?title=Erhverv%2C_karriere_og_ledelse/P%C3%A6dagogik_og_uddannelse/Danske_universiteter/Aarhus_Universitet | title = Aarhus Universitet | accessdate = 2012-07-08 | author = Gyldendal | work = Den Store Danske | publisher = [[Gyldendal]] | language = Danish}}</ref>
In 1929, the municipality of Aarhus gave the university land with a landscape of rolling hills.<ref name="DSD-au" /> The design of the university buildings and 12 ha campus area was assigned to architects [[C. F. Møller]], [[Kay Fisker]] and [[Povl Stegmann]], who won the architectural competition in 1931. Construction of the first buildings began a year later, but the campus was developed in stages and is still under development {{as of|2017|lc=y}}. Since 1939, [[C. F. Møller Architects]] has been responsible for the architectural design of Aarhus University in accordance with the original [[functionalism (architecture)|functionalist]] design key, perhaps best exemplified by the characteristic yellow brick and tile.
The first buildings was finished in 1933 and housed the Departments of Chemistry, Physics and Anatomy.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.au.dk/om/profil/historie/showroom/galleri/lokaliteterogbygninger/aarhusuniversitetsfoerstebygning/|title=Aarhus Universitets første bygning [The first building of Aarhus University] |publisher=Aarhus University|language=Danish|accessdate=1 November 2017}}</ref> These departments later moved to newer buildings at the campus and the original building complex now house Department of Psychology and Department of Political Science. The construction of the first stage was funded solely by donations which totaled 935,000 Dkr and the buildings covered an area of 4,190m<sup>2</sup>.<ref name="Albeck163">{{Harvnb|Albeck|1978|pp=163–165}}</ref> One of the most generous contributors to the first stage was ''De Forenede Teglværker i Aarhus'' ("The United Tileworks of Aarhus") led by director K. Nymark. ''Forenede Teglværker'' decided to donate 1 million yellow bricks and tiles worth c. 50,000 Dkr and later decided to extend the donation to all bricks needed.<ref name="Faber62">{{Harvnb|Faber|1946|p=62}}</ref> The inauguration on 11 September 1933, marked the first official use of the name Aarhus University and was celebrated in a tent on campus, attended by [[Christian X of Denmark|King Christian X]], [[Alexandrine of Mecklenburg-Schwerin|Queen Alexandrine]], their son [[Frederick IX of Denmark|Crown Prince Frederick]] and [[Thorvald Stauning|Prime Minister Stauning]] together with 1000 invited guests.<ref name="Faber6364">{{Harvnb|Faber|1946|pp=63–64}}</ref> On 23 April 1934, Aarhus University was given permission to hold examinations by the king and on 10 October 1935, Professor Dr. phil. Ernst Frandsen was appointed the first rector of the university.<ref name="Faber67">{{Harvnb|Faber|1946|p=67}}</ref>
Shortages of materials and a stressed economy, postponed and delayed further development of Aarhus University. In 1941, construction of The Main Building (''Hovedbygningen'') commenced, a complex to house the university aula (assembly hall) and canteen among academic and administrative purposes. The stringent minimalist and uncompromising functionalistic design of the first university buildings from 1933 had stirred some local dissatisfaction and it was decided that The Main Building should possess more traditional romantic and [[Neoclassical architecture|classical architectural]] inspirations - although in agreement with the original architectural plan -, and also make use of more lavish and expensive materials. The Main Building was finished in 1946 and still stands out from the rest of the University campus as somewhat different in its architectural design.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.au.dk/om/profil/historie/showroom/galleri/lokaliteterogbygninger/hovedbygningen/|title=Hovedbygningen (indviet 1946) |publisher=Aarhus University|language=Danish|accessdate=1 November 2017}}</ref>
In comparison with the original 4,190m<sup>2</sup> floor space of the first buildings, Aarhus University now holds a floor space of 246,000m<sup>2</sup> in the University Park alone.<ref name="Albeck163" /> A series of buildings outside the main campus adds an additional floor space of 59,000m<sup>2</sup>.<ref name="au-history" />
===Faculties===
From 1928, Aarhus University offered courses in languages and philosophy, but the students were unable to finish their studies without going to the University of Copenhagen for their final examinations. By request of the Ministry of Education, the Teachers' Association made a draft of how to conduct the final examinations in the humanistic subjects in Aarhus and in the draft, the Association proposed that the faculty was named the Faculty of Humanities by analogy with the corresponding faculties in [[Uppsala]], [[Lund]] and [[Turku]]. After negotiations between the faculties in Aarhus and Copenhagen, the King declared on 8 May 1935 that the final university examinations could be held at the Faculty of Philosophy in Copenhagen as well as at the Faculty of Humanities in Aarhus. This was the first final examinations Aarhus University was allowed to hold, but on 24 July 1936 the king granted the Faculty of Humanities the right to hold examinations for the [[Cand.mag.|magister]] degree and in 1940 for the [[PhD]].<ref name="au-history" /><ref name="Faber74">{{Harvnb|Faber|1946|p=74}}</ref>
Aarhus University had offered courses in basic medical subjects from 1933 and on 10 October 1935 the Faculty of Medicine was formally established.<ref name="Albeck265">{{Harvnb|Albeck|1978|p=265}}</ref> The establishment of a Faculty of Medicine in Aarhus was met with some opposition from the Faculty of Medicine at the University of Copenhagen. The professors thought that the state should not establish a new Faculty until the shortcomings of the old one had been solved. In the end, the professors agreed to sign a recommendation for the new Faculty as long as improvements to the old one were not delayed.<ref name="Faber52">{{Harvnb|Faber|1946|p=52}}</ref> By 1953, the Faculty of Medicine had been fully built, complete with lectures, professorship chairs, final exams, research facilities and the hospitals of Aarhus had been expanded to meet the demands of clinical training.<ref name="Albeck266267">{{Harvnb|Albeck|1978|pp=266–267}}</ref> In 1992, the Faculty of Medicine merged with the dental school and changed its name to Faculty of Health Sciences.<ref name="au-history" />
The university established its Faculty of Economics and Law in 1936, but when it offered courses in political science and in psychology (1959 and 1968, respectively), the faculty changed its name to the Faculty of Social Sciences.<ref name="au-history" /> The faculty had to be funded solely on private donations and once the university demonstrated it had the needed financial means, the Minister of Education recommended the Finance Committee to approve the establishment of the faculty on 27 January 1936 since the state did not have to grant financial support. The Committee approved and by declaration of the king on 5 November 1937, the faculty could hold examinations in economics and law.<ref name="Faber95">{{Harvnb|Faber|1946|p=95}}</ref>
Courses had been offered in theology since 1932 at the Faculty of Humanities, but in 1942 the Faculty of Theology was formally established.<ref name="DSD-au" /> Already on 22 June 1928, [[Reverend]] Balslev of Aarhus had proposed that Universitetsundervisningen i Aarhus (not yet university) taught basic courses in theology. Though the proposal was greeted by the management, the Faculty of Theology in Copenhagen pointed out that it would take 3 full-time teachers of the [[New Testament]], [[Old Testament]] and [[History of Christianity|ecclesiastical history]], respectively as well as education in [[Latin]], [[Greek language|Greek]] and [[Hebrew]] by the Faculty of Humanities. At this time, Universitetsundervisningen i Aarhus did not have the financial means to meet these criteria so the case was shelved for the time being. In April 1931, the case reopened, this time by [[Bishop]] Skat Hoffmeyer who proposed free teaching in the required subjects. The management asked the faculty in Copenhagen if this was acceptable, but because the teaching was free, the faculty saw it as tutoring rather than actual teaching and they neither approved or disproved of such an approach though they did not see it as actual university teaching. The municipality of Aarhus did not aid with funds and the management deemed a request of the state to be futile so they decided to disregard getting the teaching approved and start it anyway under the supervision of Skat Hoffmeyer. On 5 September 1932 Reverend Asmund held the first lecture in theology. This private education in theology continued until the university could hire its own professors in 1938, and in 1942 Aarhus University could at long last establish the Faculty of Theology.<ref name="au-history" /><ref name="Faber99105">{{Harvnb|Faber|1946|pp=99–105}}</ref>
===The main building and World War II=== {{See also|Aarhus Air Raid}}
[[File:Buerne mod parken 2.jpg|thumb|The brick [[colonnade]]s]] In 1938, the university management acknowledged it was time to consider an expansion due to lack of space and overcrowding of the auditoriums. The solution was The Main Building (''Hovedbygningen''), containing both rooms and facilities for new academic areas, as well as housing for the general administration, an assembly hall and a canteen. The building was to be organized according to a principle of institutes so that teaching and research took place in certain rooms with their own library and study for the professor.<ref name="Faber114">{{Harvnb|Faber|1946|pp=114–118}}</ref>
[[Image:Aarhus Universitet - mindetavle.jpg|thumb|left|Memorial in the main building to honour the ten victims of the 1944 air strike and the two workers killed during construction in 1941.]] [[File:Aulaen (klaver).jpg|thumb|Detail from the Aula, with specially designed lamps and furniture.]] The construction of the building took place during the [[Occupation of Denmark|German occupation of Denmark]] (1940–45) in [[World War II]], which affected the process in more than one way. No state funds had been involved in the construction of the first university building and a second building for [[physiology]], [[biochemistry]], and a [[high voltage]] laboratory, but because the [[Nazism|Nazis]] were against civil use of materials and work forces, the state contributed to the main building. In 1943, the [[Gestapo]], [[Sicherheitsdienst]], [[Geheime Feldpolizei]] and [[Abwehr]] set up their regional headquarters in the five student halls of residence on campus. Fearing that the same would happen to the new main building, its completion was delayed. C. F. Møller later wrote that for once there was plenty of time to work on the details of the building, like patterned brickwork, acoustic screens and furniture.<ref name="Møller4658">{{Harvnb|Møller|1978|pp=46–58}}</ref><ref name="Fode103">{{Harvnb|Fode|2005|p=103}}</ref> Furniture designer [[Aage Windeleff]], designed the furniture specially for the main building, while [[Børge Mogensen]]'s industrially produced furniture designs are the most commonly used elsewhere on campus.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.au.dk/om/profil/historie/showroom/web-udstillinger/moebler-ved-aarhus-universitet/|title=Møbler ved Aarhus Universitet [Furniture at Aarhus University] |publisher=Aarhus University|language=Danish|accessdate=1 November 2017}}</ref>
The presence of the Gestapo in Aarhus led to multiple arrests of Danish resistance fighters and [[Danish resistance movement|the resistance movement]] soon realized they needed outside assistance. On 15 October, the leader of the illegal Danish underground army in Jutland, [[Niels Bennike]], sent the following telegram to [[London]]:<ref name="Fode103" /> [[File:Aula (Aarhus Universitet).jpg|thumb|University Aula]] <blockquote> Undergrunden i Jyland ved at blive revet op af Gestapo. Vigtigere at få ødelagt arkiver og bevare vore folk end at bevare arkiver og få ødelagt vore folk. Jeg beder indtrængende om, at kollegium 4 og 5, gentager 4 og 5, må blive ødelagt ved luftangreb. Det er de to vestligste, gentager vestligste, bygninger i universitetskomplekset. Haster, gentager haster.<br /> ("Underground in Jutland getting torn up by the Gestapo. More important to get the archives destroyed and save our people than getting our people destroyed and save the archives. I implore that residence hall 4 and 5, repeat 4 and 5, be destroyed by air strike. They are the two farthest to the west, repeat farthest to the west, buildings of the university complex. Urgent, repeat urgent.") </blockquote>
On 31 October 1944, the [[Royal Air Force]] bombed the Gestapo's headquarters in residence halls 4 and 5, also killing ten civilian workers. [[No. 2 Group RAF|2 Group Bomber Command]] carried out the bombing by using 25 [[De Havilland Mosquito|Mosquito planes]]. The air strike on the University of Aarhus took place in a heavily populated area and the campus was surrounded by three hospitals. To avoid civilian casualties, the RAF prepared with a model of the campus, shooting at residence halls 4 and 5 with chalk bags. The architect C. F. Møller was in the main building during the air strike but survived and was later dug free from the rubble. The reconstructed main building opened on 11 September 1946.<ref name="Faber114" /><ref name="Møller4658" /><ref name="Fode102109">{{Harvnb|Fode|2005|pp=102–109}}</ref>
===Since 1970=== Aarhus University was an independent institution until 1970, but with management representatives from the city council and the organization of Universitets-Samvirket. Hereafter, the university became a state-run institution under the first University Act. With the next University Act in 1992, external organizations were once again represented in the administration and under the 2003 Act, all Danish universities are governed by a nationwide university board. This board appoints the rector, deans and heads of departments instead of the students. It commenced in January 2004 for the first time and in August 2005, it appointed a new rector.<ref name="au-history" /><ref name="DSD-au" />
In 1994, the university was a [[Aarhus University shooting|scene of a shooting]]; 3 people (including the perpetrator) were killed and two more were injured.
Aarhus University has hosted significant musical events. The [[Grateful Dead]] played there on April 16, 1972; the recorded performance was part of the group's Europe '72 tour.
In the current century, several higher education institutions have been merged with Aarhus University. Following the Danish University reform of 2006,{{citation needed|date=March 2014}} it merged with the HIH{{clarify|date=March 2014}} in Herning and the DPU{{clarify|date=March 2014}} in Copenhagen, making the university nationwide and adding 6,000 students. In 2012, Aarhus University's School of Engineering was merged with the university proper, making it Denmark's largest.{{clarify|Denmark's largest what?|date=March 2014}}
==Campus== [[File:Aarhus Universitet - Lake and library.jpg|thumb|The University Park]] [[File:Vennelystparken (maj) 03.jpg|thumb|Vennelystparken, the southern section of the University Park.]] Aarhus University's main campus is located in central Aarhus, encircling the [[University Park, Aarhus|University Park]] (''Universitetsparken'').
The campus master plan competition was won in 1931 by the collaborative scheme of Danish architects [[Kay Fisker]], [[C. F. Møller]] and [[Povl Stegmann]] in collaboration with landscape architect [[Carl Theodor Sørensen]]. The design includes a wide variety of buildings in a large area, but each building is constructed of the same yellow brick and roofing tile and with a common design key, providing the whole campus with a unified appearance. Construction commenced in 1932 and has continued into present times, lately in 1999-2001 (''Søauditorierne'') and 2014-17 (AU Health).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cfmoller.com/p/-en/soeauditoriet-aarhus-universitet-i263.html |title=Auditoriums, University of Aarhus |publisher=C.F. Møller Architects|accessdate=31 October 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://cubo.dk/projekt/institut-for-biomedicin-aarhus-universitet-faculty-of-health/ |title=Institut for Biomedicin Aarhus Universitet Faculty Of Health |publisher=Cubo Architects|language=Danish |accessdate=31 October 2017}}</ref> The original main building was one of the first Danish functionalist public buildings and has been included in the Ministry of Culture's [[Danish Culture Canon|canon of Danish architecture]]; it is acknowledged as one of the twelve most significant architectural works in the cultural history of Denmark. In a harmonic interplay with the park, the yellow buildings form a campus that has received international recognition for its aesthetic values and it has been protected by law since 1993, in order to conserve its unique design.<ref>{{cite book|title=Arkitekturfortællinger - om Aarhus Universitets Bygninger|language=Danish|author=Olaf Lind and Poul Ib Henriksen|publisher=Aarhus University Press|date=2003}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://soap.plansystem.dk/pdfarchive/20_1117400_APPROVED_1242812291478.pdf|title=Lokalplan nr. 376 |at=Bevarende lokalplan for Universitetetsparken og Vennelystparken|language=da|author=Stadsarkitektens kontor|publisher=Århus Kommune|date=February 1993|accessdate=29 June 2015}}</ref> [[C. F. Møller]] and his company, [[C. F. Møller Architects]] have continued as architects of the campus ever since, except the new department of AU Health currently under construction, designed by [[Cubo Architects|Cubo]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://en.statsbiblioteket.dk|title=Statsbiblioteket|publisher=|accessdate=29 June 2015}}</ref> The park and campus has been expanded throughout the years, in 1957 the old park of [[Vennelystparken]], just south of the University park was included.
Apart from the main campus, Aarhus University has several smaller campuses and departments throughout Aarhus.<ref name=campus>{{cite web|url=http://studerende.au.dk/studier/fagportaler/arts/campus/|title=Campus|publisher=Aarhus University|language=Danish|date=24 August 2015|accessdate= 8 September 2015}}</ref> This includes the campus of [[Aarhus BSS]], school of business and social sciences in [[Aarhus V]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://bss.au.dk/|title=Welcome to Aarhus BSS|publisher=Aarhus University|date=9 August 2015|accessdate= 8 September 2015}}</ref> the new adjacent campus of Nobelparken, built in 1997-2004 in red brick, also by C. F. Møller Architects, but in a different design, a campus at [[Trøjborg]] for Nordic linguistics and related studies, and parts of the research park of IT-byen at [[Katrinebjerg]], where the computer science institute also teach and do research. [[Archaeology]] and [[anthropology]] takes residence in [[Moesgård Manor]], an old manor house at the new [[Moesgård Museum]].
Aarhus University also has a small campus in [[Emdrup]] in Copenhagen (approx. 6.000 students), where the university's programmes in education and pedagogy are taught and researched.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.edu.au.dk/en|title=Danish School of Education|author=17928@au.dk|publisher=|accessdate=29 June 2015}}</ref> It is due for expansion by 2020, and the small Environmental Science Unit at Frederiksborgvej 399, [[Roskilde]] is due to move there. In the city of [[Herning]], there is also a small campus where a few of the university's business, engineering and technology programmes are taught, called the [[Department of Business Development and Technology]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://auhe.au.dk/en/|title=Department of Business Development and Technology|author=223704@au.dk|publisher=|accessdate=29 June 2015}}</ref>
<gallery> File:Aarhus University, Aarhus (1931).jpg File:Aarhus University Park (autumn).jpg|Aarhus University Park File:Universitetsparken (vinter).jpg|The university park in winter File:Buerne i parken.jpg File:Efeu omkring vinduerne, facade mod Universitetsparken.jpg|Example of university building facing the park File:Campussee.jpg|University park lake in summer File:Amfiscenen (AU) 01.jpg File:Vennelystparken (efterår) 03.jpg|Vennelystparken File:Tunnel til Nordre Ringgade 2.jpg File:Universitetsparken (Biomedicin) 02.jpg </gallery>
==Organisation and administration== The university is governed by the University Board which has 11 members: six members recruited outside the university form the majority of the board, two members are appointed by the academic staff, one member is appointed by the technical/administrative staff, and two members are appointed by the university students.<ref>{{cite web | url= http://www.au.dk/en/about/uni/theaarhusuniversityboard | title= Aarhus University Board | accessdate= 2011-03-01}}</ref> The rector is appointed by the university board. The rector in turn appoints deans and deans appoint heads of departments. There is no faculty senate and faculty is not involved in the appointment of rector, deans, or department heads. Hence the university has no faculty governance.
===Main academic areas=== Since 1 January 2011, the university has been organised into four major main academic areas:<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.au.dk/en/facultiesdepartmentsetc/organisation|title=Departments and Schools|author=136957@au.dk|publisher=|accessdate=29 June 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100219171807/http://www.au.dk/en/facultiesdepartmentsetc/organisation/|archivedate=19 February 2010|df=}}</ref> *''[[Science and Technology (Aarhus University)|Science and Technology]]'' – consists of the former Faculty of Science, the former Faculty of Agricultural Sciences and the [[National Environmental Research Institute of Denmark|Danish Centre for Environment and Energy]] (DCE).{{refn|The latter was created in July 2011, as the National Environmental Research Institute of Denmark (NERI) was dissolved.|group="nb"}} *''[[Aarhus Faculty of Arts (Aarhus University)|Arts]]'' – consists of the former Faculty of Humanities, the former Faculty of Theology and the Danish School of Education. *''[[Aarhus BSS]]'' – consists of the former Faculty of Social Sciences and the [[Aarhus School of Business]]. *''[[Aarhus Faculty of Health Sciences (Aarhus University)|Health]]'' – consists of the former Faculty of Health Sciences.
==Academics== [[File:Aarhus University.jpg|thumb|Department of Law, part of The Main Building.]] [[File:IMFPanorama.jpg|thumb|Department of Mathematics]] [[File:DeptCompSci.jpg|thumb|[[Department of Computer Science, AU]] in Aarhus N]] [[File:Langelandsgades Kaserne (facade) 01.jpg|thumb|Aarhus University, School of Communication and Culture, Arts]] {{as of|2014|October|1}}, more than 42,000 students were enrolled in Aarhus University.<ref name="au.dk"/> Each year more than 1000 international exchange students come to Aarhus University to study for one or two terms. In 2009 close to 3000 international students were enrolled in full degree programmes.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.e-pages.dk/aarhusuniversitet/122/|title=AU profilbrochure 10-11 uk|publisher=|accessdate=29 June 2015}}</ref> Aarhus University is an international university with a large proportion of students at the post-baccalaureate level: over half of its students are enrolled in master's degree and PhD programmes. In 2011, 59 of the university's 113 Master's degree programmes were taught in English.<ref name="118675@au.dk">{{cite web|url=http://kandidat.au.dk/en/masters-degree-programmes/|title=Master's student guide|author=118675@au.dk|publisher=|accessdate=29 June 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131013160515/http://kandidat.au.dk/en/masters-degree-programmes/|archivedate=13 October 2013|df=}}</ref> Talent development of young researchers has been identified as one of the university's core activities.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.au.dk/en/phd/phdactionplan/|title=PHD ACTION PLAN FOR PHD EDUCATION AT AARHUS UNIVERSITY|author=118956@au.dk|publisher=|accessdate=29 June 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150609235532/http://www.au.dk/en/phd/phdactionplan/|archivedate=9 June 2015|df=}}</ref> This means that highly qualified students have the option of starting their PhD studies before completing their master's degree. The university's doctoral programmes allow talented students to enroll in a combined Master's/PhD programme either right after completing the bachelor's degree (the 3+5 track) or one year into their master's degree programme (the 4+4 track).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://talent.au.dk/phd/applyforphdadmission/|title=PhD fellowships and scholarships|publisher=|accessdate=29 June 2015}}</ref> Since 2006 the number of PhD students has risen from approximately 1000 to approximately 1700 in 2010.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.au.dk/om/profil/nogletal/2010/tabelc1/|title=Tabel c1|author=274194@au.dk|publisher=|accessdate=29 June 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150923180426/http://www.au.dk/om/profil/nogletal/2010/tabelc1/|archivedate=23 September 2015|df=}}</ref>
===International Centre=== The International Centre maintains international partnerships and combines a wide range of services for exchange students, international full-degree students, PhDs and visiting scholars. The International Centre is often the first stop for foreign students at Aarhus University, since the centre offers advice on finding housing and living in Denmark.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.au.dk/en/internationalcentre/|title=International Centre|author=287607@au.dk|publisher=|accessdate=29 June 2015}}</ref>
===AU Summer University=== Starting in 2011 all summer courses and summer schools offered by Aarhus University for Bachelor's, Master's and PhD students will be gathered together and expanded to provide more diversity in a new framework: AU Summer University. In the summer of 2011 more than 80 courses were offered within the fields of humanities, theology, social sciences, health sciences, natural sciences, agricultural sciences, business and educational sciences. Summer courses are open to both Danish and international students.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.au.dk/en/summeruniversity/ausummeruniversity/|title=AU Summer University|author=223698@au.dk|publisher=|accessdate=29 June 2015}}</ref>
===Degree programmes=== Aarhus University has seen some deep administrational changes since the turn of the century and now also includes several large sub-departments such as [[Aarhus BSS]], [[AU Engineering]] and others. Each of these sub-departments offers [[undergraduate]] and/or [[Graduate school|graduate]] programmes specific to their own field of study. The core academic degree programmes of Aarhus University includes the following fields:<ref>{{cite web|url=http://studieguide.au.dk/en/|title=Study guide|author=136957@au.dk|publisher=Aarhus University|date=8 May 2015|accessdate=8 September 2015}}</ref> {{Div col|colwidth=30em}} *Agricultural Sciences *Biology *Bosnian/Croatian/Serbian *Chemistry *Chinese *Classical [[Archaeology]] *Classical [[Philology]] *[[Cognitive Science]] *Cognitive Semiotics *Comparative Religion *[[Department of Computer Science, AU|Computer Science]] *Czech *[[Dentistry]] *Digital Design *[[Economics]] *[[Engineering]] *[[Ethnography]] *European Studies *Food Science *[[Geology]] *[[History]] *History of Ideas *[[Hungarian language|Hungarian]] *Information Studies *IT/IT Product Development *[[Japanese language|Japanese]] *[[Latin]] *Law *Linguistics *Management *[[Mathematical economics|Mathematical Economics]] *Mathematics *Media Studies *Medicine *Medieval and Renaissance Archaeology *Modern Languages *Molecular Biology *[[Musicology]] *[[Nanotechnology]] *Nordic Language and Literature *[[Philosophy]] *Physics and Astronomy *[[Political Science]] *Prehistoric Archaeology *[[Psychology]] *Religious Studies *[[Russian language|Russian]] *Scandinavian Studies *Semitic Philology *[[Sports Science]] *[[Theology]] *The Religious Roots of Europe {{Div col end}}
The university offers eight [[undergraduate]] and about 60 [[Graduate school|graduate]] programmes in English-language.<ref name="118675@au.dk"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://bachelor.au.dk/en/study-programmes/|title=Bachelor's student guide|author=118675@au.dk|publisher=|accessdate=29 June 2015}}</ref>
===Cheminova controversy and academic freedom at AU=== Since 1944, Aarhus University owned [[Cheminova]], a chemical manufacturer who among other controversies has been selling [[methyl parathion]] pesticide to Brazil farmers.<ref>{{cite web | url= http://www.information.dk/163911 | title= ATP kræver kulegravning af Cheminova | date= 18 August 2008| accessdate= 2009-11-08 }}</ref> In 2009, senior researcher Mette Jensen emailed her colleagues at AU, asking whether they thought Cheminova should stop selling the controversial pesticides. For this, the university threatened her with dismissal.<ref>{{cite web | url= http://www.information.dk/184755 | title= Universitet knægter ansats ytringsfrihed | date= 8 March 2009| accessdate= 2009-11-08 }}</ref> The university's Pro-Vice-Chancellor Søren E. Frandsen denied that the university had made any mistakes or threatened the freedom of speech and academic freedom of its staff.<ref>{{cite web | url= http://www.information.dk/191418 | title= 'Mette Jensen-sagen handler ikke om ytringsfrihed' | date= 17 May 2009| accessdate= 2009-11-20 }}</ref>
On 30 April 2015, Cheminva was sold to the [[FMC Corporation]] for DKK 8.5 billion, a controversial issue in itself.<ref>{{cite paper|url=http://www.business.dk/industri/saadan-slap-aarhus-universitet-af-med-cheminova|title=Sådan slap Aarhus Universitet af med Cheminova [This is how Aarhus University got rid of Cheminova] |newspaper=Berlingske Business|date=29 April 2015 |author=Birgitte Erhardtsen |language=Danish|accessdate=23 December 2016}}</ref>
==Major research centres== [[Image:Aarhus universitet.jpg|thumb|Royal Danish Library, Aarhus, at the university campus]] [[File:Victor Albeck Bygningen.JPG|thumb|The Victor Albech building, library of the Health faculty, Aarhus University]] Aarhus University is home to 15 Centres of Excellence supported by the Danish National Research Foundation<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dg.dk/en/|title=Eksperimentel astropartikelfysik-gruppe ved Discovery Center officielt tildelt status af fuldt medlemskab af IceCube-samarbejdet|publisher=|accessdate=29 June 2015}}</ref> and a considerable number of major research centres. The 15 Centres of Excellence are:<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.au.dk/en/research/centresofexcellence/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-02-16 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20100223013455/http://www.au.dk/en/research/centresofexcellence/ |archivedate=2010-02-23 |df= }}</ref> * Centre for Membrane Pumps in Cells and Disease (PUMPKIN) * Centre for Insoluble Protein Structures (INSPIN) * Centre for Geomicrobiology * Centre for Materials Crystallography (CMC) * Centre for DNA Nanotechnology * Centre for Functionally Integrative Neuroscience (CFIN)d * Centre on Autobiographical Memory Research (CON AMORE) * Centre for Massive Data Algorithmics (MADALGO) * The Water and Salt Research Centre * Centre for Carbonate Recognition and Signaling (CARB) * Centre for Research in Econometric Analysis of Time Series (CREATES) which is one of the best econometrics center according to https://ideas.repec.org/top/top.ecm.html. Currently this center is positioned as second best center of research in econometric time series analysis. Furthermore, this center is considered {{Citation needed|date=August 2013}} as one of the best places to study a PhD in Econometrics. * Centre for Oxygen Microscopy and Imaging (COMI) * Centre for mRNP Biogenesis and Metabolism * Centre for Quantum Geometry of Moduli Spaces (QGM) * Centre for the Theory of Interactive Computation * Center for Theoretical Chemistry (qLEAP)
Some of the university's other major research centres include MindLab and iNANO.
===MINDlab=== MINDLAB was established with a DKK 120 million grant awarded by the Danish Ministry of Science, Technology and Innovation. At MINDLab neuroscientists, psychologists, biologists, statisticians and researchers from other fields work together to understand the brain, its disorders, and its development through physical and social interactions – and vice versa.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mindlab.au.dk/menu50-en/|title=Projects - MINDLab|publisher=|accessdate=29 June 2015}}</ref>
===iNANO=== The [[Interdisciplinary Nanoscience Center]] (founded in 2002 by Professor Flemming Besenbacher) offers a [[Nanotechnology education|degree programme in nanoscience]] with an interdisciplinary curriculum covering a broad spectrum of introductory, advanced and specialised courses, aimed at providing the student with a sufficiently broad basis to conduct interdisciplinary research within nanoscience and at the same time achieve disciplinary depth and specialised skills in selected areas. Hence, the programme encompasses [[physics]], [[chemistry]], [[biology]], [[molecular biology]], [[mathematics]] and [[computer science]].
==Student life==
Students from different fields meet in the numerous Friday bars, in the Student House Aarhus (''Studenternes Hus'')<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.studenterhusaarhus.dk/Welcome.aspx|title=Studenterhus Århus - Welcome|publisher=|accessdate=29 June 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150702125051/http://studenterhusaarhus.dk/Welcome.aspx|archivedate=2 July 2015|df=}}</ref> and at concerts in the University Park and around the rest of the city. The Friday bars are often organised by the different departments who set up a small bar in a canteen or classroom where beers and non-alcoholic drinks are served.
The university also has a number of libraries, some of which are open around the clock. Almost every department has its own library, but the main library is the State and University Library. It has an extensive electronic journal database which students and staff can access either at the library or from home.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://en.statsbiblioteket.dk/|title=Statsbiblioteket|publisher=|accessdate=29 June 2015}}</ref>
Aarhus University Sports (AUS) is open to all university students and organises a wide range of activities from badminton, to fencing and chess.
===Student organisations=== [[File:Studenternes Hus (Fredrik Nielsens Vej).jpg|thumb|Studenternes Hus (The Students House), built in 1964]] The largest student organisations at Aarhus University are the [[Students' union#Denmark|Student Union]] (''Studenterrådet'') and ''Studenterlauget''. The Student Union represents the main student body at Aarhus University while ''Studenterlauget'' is a mainly social organisation at [[Aarhus University, School of Business and Social Sciences|School of Business and Social Sciences]]. The Student Union has both student seats on the university board.<ref>[http://www.au.dk/en/uni/theboardoftheuniversityofaarhus The Board of the University of Aarhus] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080331014235/http://www.au.dk/en/uni/theboardoftheuniversityofaarhus |date=2008-03-31 }}, Aarhus University, www.au.dk</ref> The Student Union also arranges annual concerts and seminars, and publishes the student magazine ''Delfinen'' (The Dolphin).
There are political students organisations at the university, the largest of which include the Social-Democratic Students (''Frit Forum''), Conservative Students (''Konservative Studenter''), and [[Liberal Students]] (''Liberale Studerende''). The Conservative Students union publishes the student magazine ''Critique''. The Liberal Students union publishes the leaflet Minerva.
===Clubs and societies===
Aarhus University offers many activities and services for foreign and Danish students. Several "Friday Bars", clubs organized and crewed by students at the university offer cheap beer and drinks, which has a wide appeal to the student body.
====The Students House ==== Studenternes Hus (The Students House) was built in 1964 at the central campus to accommodate students organisations, activities, festivities and gatherings. Among many other things, the buildings are headquarters to the students organisation ''Studenterhus Aarhus'', and Aarhus University offers a free membership to all exchange students.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.studenterhusaarhus.dk/frontpage|title=Frontpage|author=|date=|website=www.studenterhusaarhus.dk|accessdate=29 March 2018}}</ref> The Students House is a meeting place for international and Danish students in Aarhus and ''Studenterhus Aarhus'' organize social and cultural activities throughout the year, ranging from parties and road trips, to language classes and weekly international nights (a popular dinner club).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.studenterhusaarhus.dk/Default.aspx?ID=21|title=Studenterhus Århus - Welcome|publisher=|accessdate=29 June 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110205215226/http://www.studenterhusaarhus.dk/Default.aspx?ID=21|archivedate=5 February 2011|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.au.dk/fileadmin/www.au.dk/Internationalt_Center/Incomingexchangestudents/Student_Exchange_Guide_2010_2011.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-03-24 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101224173322/http://www.au.dk/fileadmin/www.au.dk/Internationalt_Center/Incomingexchangestudents/Student_Exchange_Guide_2010_2011.pdf |archivedate=2010-12-24 |df= }}</ref>
====Aarhus University Sports (AUS)==== AUS is the official sports club of Aarhus University, and is open to all university students. It is an umbrella organisation consisting of 14 independent member clubs, which host a wide range of activities, from badminton to fencing to chess. In addition, AUS also offers independent activities such as indoor soccer tournaments, gym facilities and skiing trips.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.aus.dk|title=Aarhus Universitets-Sport|work=Aarhus Universitets-Sport|accessdate=29 June 2015}}</ref>
====Dale's Café==== [[File:Dale's Café.jpg|thumb|Dale's Café, one of several socializing spots]] Dale's Café is a meeting place for international students and the university's PhD students that opened in 2011. The café offers coffee, sandwiches and a wide selection of beers. It has an informal lounge area where students and young researchers can relax while enjoying snacks and beverages. Like the main building, Dale's Café is named after Aarhus University's 2010 Nobel Laureate in Economic Sciences, Dale T. Mortensen. The Dale T. Mortensen Building houses the International Centre, the PhD House and the IC Dormitory, which contains 28 dorm rooms and two apartments dedicated to recently arrived international PhD students.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.au.dk/en/news/archive/2011/haveacoffeewithanobellaureateandhangoutindalescafe |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-03-24 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120723074106/http://www.au.dk/en/news/archive/2011/haveacoffeewithanobellaureateandhangoutindalescafe |archivedate=2012-07-23 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://phd.au.dk/en/phdhouse/dalescafe|title=Dale's Café|first=|last=243241@au.dk|date=5 February 2018|website=phd.au.dk|accessdate=29 March 2018}}</ref>
====Klubben==== Klubben (which means 'The Club' in Danish) is a bar located at the former ASB (Aarhus School of Business), now under the faculty of [[Aarhus University, School of Business and Social Sciences|School of Business and Social Sciences]]. The bar is open during regular school hours and weekdays, but hosts larger parties during Fridays and in relation to major sports events. Admittance is usually restricted to students of the [[Aarhus University, School of Business and Social Sciences|School of Business and Social Sciences]].<ref>[http://klubben.studenterlauget.dk/ Klubben] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120308132731/http://klubben.studenterlauget.dk/ |date=2012-03-08 }}</ref>
====Studenterlauget==== Studenterlauget, [[Aarhus University, Business and Social Sciences|School of Business and Social Sciences]] (at the former [[Aarhus School of Business|ASB]]) is currently the largest student organisation in Denmark – [http://www.studenterlauget.dk/ Studenterlauget]. The organisation has approximately 4,000 members whom they service through nine smaller "business units". Studenterlauget has around 130 employees, most of them students.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.studenterlauget.dk/about-sl/studenterlauget.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-02-26 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120912072533/http://www.studenterlauget.dk/about-sl/studenterlauget.html |archivedate=2012-09-12 |df= }}</ref>
== University museums == Aarhus University operates a number of museums, both in and outside the University campus:
* [[Moesgaard Museum]] (MOMU) * [[Steno Museum]] * [[Ole Rømer Observatory]] * [[Aarhus Botanical Gardens]] and greenhouses * [[Natural History Museum, Aarhus|Natural History Museum]] * [[Museum of Ancient Art, Aarhus|Museum of Ancient Art]]
==Notable Alumni, Faculty and Students==
===Former and Current Faculty=== {{Div col|colwidth=30em}} *[[Benjamin K. Sovacool]], Director of the Center for Energy Technology at AU-Herning and a Professor of Social Sciences *[[David Field (astrophysicist)|David Field]], physicist *[[David Gress]], Danish-American historian *[[Helmuth Nyborg]], Danish professor of developmental psychology *[[Ivan Damgård]], Danish cryptographer *[[Jens Christian Skou]], Danish chemist and Nobel Prize laureate in Chemistry 1997 *[[Johannes Sløk]], Danish philosopher and theologian *[[Birte Melsen]], Danish Orthodontist *[[Jørgen Christensen-Dalsgaard]], Danish astronomer *[[Kjeld Philip]], Danish economist and politician *[[Knud Ejler Løgstrup]], Danish [[philosopher]] and [[theologian]], [[Pastor]] at [[Sandager]]-[[Holevad]] from 1936-1943, Professor at [[University of Aarhus]] from 1943-1975 *[[Kristen Nygaard]], Norwegian Computer Scientist (1975-1976), Turing Award *[[Ole Barndorff-Nielsen]], Danish statistician *[[Poul Jørgensen (chemist)]], Director of the qLEAP center for theoretical chemistry *Torben M. Andersen, professor, former Chairman of the Welfare Commission *[[Rubina Raja]], Professor of Classical Archaeology and leader of The Danish National Research Foundation's Center of Excellence for Urban Network Evolutions
===Alumni=== *[[Anders Fogh Rasmussen]], (MSc in Economics 1978) [[Prime Minister of Denmark]] from 2001 until 2009. [[Secretary General of NATO]] from August 2009 until October 2014. *[[Bertel Haarder]], (MSc in Political Science 1971) Danish politician, Member of the Danish Parliament. *[[Bjarne Stroustrup]], (MSc in Mathematics and Computer Science 1975) Danish inventor, designer and original implementer of the C++ programming language. *[[Bjørn Lomborg]], (MSc in Political Science 1991) Danish author, academic and environmentalist. *[[Crown Prince Frederik]], (MSc in Political Science 1995) Crown Prince of Denmark. *[[Dan Jørgensen]], (MSc in Political Science) Danish politician. Member of the European Parliament since 2004. *[[Dorete Bloch]], (MSc in Zoology 1970) Danish zoologist. *[[Ebbe Nielsen]], (MSc in Zoology 1976) Danish entomologist. *[[Høgni Reistrup]], (BA in Media studies and Organisational Development 2008 from Aarhus University and MA in Media Studies 2010 from the [[University of Copenhagen]]),<ref name="Linkedin">{{cite web|url=https://www.linkedin.com/in/hognireistrup|title=Høgni Reistrup|publisher=LinkedIn|accessdate=17 January 2016}}</ref> co-writer of the book ''Exit Føroyar'' which created debate about the declining population in the Faroe Islands.<ref name="Færøudvalg">{{cite web|url=http://www.ft.dk/folketinget/udvalg_delegationer_kommissioner/udvalg/faeroeudvalget/nyheder/2013/03/temamoede%20fraflytning%20fra%20faeroerne.aspx|title=Folketingets Færøudvalg holder temamøde om den voksende fraflytning fra Færøerne|last=Bohlbro|first=Peter|date=13 March 2013|publisher=The Folketing|language=Danish|accessdate=17 January 2016}}</ref> *[[Jan Beyer Schmidt-Sørensen]] (Msc in Economics 1983 from Aarhus University and PhD in 1990 in Economics from Aarhus School of Business) former [[Rector (academia)|Rector]] of [[Aarhus School of Business]] (now Aarhus University, School of Business and Social Sciences) and Director of Business Development at [[Aarhus Municipality]]. *[[Jens-Peter Bonde]], Danish journalist, author, politician and Member of the European Parliament 1979-2008. *[[Johannes Lebech]] (MA), Danish politician. *[[John Degnbol-Martinussen]] (PhD) political scientist. *[[John Frandsen (composer)|John Frandsen]], (MA in Music 1982) Danish composer, organist and conductor. *[[Jørgen Vig Knudstorp]], (MSc 1995, PhD in 1998 in Economics) CEO of the [[Lego Group]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.timeshighereducation.com/world-university-rankings/aarhus-university#survey-answer|title=Aarhus University|website=Times Higher Education (THE)|language=en-US|access-date=2017-08-25}}</ref> *[[Kjeld Philip]], (MSc in Economics) Danish economist and politician. *[[Lars Knudsen]], (MSc 1992, PhD 1994) Danish cryptographer. *[[Lars Rasmussen (software developer)]], (MSc in Mathematics and Computer Science 1990) Danish computer scientist, software developer, and co-founder of [[Google Maps]]. *[[Lene Hau]], (MSc 1986, PhD 1991 in Physics) Danish physicist. *Mads Nipper, (Msc in Economics and Business Adm. - International Business 1991), CEO at [Grundfos]. *[[Morten Albæk]], (MA in History (minor in Philosophy) Former Group Senior Vice President i [[Vestas Wind Systems]], named one of the 100 most innovative marketing leaders in 2011, 2012 and 2013 by the magazine, The Internationalist. *[[Madhavan Mukund]], Dean of Studies, [[Chennai Mathematical Institute]], [[India]] *[[Naser Khader]], Danish-Syrian politician and Member of the Danish Parliament. Chairman of the [[Liberal Alliance (Denmark)|Liberal Alliance]] 2007-2009. *[[Niels Jacobsen]], (Msc in Economics 1983) CEO of William Demant *[[Nils Malmros]], (MD 1988) Danish film director and screenwriter. *[[Nils Smedegaard Andersen]], (MSc 1982 in Economics) CEO of [[Maersk]] *[[Søren Gade]], (MSc in Economics 1990) Danish politician, Minister of Defence and Member of the Danish Parliament. *[[Svend Auken]], (MSc in Political Science 1969) Danish politician. Chairman of the [[Social Democrats (Denmark)|Danish Social Democrats]] 1987-1992. *[[Tim Bollerslev]], (MSc in Economics and Mathematics 1983) Danish Econometrician. Inventor of the [[GARCH]] model. *[[Tøger Seidenfaden]], (MSc in Political Science 1983) Danish journalist. Editor-in-chief at [[Politiken]] 1993-2011. *[[Yildiz Akdogan]], (MSc in Political Science 2006) Danish politician, Member of the Danish Parliament since 2007. *Aage Frandsen, Danish politician, Member of the Danish Parliament 1971-1975, 1987–1990 and 1994-2005. *[[Folmer Wisti]] founder of the [[Danish Institute]] {{Div col end}}
===Students=== *[[Queen Margrethe II]], [[Queen regnant]] of Denmark since 1972.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.au.dk/om/profil/historie/showroom/web-udstillinger/prinsesse-margrethe-paa-aarhus-universitet-19611962/|title=Prinsesse Margrethe på Aarhus Universitet 1961/1962 [Princess Margrethe at Aarhus University 1961/1992] |language=Danish|publisher=Aarhus University|accessdate=26 August 2016}}</ref>
==International recognition== {{Infobox world university ranking | ARWU_W = 65 | THE_W = 109 | THE_W_ref = <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.timeshighereducation.com/world-university-rankings/2018/world-ranking|title=World University Rankings|author=|date=18 August 2017|website=timeshighereducation.com|accessdate=29 March 2018}}</ref> | QS_W = 141 |ARWU_W_ref=<ref>http://www.shanghairanking.com/World-University-Rankings/Aarhus-University.html</ref>|QS_W_ref=<ref>https://www.topuniversities.com/universities/aarhus-university</ref>|USNWR_W=89|USNWR_W_ref=<ref>http://nturanking.lis.ntu.edu.tw/bySchoolName/Aarhus%20University</ref>}} Aarhus University is highly ranked by international organizations and maintains its own page listing its current rankings.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://international.au.dk/about/profile/rankings/|title=Rankings|last=48637@au.dk|date=2018-09-20|website=international.au.dk|language=en|access-date=2018-09-23}}</ref> It's ranked 65th by the [[Academic Ranking of World Universities|Shanghai Ranking]] (2018),<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.shanghairanking.com/World-University-Rankings/Aarhus-University.html|title=Academic Ranking of World Universities - Aarhus University|publisher=ShanghaiRanking Consultancy|accessdate=2016-10-04|language=en|location=Shanghai|website=Academic Ranking of World Universities}}</ref> 89th by National Taiwan University Ranking (2018),<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://nturanking.lis.ntu.edu.tw/bySchoolName/Aarhus%20University|title=Aarhus University|website=nturanking.lis.ntu.edu.tw|language=tw|access-date=2018-09-23}}</ref> 95th by the [[U.S. News & World Report]] (2018),<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.usnews.com/education/best-global-universities/aarhus-university-502125|title=U.S. News & World Report|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141030180720/http://www.usnews.com/education/best-global-universities/aarhus-university-502125|archive-date=2014-10-30|dead-url=yes|access-date=}}</ref> 109th by [[Times Higher Education World University Rankings]] (2018),<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.timeshighereducation.com/world-university-rankings/aarhus-university?ranking-dataset=589595|title=Times Higher Education World University Rankings - Aarhus University|publisher=TES Global Limited|website=Times Higher Education|location=London|language=en|accessdate=2016-10-04}}</ref> and 141th by [[QS World University Rankings]] (2018).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.topuniversities.com/universities/aarhus-university|title=Top Universities - Aarhus University|publisher=Quacquarelli Symonds Limited|location=London|language=en|accessdate=2016-10-04|website=Top Universities}}</ref> In Denmark, only [[University of Copenhagen]] generally achieves better rankings.
==Residence halls==
Residence halls for students in Aarhus, includes the following: [[File:Parkkollegierne.jpg|thumb|Parkkollegierne in Aarhus University Park.]] {{Div col|colwidth=30em}} *Bronzealdervænget *[[Børglum Kollegiet]] *Dania kollegiet *Grundtvigs Hus Kollegiet *Hejredal Kollegiet *Herredsvej *Kirsebærhaven *Kløvergården *Kollegierne i Universitetsparken (Parkkollegierne) *Ladegårdskollegiet *Munkegadekollegiet *Nørre Alle Kollegiet *Ravnsbjerg Kollegiet *Rundhøjkollegiet *Skejbygårds Kollegiet *Skejbyparken *Skelager Kollegiet *Skjoldhøj Kollegiet *Skovkollegiet *Stenaldervej Kollegiet *Tandlægekollegiet *Teknologkollegiet *Vilhelm Kiers Kollegium {{Div col end}}
Only the Parkkollegierne residence halls are located on campus; other residence halls are located elsewhere, all across the city.<ref>[http://koll.au.dk/ Kollegierne i Universitetsparken] {{da icon}}</ref> It is also the only residence hall exclusively for students at Aarhus University. A large part of the residence halls and youth accommodation in Aarhus is administered by the non-profit [[housing cooperative]] of Kollegiekontoret.<ref>[http://www.kollegiekontoret.dk/ Kollegiekontoret i Aarhus] {{da}}</ref> The public web-platform of Ungdomsboliger.dk provides access to student and youth accommodation all across Denmark.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ungdomsboliger.dk/?id=front&lang=en|title=Kollegie- og ungdomsboliger i hele Danmark - Studieboliger i København, Odense, Aarhus, Aalborg m.fl.|author=|date=|website=www.ungdomsboliger.dk|accessdate=29 March 2018}}</ref>
==Partner universities and membership== *Member of the [[Coimbra Group]] *Member of the [[Utrecht Network]]
==See also== * [[List of modern universities in Europe (1801–1945)]] * [[Open access in Denmark]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.opendoar.org/countrylist.php?cContinent=Europe#Denmark |title= Denmark |work=[[Directory of Open Access Repositories]] |publisher=University of Nottingham |location= UK |accessdate= 11 March 2018 }}</ref>

revision.text:
{{DISPLAYTITLE:Arusha Technical College}} '''Arusha Technical College (ATC)''' in [[Arusha]], [[Tanzania]]{{Cite web|url=https://www.atc.ac.tz/|title=Establishment of the Arusha Technical College (ATC)|last=|first=|date=|website=Arusha Technical College|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=30 August 2017}} is a public higher tertiary education institution, which was jointly established in 1978 by the Governments of the United Republic of Tanzania and [[Germany]] (then the [[West Germany|Federal Republic of Germany]]), as the Technical College Arusha (TCA). The [[college]] is in the Central Business [[District]] of Arusha City in the Northern Tanzania-East Africa Community (EAC). [[File:Atc logo.jpg|thumb|266x266px|Arusha Technical College
[https://www.atc.ac.tz website] ]] In March 2007, the name changed to the Arusha Technical College (ATC) through the Arusha Technical College Establishment Order No. 78 as enabled by the NACTE Act No. 9 of 1997.{{Cite journal|date=2017-08-29|title=File:Approved undergraduate institutions in Tanzania.pdf|url=https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=File:Approved_undergraduate_institutions_in_Tanzania.pdf&oldid=797891295|journal=Wikipedia|language=en}} == Campuses == The college has two campuses: [[Ministry of Defence and National Service|Oljoro]] in Arusha and Kikuletwa in Hai [[Mount Kilimanjaro|Kilimanjaro]]. ==References == {{reflist}} {{coord missing|Tanzania}} [[Category:Tertiary education]] [[Category:Education in Tanzania]] [[Category:Universities in Tanzania]] __FORCETOC__ __INDEX__

revision.text:
'''Asian Business Case Competition @ Nanyang''' is an [[international]] [[undergraduate]] [[business]] case [[competition]] in [[Singapore]], established in 2007.<ref name="DarylNeo">Daryl Neo. (12 October 2009). "Environmental business solutions". The Business Times (Singapore).</ref> It is organised by [[Nanyang Business School]]’s case club Business Solutions and is backed by the Asian Business Case Centre. ABCC @ Nanyang is a student-led case competition with a focus on sustainability. Every year, the competition hosts undergraduate participants from [[business school]]s around the world, applying their knowledge and skills to solve real-life business problems. ABCC @ Nanyang has been certified [[carbon neutral]] by TheCarbonNeutral Company.<ref name="HafidhZulkarnaen">Hafidh Zulkarnaen (8 November 2010). "Making a case for green business practices". The Business Times (Singapore).</ref> [[File:ABCC Xperience Singapore participants, Chinatown MRT Station, Singapore - 20130520.jpg|thumb|right|ABCC 2011 Xperience Singapore]]
== Activities ==
=== Case competition ===
The competition centres around a 40-hour-long case,<ref name="QuahChin">Quah Chin Chin (29 October 2008). "A battle of wits and grit". The Business Times.</ref> where students would strategize their best solution to a [[business case study]], and present their case to a panel of judges. In 2017, after one successful decade of hosting Asian Business Case Competition, the format of competition was changed to include one 8-hour case, and one 24-hour case to provide an enhanced competition experience.
==== Past winners ====
'''2017'''
Champions: [[University of Alberta]]
'''2016'''
Champions: [[University of Alberta]]<ref name="2016Champions">{{cite web |url=https://www.ualberta.ca/ |title=University of Alberta clinches champion in Asian Business Case Competition hosted at Nanyang Business School |publisher=Nanyang Technological University |accessdate=5 November 2015 }}</ref>
'''2015'''
Champions: [[Nanyang Business School]], [[Nanyang Technological University]] <ref name="2015Champions">{{cite web |url=http://www.nbs.ntu.edu.sg/News_Events/News/Pages/NBSacesABCC.aspx |title=NBS aces Asian Business Case Competition |publisher=Nanyang Technological University |accessdate=5 November 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304224837/http://www.nbs.ntu.edu.sg/News_Events/News/Pages/NBSacesABCC.aspx |archive-date=2016-03-04 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref>
'''2014'''
Champions: [[University of New South Wales]]<ref name="2014Champions">{{cite web |url=http://abcc.com.sg/2015/archive.php?yr=2014 |title=University of New South Wales wins ABCC at Nanyang Business School |publisher=Nanyang Technological University |accessdate=5 November 2015 }}</ref>
'''2013'''
Champions: [[Chulalongkorn University]]<ref name="2013Champions">{{cite web|url=http://bba.acc.chula.ac.th/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=657&Itemid=29 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140104205416/http://bba.acc.chula.ac.th/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=657&Itemid=29 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=4 January 2014 |title=BBA Chula wins ABCC at Nanyang Business School |publisher=Chulalongkorn University |accessdate=4 November 2013 }}</ref>
'''2012'''
Champions: [[University of Porto]]
'''2011'''
Champions: [[Queensland University of Technology]]
'''2010'''
Champions: [[Maastricht University]]<ref name="2010Champions">{{cite web |url=http://www.maastrichtuniversity.nl/web/Main/Sitewide/News1/SBEStudentsWinAsianBusinessCaseCompetition2010.htm |title=Maastricht University wins ABCC 2010 |publisher=Maastricht University |accessdate=4 November 2013 }}</ref>
'''2009'''
Champions: [[University of Southern California]]
'''2008'''
Champions: [[University of Southern California]]<ref name="2008Champions">{{cite web |url=http://www.gaiadiscovery.com/corporate-social-responsibilit/universities-put-business-cases-forward-for-greener-economy.html |title=Universities Put Business Cases Forward for Greener Economy |publisher=Gaia Discovery |accessdate=4 November 2013 }}</ref>
=== Sustainability initiatives ===
ABCC @ Nanyang has adopted and adhered to several sustainability practices. Besides sourcing for [[environmentally-friendly]] materials for use during the competition where possible, ABCC @ Nanyang also purchases [[carbon credits]] and is carbon-neutral certified.<ref name="Carbon Neutral">{{cite web |url=http://abcc.com.sg/2013/our-green-efforts.php |title=ABCC@Nanyang is certified Carbon Neutral |publisher=Asian Business Case Competition |accessdate=4 November 2013 }}</ref>
A one-day event during ABCC is dedicated to sustainability each year. It has taken different forms in the past few years including panel discussions and mini-case presentations, revolving around sustainability. Some of the highlights include the sustainability roundtable event in 2010, where participants were split into different groups to hold a discussion based on the central theme of “Profitable Shade of Green”. Other formats include 2011’s event, which took the form of a mini-case, where teams were challenged to come up with a strategic plan for sustainable growth in the [[Small-Medium Enterprise]] (SME) context, with a focus on engaging fresh graduate talent.
[[File:Asian Business Case Competition @ Nanyang Sustainability Roundtable, Nanyang Technological University, Singapore - 20130520.jpg|thumb|right|ABCC Sustainability Roundtable]]
=== Organisers ===
The competition is organized by students from [[Nanyang Business School]]'s case club, Business Solutions. Nanyang Business School is part of [[Nanyang Technological University]], based in Singapore. Besides ABCC @ Nanyang, Business Solution also organises the Singapore Business Case Competition,<ref name="SBCC">{{cite web|url=http://www.business.solutions.ntu.edu.sg/index.php |title=Singapore Business Case Competition |publisher=Business Solutions, Nanyang Business School |accessdate=4 November 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140104204144/http://www.business.solutions.ntu.edu.sg/index.php |archivedate=4 January 2014 }}</ref> a case competition targeted at students from the local tertiary institutions in Singapore.
== External links == *[http://www.abcc.com.sg Asian Business Case Competition @ Nanyang Official Website]
== References ==
{{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Asian Business Case Competition}} [[Category:Management education]]
