revision.text:
'''Career and technical student organizations''' ('''CTSOs''') are [[vocational]] organizations primarily based in high schools and career technology centers.
Often, on the state level, they are integrated into [[State education agency|departments of education]] or incorporated as [[nonprofit organization]]s. Many states define CTSOs as "integral parts" of the high school and college education programs.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.ffa.org/SiteCollectionDocuments/about_publiclaw105225.pdf|title=Public Law 105-225|publisher=National FFA Organization|date=August 12, 1998|accessdate=July 1, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tsaweb.org/sites/default/files/CTSO-Guide.pdf|title=Career and Technical Student Organizations: A Reference Guide|date=2008|publisher=Technology Student Association|accessdate=July 1, 2017|first1=Lyn|last1=Fiscus|first2=Alisha|last2=Dixon Hyslop}}</ref> Other higher education institutions have added extracurricular activities that are not sports-related, like CTSOs in order to enhance the college experience.
Some major CTSOs include:<ref name="ctsolist">{{cite web|publisher=U.S. Department of Education|accessdate=July 1, 2017|title=Career and Technical Student Organizations|url=http://www2.ed.gov/about/offices/list/ovae/pi/cte/vso.html}}</ref>
* [[Business Professionals of America|BPA]] (Business Professionals of America) * [[DECA (organization)|DECA]] (formerly Distributive Education Clubs of America) * [[Educators Rising]] * [[FBLA-PBL]] (Future Business Leaders of America-Phi Beta Lambda) * [[FCCLA]] (Family, Career, and Community Leaders of America) * [[National FFA Organization|FFA]] (formerly Future Farmers of America) * [[HOSA-Future Health Professionals]] (formerly Health Occupations Students of America) * [[NYFEA]] (National Young Farmer Educational Association) * [[National Postsecondary Agricultural Student Organization|PAS]] (National Postsecondary Agricultural Student Organization) * [[SkillsUSA]] (formerly Vocational Industrial Clubs of America) * [[TSA (student organization)|TSA]] (Technology Student Association)
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links==
{{DEFAULTSORT:Career And Technical Student Organization}} [[Category:Career and technical student organizations| ]]

revision.comment: removed [[Category:Chemistry experiments]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text: [[File:Chemical chameleon redox reaction (permanganate).ogg|thumb|thumbtime=0:40|right|Chemical chameleon reaction]] The '''chemical chameleon''' is a [[redox reaction]], well known from classroom demonstrations, that exploits the dramatic color changes associated with the various oxidation states of [[manganese]].[http://www.sciencebrothers.org/the-chemical-chameleon/ Science Brothers: The Chemical Chameleon][http://chs-science-maths.blogspot.com/2012/02/oxidation-states-and-chemical-chameleon.html Oxidation states and the Chemical Chameleon] [[Catholic High School, Malaysia|Catholic High School]] Science and Maths Society [[Johann Rudolf Glauber|Glauber]] reported the first description of the production of [[potassium permanganate]] when he noted that [[manganese dioxide]] (as the mineral [[pyrolusite]]) could be reacted at high temperatures with [[alkali]] to obtain a material that dissolved in water to give a green solution which slowly shifted to a violet-red.Weeks, M. E. and Leicester, H. M.; ''Discovery of the Elements'', Journal of Chemical Education '''1968''' This process, similar to that still used in the production of potassium permanganate,Reidies, Arno H. (2002) "Manganese Compounds" in ''Ullmann's Encyclopedia of Industrial Chemistry'', Wiley-VCH, Weinheim. {{DOI|10.1002/14356007.a16_123}} oxidized [[manganese dioxide]] to [[potassium manganate]] which, acidified by [[carbon dioxide]] absorbed from the air, oxidized further to purple potassium permanganate. The chemical chameleon reaction shows the process in reverse, by reducing violet potassium permanganate first to green potassium manganate and eventually to brown manganese dioxide:{{cite web|title=The Chemical Chameleon|url=http://oise-is-chemistry-2011-2012.wikispaces.com/file/view/Chem%20Chameleon%20Handout.docx/317092198/Chem%20Chameleon%20Handout.docx|publisher=[[Ontario Institute for Studies in Education]]|accessdate=20 March 2014|format=docx}} :[[potassium permanganate|KMnO4]] (violet) → [[potassium manganate|K2MnO4]] (green) → [[Manganese dioxide|MnO2]] (brown/yellow suspension) Blue [[potassium hypomanganate]] may also form as an intermediate.[http://science.perthuniversity.org/chemistry-experiment-kmno4-naoh-sugar/ Faculty of Science Perth University: Chemistry experiment – KMnO4 + NaOH + sugar] {|class="wikitable floatright" |- ! colspan=2|Oxidation states of manganese{{cite book|title = Anorganische Chemie II.|chapter = VII. Nebengruppe|pages = 100–109|first = Max|last = Schmidt|publisher = Wissenschaftsverlag|year = 1968|language = German}} |- | '''+7''' || [[Potassium permanganate|{{chem|KMnO|4}}]] (violet) |- | '''+6''' || [[Potassium manganate|{{chem|K|2|MnO|4}}]] (green)) |- | '''+5''' || [[Potassium hypomanganate|{{chem|K|3|MnO|4}}]] (blue) |- | '''+4''' || [[Manganese dioxide|{{chem|MnO|2}}]] (yellow) |} The reaction proceeds in alkaline conditions under the influence of a reducing agent. [[Sodium hydroxide]], [[potassium hydroxide]], and [[ammonium hydroxide]] can be used to alkalize the permanganate solution, while a variety of reducing agents can be used, [[sugar]]s being common.{{cite book|title=Chem C3000 Experiment Manual|publisher=Thames & Kosmos|page=53|url=http://www.thamesandkosmos.com/news/manualsamples/640132_chemc3000v2_manual_sample.pdf}} A similar demonstration involves soaking paper in alkalized permanganate solution, which produces the same color changes as the paper is oxidized and the permanganate reduced.{{cite book|last=Thompson|first=Robert Bruce|title=Illustrated Guide to Home Chemistry Experiments|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=iZVCN05SURsC|chapter=Lab 10.2: Oxidation States of Manganese}} ==References== {{reflist}} [[Category:Chemistry classroom experiments]] [[Category:Articles containing video clips]]

revision.text:
{{about||the American soldier and Medal of Honor recipient|Daniel G. Caldwell|the colonial government official in Hong Kong|Daniel Richard Caldwell}} {{Infobox person | name = Daniel Caldwell | image = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = 1935 | birth_place = [[Marin, California]] | death_date = {{death date|2015|3|15}} | death_place =[[Tiburon, California]] | othername = Dan Caldwell | occupation = [[actor]], [[stage director]], [[drama]] teacher | years_active = 1962–present | spouse = Karlene Crockett | partner = | website = }} '''Daniel Edmund Caldwell''' (1935 – March 15, 2015) was an American actor, [[stage director]] and [[drama]] teacher. He was the founder of Conservatory Theatre Ensemble in [[Mill Valley, California]], where he taught drama at [[Tamalpais High School]].<ref>[http://www.marinij.com/general-news/20150324/visionary-tam-high-drama-teacher-dan-caldwell-dies-at-79 Visionary Tam High drama teacher Dan Caldwell dies at 79]</ref><ref>http://www.legacy.com/obituaries/marinij/obituary.aspx?pid=174424590</ref>
==Early life and education==
Caldwell attended Tamalpais High School, transferring to [[Sir Francis Drake High School]] in [[Fairfax, California|Fairfax]] when it opened in 1951. He graduated from Drake in 1952.
==Teaching career==
Caldwell taught drama for 37 years at [[Tamalpais High School]], from 1962 to until his retirement in 1999. In 1976, with Michelle Swanson, he cofounded the Ensemble Theatre Company of Marin (ETC), which later changed its name to the Conservatory Theatre Ensemble (CTE).<ref>[http://www.marinscope.com/rossvalleyreporter/detail_page.php?rdate=2008-05-01%2014:54:54&pcode=MVH&scode=Mn1&ldate=2008-01-30%2017:07:23 "A look back at Tam High’s rich history"], Chuck Oldenburg, ''Mill Valley Herald,'' retrieved September 7, 2008, from the ''Ross Valley Reporter''</ref> Calwell and Swanson won the F. Loren Winship Secondary School Theatre Award from the American Alliance of Theatre and Education in 1988 and 1990.<ref>[http://www.aate.com/awards_winners.asp American Alliance of Theatre and Education, AATE Awards] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080513151709/http://www.aate.com/awards_winners.asp |date=2008-05-13 }}, retrieved September 7, 2008</ref>
Notable former students at Tam and CTE include [[Michael Thomsett]] (Class of 1966), [[Kathleen Quinlan]] (Class of 1972),<ref>[http://www.marinij.com/lifestyles/ci_7189746 "Milley Awards: Quinlan's favorite role: Mom"], [[Michael Aron]] (class of 1986) Paul Liberatore, October 15, 2007, ''Marin Independent Journal,'' retrieved September 7, 2008</ref> [[Courtney Thorne-Smith]] (1985), and [[Tupac Shakur]] (1989), [[Merritt Butrick]] (September 3, 1959 – March 17, 1989) in the mid 70's.
In 2002, the [[Tamalpais Union High School District]] named the new theater under construction at Tam the "Daniel Caldwell Performing Arts Center."<ref>[http://www.tamdistrict.org/board/minutes/2002/1022.htm Tamalpais Union High School District, Board of Trustees Minutes, October 22, 2002 • Regular Meeting] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060630164433/http://tamdistrict.org/board/minutes/2002/1022.htm |date=June 30, 2006 }}, retrieved September 7, 2008</ref> The new Center was completed and opened in 2006.
==Stage and film career==
Caldwell's early career as a film actor includes work with [[Woody Allen]], [[Otto Preminger]], [[Michelangelo Antonioni]], [[Tommy Chong]], [[Richard Lester]] and [[John Korty]].<ref name=CTEbio>[http://www.ctetam.org/pages/teachers-staff/guest/guest_DCaldwell.html Conservatory Theatre Ensemble, Guest Artists: Daniel Caldwell] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081120183104/http://www.ctetam.org/pages/teachers-staff/guest/guest_DCaldwell.html |date=2008-11-20 }}, retrieved September 7, 2008 (His acting and directing credits can not easily be determined on the Internet Movie Database (IMDB.com), which combines at least some of his credits with those of another actor named Dan Caldwell who died in 1996.)</ref> He was also a director in the early years of [[Marin Shakespeare Company|Marin Shakespeare Festival]] and a freelance director of the long running play, ''The Trial Of James McNeill Whistler.'' His recent work included ''The Art of Dining.'' at Marin Theatre Company, ''Autumn Canticle,'' at the Eureka Theatre, and the film ''Dead City,'' directed by his former student and CTE grad, Jason Houston.
Caldwell was Vice-President of the [[Screen Actors Guild]], serving as president of the San Francisco branch for 18 years. He served on the Board of Directors for the Marin Arts Council, the Magic Carpet Play Company, and Teen’s Kickoff. He was married to actress Karlene Crockett.<ref name=CTEbio/>
== References == {{Reflist}}
{{Portal|San Francisco Bay Area}} {{Authority control}}

/* Life and career */
revision.text:
{{Infobox scientist |name = Donald Rodney Justice |image = Donald Justice.jpg |image_size = 208px |birth_date = {{birth date|1925|8|12}} |birth_place = [[Miami, Florida]], [[United States|U.S.]] |death_date = {{death date and age|2004|8|6|1925|8|12}} |death_place = [[Iowa City, Iowa]], U.S. |nationality = [[United States]] |field = Poetry |work_institutions = [[University of Florida]]
[[Syracuse University]] |alma_mater = [[University of Miami]]
[[University of Iowa]] |doctoral_advisor = |doctoral_students = |known_for = |prizes = [[Guggenheim Fellowship]]
[[Pulitzer Prize]] }} '''Donald Justice''' (August 12, 1925 – August 6, 2004) was an American [[poet]] and teacher of writing. In summing up Justice's career [[David Orr (journalist)|David Orr]] wrote, "In most ways, Justice was no different from any number of solid, quiet older writers devoted to traditional short poems. But he was different in one important sense: sometimes his poems weren't just good; they were great. They were great in the way that Elizabeth Bishop's poems were great, or Thom Gunn's or Philip Larkin's. They were great in the way that tells us what poetry used to be, and is, and will be."{{cite news |last=Orr |first=David |title='Collected Poems': The Ironist of Nostalgia |date=August 29, 2004 |work=The New York Times |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2004/08/29/books/review/29ORRL.html}} ==Life and career== Justice grew up in Florida, and earned a bachelor's degree from the [[University of Miami]] in 1945. He received an M.A. from the [[University of North Carolina]] in 1947, studied for a time at [[Stanford University]], and ultimately earned a doctorate from the [[University of Iowa]] in 1954. He went on to teach for many years at the [[Iowa Writers' Workshop]], the nation's first graduate program in creative writing. He also taught at [[Syracuse University]], the [[University of California]] at Irvine, [[Princeton University]], the [[University of Virginia]], and the [[University of Florida]] in [[Gainesville, Florida|Gainesville]].{{cite news |title=Donald Justice, 78, a Poet Admired for Precise Beauty |work=The New York Times |date=August 10, 2004 |last=Saxon |first=Wolfgang |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2004/08/10/arts/donald-justice-78-a-poet-admired-for-precise-beauty.html}}Date of birth taken from the [[Social Security Death Index]].{{cite web |title=Notable University of Iowa Alums |url=http://www.uiowa.edu/facts/alumni/notable.htm |publisher=University of Iowa |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100723035804/http://www.uiowa.edu/facts/alumni/notable.htm |archivedate=2010-07-23 |df= }} Justice published thirteen collections of his poetry. The first collection, ''The Summer Anniversaries'', was the winner of the [[James Laughlin Award|Lamont Poetry Prize]] given by the [[Academy of American Poets]] in 1961; ''Selected Poems'' won the [[Pulitzer Prize for Poetry]] in 1980. He was awarded the [[Bollingen Prize]] in Poetry in 1991, and the [[Lannan Literary Awards#Lannan Literary Award for Poetry|Lannan Literary Award for Poetry]] in 1996. His honors also included grants from the [[Guggenheim Fellowship|Guggenheim Foundation]], the [[Rockefeller Foundation]], and the [[National Endowment for the Arts]]. He was a member of the [[American Academy of Arts and Letters]], and a Chancellor of the [[Academy of American Poets]] from 1997 to 2003. His ''Collected Poems'' was nominated for the [[National Book Award]] in 2004. Justice was also a National Book Award Finalist in 1961, 1974, and 1995. In his obituary, Andrew Rosenheim notes that Justice "was a legendary teacher, and despite his own Formalist reputation influenced a wide range of younger writers — his students included [[Mark Strand]], [[Rita Dove]], [[James Tate (writer)|James Tate]], [[C. Dale Young]], [[Ellen Bryant Voigt]], Will Schmitz, [[Jorie Graham]] and the novelist [[John Irving]]."{{cite news |last=Rosenheim |first=Andrew |date=August 18, 2004 |title=Donald Justice: Award-winning poet revered by his peers and influential to a wide range of younger writers |work=[[The Independent]] |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/obituaries/donald-justice-550298.html}} His student and later colleague [[Marvin Bell]] said in a reminiscence, "As a teacher, Don chose always to be on the side of the poem, defending it from half-baked attacks by students anxious to defend their own turf. While he had firm preferences in private, as a teacher Don defended all turfs. He had little use for poetic theory..."{{cite journal |last=Bell |first=Marvin |journal=[[The Iowa Review]] |volume=34 |issue=3 |title=A Garland for Donald Justice: A Reminiscence |pages=177–178 |date=Winter 2004–2005 |jstor=20151937}} Of Justice's accomplishments as a poet, his former student, the poet and critic [[Tad Richards]], noted that "Donald Justice is likely to be remembered as a poet who gave his age a quiet but compelling insight into loss and distance, and who set a standard for craftsmanship, attention to detail, and subtleties of rhythm."Richards, Tad (2005). [http://www.opus40.org/tadrichards/DJusticeGW.html "Donald Justice,"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081202113409/http://www.opus40.org/tadrichards/DJusticeGW.html |date=December 2, 2008 }} ''Greenwood Encyclopedia of American Poets and Poetry'' (Greenwood Press). {{ISBN|978-0-313-32381-2}}. Online version retrieved November 9, 2007. Justice's work was the subject of the 1998 volume ''Certain Solitudes: On The Poetry of Donald Justice'', a collection of essays edited by [[Dana Gioia]] and [[William Logan (poet)|William Logan]].{{cite book |editor1-last=Gioia |editor1-first=Dana |editor2-last=Logan |editor2-first=William |date=1998 |title=Certain Solitudes: On The Poetry of Donald Justice |publisher=University of Arkansas Press |isbn=978-1-55728-475-4 |oclc=875545534}} ==Death== Justice died August 6, 2004 at an Iowa City, IA nursing home. He'd been staying at the nursing home after suffering a stroke several weeks before he died. He was 78 years old. His family said the immediate cause of death was pneumonia, but that he also had [[Parkinson's disease]]. ==Published work== In bertram's Rose Garden was published in the compilation made by James K bell and Adrian A cohan entitled "Toward the new America".{{Cite book|title=Toward The New America|last=Bell - Cohn|first=James - Adrian|publisher=D.C health and company reprinted from The summer anniversaries|year=1970|isbn=|location=United states of America|pages=238}} ===Poetry collections=== *''The Old Bachelor and Other Poems'' (Pandanus Press, Miami, FL), 1951. *''The Summer Anniversaries'' ([[Wesleyan University Press]], Middletown, CT), 1960; revised edition (University Press of New England, Hanover, NH), 1981. *''A Local Storm'' (Stone Wall Press, Iowa City, IA, 1963). *''Night Light'' (Wesleyan University Press, Middletown, CT, 1967); revised edition (University Press of New England, Hanover, NH, 1981). *''Sixteen Poems'' (Stone Wall Press, Iowa City, IA, 1970). *''From a Notebook'' (Seamark Press, Iowa City, IA, 1971). *''Departures'' (Atheneum, New York, NY, 1973). *''Selected Poems'' (Atheneum, New York, NY, 1979). *''Tremayne'' (Windhover Press, Iowa City, IA, 1984). *''The Sunset Maker'' (Anvil Press Poetry, 1987). {{ISBN|978-0-85646-195-8}}. *''A Donald Justice Reader'' (Middlebury, 1991). {{ISBN|978-0-87451-626-5}}. *''New and Selected Poems'' (Knopf, 1995). {{ISBN|978-0-679-44173-1}}. *''Orpheus Hesitated beside the Black River: Poems, 1952-1997'' (Anvil Press Poetry, London, England), 1998. *''Collected Poems'' (Knopf, 2004). {{ISBN|978-1-4000-4239-5}} . ===Essay and interview collections=== *''Platonic Scripts'', 1984 *''Oblivion: On Writers and Writing'', 1998 *''Compendium: A Collection of Thoughts on Prosody.'' ed. David Koehn & Alan Soldofsky (Omnidawn, 2017). {{ISBN|978-1-63243-032-8}}http://www.omnidawn.com/products-page/new-upcoming-releases/compendium-a-collection-of-thoughts-on-prosody-donald-justice/ ===Edited volumes=== Justice edited posthumous selections of unpublished poetry for four poets: Weldon Kees, Henri Coulette, Raeburn Miller, and Joe Bolton. *{{cite book |title=Contemporary French Poetry: Fourteen Witnesses after Man's Fate |last=Aspel |first=Alexander |editor2-last=Justice |editor2-first=Donald |editor1-last=Aspel |editor1-first=Alexander |year=1965 |publisher=University of Michigan Press}} *{{cite book |last1=Kees |first1=Weldon |authorlink=Weldon Kees |last2=Wojahn |first2=David |title=The Collected Poems of Weldon Kees (Third Edition) |editor1-last=Justice |editor1-first=Donald |year=2003 |publisher=Bison Books |isbn=978-0-8032-7809-7}} The first edition of this collection was published in 1960. *{{cite book |title=Collected Poems of [[Henri Coulette]] |last=Coulette |first=Henri |authorlink=Henri Coulette |editor1-last=Justice |editor1-first=Donald |editor2-last=Mezey |editor2-first=Robert |year=1990 |publisher=University of Arkansas Press |isbn=978-1-55728-145-6}} *{{cite book |last1=Miller |first1=Raeburn |last2=Justice |first2=Donald |authorlink=Raeburn Miller |editor1-last=Justice |editor1-first=Donald |editor2-last=Mackin |editor2-first=Cooper R. |editor3-first=Richard D. |editor3-last=Olson |title=The Comma after Love: Selected Poems of Raeburn Miller |publisher=University of Akron Press |year=1994 |isbn=978-1-884836-03-9}} *{{cite book |last=Bolton |first=Joe |authorlink=Joe Bolton (poet) |title=Last Nostalgia: Poems 1982-1990 |editor1-last=Justice |editor1-first=Donald |year=1999 |isbn=978-1-55728-558-4}} ===Libretti=== *''The Young God - A Vaudeville'' (opera by Edward Miller), 1969 *''The Death of Lincoln: an opera by Edwin London on an original libretto by Donald Justice'', 1988 ==Further reading== *Justice, Donald and Hoy, Richard (2002). ''Donald Justice in Conversation With Philip Hoy'' (Between the Lines). {{ISBN|9780953284191}}. ==See also== {{portal|Poetry}} * [[Donald Justice Poetry Prize]] * [[American poetry]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{wikiquote}} *Renner, B. (1997). [https://web.archive.org/web/20061012084034/http://www.elimae.com/interviews/justice.html "Donald Justice interview"], [https://web.archive.org/web/20061004032845/http://elimae.com/ ''Elimae''] (an electronic literary magazine). *[http://www.poetryfoundation.org/archive/poet.html?id=80787 Biography and links to several poems] at the [[Poetry Foundation]] website. Retrieved November 9, 2007. {{PulitzerPrize PoetryAuthors 1976–2000}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Justice, Donald}} [[Category:1925 births]] [[Category:2004 deaths]] [[Category:University of Florida faculty]] [[Category:Formalist poets]] [[Category:American male poets]] [[Category:Writers from Miami]] [[Category:Pulitzer Prize for Poetry winners]] [[Category:University of Miami alumni]] [[Category:University of Iowa faculty]] [[Category:Syracuse University faculty]] [[Category:University of Virginia faculty]] [[Category:Princeton University faculty]] [[Category:University of California, Irvine faculty]] [[Category:Iowa Writers' Workshop alumni]] [[Category:Iowa Writers' Workshop faculty]] [[Category:Poets from Florida]] [[Category:Bollingen Prize recipients]] [[Category:Guggenheim Fellows]] [[Category:20th-century American poets]] [[Category:20th-century American male writers]]

{{short description|administration of education systems}} {{Multiple issues|{{copy edit|date=November 2018}}{{globalize|date=November 2018}}}}
{{For|other uses|Education|Education (disambiguation)|Management}} [[File:Educational Management Mindmap.jpg|thumb|An Overview of Educational Management]]
'''Educational management''' refers to the administration of the education system whereby a collective group combines human and material resources to supervise, plan, strategise, and implement structures to execute the functions of an education system.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nie.edu.sg/higher-degrees/masters-by-coursework/master-of-arts-educational-management|title=Master of Arts (Educational Management) {{!}} National Institute of Education (NIE), Singapore|website=www.nie.edu.sg|language=en|access-date=2018-10-18}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Connolly|first=Michael|last2=James|first2=Chris|last3=Fertig|first3=Michael|date=2017-12-20|title=The difference between educational management and educational leadership and the importance of educational responsibility|journal=Educational Management Administration & Leadership|language=en|pages=174114321774588|doi=10.1177/1741143217745880|issn=1741-1432}}</ref>
Education is the equipping of knowledge, skills, values, beliefs, habits, and attitudes through learning experiences. The education system is an ecosystem of professionals situated in educational institutions such as Government ministries, unions, statutory boards, agencies, and schools. The education system comprises political heads, principals, teaching staff, non-teaching staff, administrative personnel and other education professionals working in tandem to enrich and enhance.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.rand.org/topics/educational-administration.html|title=Educational Administration|website=www.rand.org|language=en|access-date=2018-11-09}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://learn.org/articles/What_is_Educational_Management.html|title=What Is Educational Management?|access-date=2018-10-17|language=en}}</ref> At all levels of the ecosystem in the education system, management is required. Management involves the planning, organising, implementation, review, evaluation, and integration of clear deliverables of the institution.
The function of educational management can be referenced to [[Henri Fayol]]'s 14 Principles of Management.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.managementstudyhq.com/henri-fayol-principles-of-management.html|title=Henri Fayol's 14 Principles of Management {{!}} Management Study HQ|date=2013-07-24|work=Management Study HQ|access-date=2018-10-18|language=en-US}}</ref>
== Scope ==
=== Co-curricular Activities === Co-curricular activities help students maintain a holistic education and are a key expression of students' interests and talents. These activities also help foster a sense of social integration and add an important sense of commitment and belonging to one's community and country. Co-curricular activities include science-oriented talent development programmes, clubs and societies, physical sports, uniformed groups, and visual and performing arts groups. Co-curricular activities could also include student interests groups such as advocacy groups, botany, personal care, innovation, research methodologies, and current affairs.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.np.edu.sg/studentlife/Pages/ccas.aspx|title=Clubs & Societies|website=www.np.edu.sg|language=en-SG|access-date=2018-10-31}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.sst.edu.sg/cca/|title=CCA|website=School of Science and Technology, Singapore|access-date=2018-10-31}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.mgs.moe.edu.sg/secondary/mg-curriculum/co-curricular-activities-cca/achievements|title=Achievements|website=www.mgs.moe.edu.sg|language=en|access-date=2018-10-31}}</ref>
=== Curriculum Planning and Development === Curriculum planning and development involves “the design and development of integrated plans for learning, and of the evaluation of plans, their implementation and the outcomes of the learning experience”.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.flinders.edu.au/teaching/teaching-strategies/curriculum-development/a-curriculum-process.cfm|title=A Curriculum Development Process|website=www.flinders.edu.au|language=en|access-date=2018-10-04}}</ref> The role of this department is to design and review curriculum, promote teaching and assessment strategies that are aligned to curriculum frameworks, formulate special curriculum programmes, create clear and observable objectives, and generate effective assessment rubrics.<ref>{{Cite book|title=The skilful teacher: Building your teaching skills|last=Saphier|first=J|last2=Haley|first2=M|last3=Gower|last4=R|publisher=Research For Better Teaching|year=2008|isbn=|location=Acton, MA|pages=}}</ref>
Curriculum development can be described in a three-stage process, encompassing the planned curriculum, the delivered curriculum, and lastly the experienced curriculum.<ref name=":0" /> The curriculum is often shaped by the pedagogical approaches contributed by theorists and researchers such as notable figures like [[John Dewey]], [[Lev Vygotsky]], [[Jean Piaget]], [[Jerome Bruner]], and [[Albert Bandura]].<ref>{{Cite book|title=Nurturing Early Learners: A Curriculum Framework for Kindergartens in Singapore|last=Ministry of Education, Singapore|publisher=Ministry of Education, Singapore|year=2012|isbn=|location=Singapore|pages=}}</ref>
==== Pre-school Education ==== Curriculum development as the pre-school education level is based on the different school of thoughts. They include but are not limited to:
* The [[Kindergarten|Froebelian Kindergarten]] was established by [[Friedrich Fröbel|Friedrich Wilhelm August Fröbel]] when he set up the first kindergarten programme in Germany in 1837. Froebel described three forms of knowledge that he viewed as essential aspects that formed the basis of all learning.<ref name=":2">{{Cite book|title=Who Am I in the Lives of Children? An Introduction to Early Childhood Education|last=Feeney|first=Stephanie|last2=Moravcik|first2=Eva|last3=Nolte|last4=Sherry|publisher=Pearson Education|year=2013|isbn=978-981-45-2689-0|location=Singapore|pages=}}</ref> Firstly, knowledge of forms of life, which include an appreciation for gardening, animals and domestic tasks. Secondly, the knowledge of forms of mathematics, such as geometry and the relationships with each form. Lastly, knowledge of forms of beauty, which include colour and shape, harmonies and movement.<ref name=":2" /> The goals of the Froebelian Kindergarten are awakening the child's physical senses through learning experiences and providing common ground for all individuals to advance. The practices that have been adapted from the Froebelian Kindergarten include teaching materials and activities, as well as education preparation programmes for teachers *[[Margaret McMillan|Margaret]] and [[Rachel McMillan]] were social reformers in England who spend their lives trying to address the problems poverty.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.mcmillannurseryschool.co.uk/?p=2078|title=History of the McMillan Sisters|date=2015-01-15|work=McMillan Nursery School|access-date=2018-10-17|language=en-US}}</ref> The established the Open-Air [[Preschool|Nursery School]] and Training Centre in London. The goals of the [[Preschool|Nursery School]] were to provide loving care, health support, nourishment and physical welfare to children.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Betty|first=Liebovich|date=2014|title=The Contributions of the McMIllan Sisters to Early Years Education in England.|journal=FORUM: For Promoting 3-19 Comprehensive Education|volume=56|issue=3|pages=529|doi=10.15730/forum.2014.56.3.529}}</ref> Additionally, assistance was provided to parents to aid them in caring for and interacting with their children. Pedagogical models on how to engage and interact with young children were also provided. The pedagogical principles of the [[Preschool|Nursery School]] can be found in educational frameworks that require teachers to nurture and teach a curriculum that covers the domains of an exploration of the world, aesthetics, music and movement and literacy.<ref name=":2" /> *[[John Dewey]] formed the theory of [[Progressive education]] during the progressive movement.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.britannica.com/biography/John-Dewey|title=John Dewey {{!}} American philosopher and educator|work=Encyclopedia Britannica|access-date=2018-10-17|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.britannica.com/biography/John-Dewey|title=John Dewey {{!}} American philosopher and educator|work=Encyclopedia Britannica|access-date=2018-10-18|language=en}}</ref> The progressive education philosophy embraces the idea that children should be taught how to think. Dewey was opposed to assessments as they cannot measure whether or not a child is an educated person.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.thoughtco.com/progressive-education-how-children-learn-today-2774713|title=Progressive Education - How Children Learn|work=ThoughtCo|access-date=2018-10-18}}</ref> Therefore, the school community offers learning opportunities that are interesting and meaningful, and prepare individuals to live in a democratic society. Children learn through doing, cooperation, problem solving and collaborations with the teacher acting as a guide. For example, projects in the curriculum encourage exploration, self-discovery and sensorial experiences that translate to a holistic approach. The curriculum focusses on the children's interests and are developmentally appropriate.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.naeyc.org/resources/topics/12-principles-of-child-development|title=12 Principles of Child Development and Learning that Inform Practice {{!}} NAEYC|website=www.naeyc.org|language=en|access-date=2018-10-18}}</ref> *The [[Montessori education|Montessori]] approach was developed by [[Maria Montessori]] who believed that children go through sensitive periods, also known as 'window of opportunities'.<ref name="What is Montessori Education">{{Cite web|url=https://montessori-nw.org/what-is-montessori-education/|title=What is Montessori Education?|website=Montessori Northwest - Montessori Teacher Training & Professional Development in Portland, Oregon|language=en-US|access-date=2018-11-08}}</ref> Every material in a Montessori classroom enhances and develops the child's growth. Materials consist of children's interests and found materials in the natural environment.<ref name="What is Montessori Education"/> The whole learning environment is focused on the child, also known as the child-centred environment. The curriculum trains children to be responsive and promote the desire for skills mastery.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Curriculum: Alternative approaches.|last=Marsh|first=C.|last2=Willis|first2=G|publisher=Pearson/Merrill Prentice|year=2007|isbn=|location=Upper Saddle River, NJ|pages=}}</ref> *Waldorf Education was created by Austrian philosopher [[Rudolf Steiner]]. In Waldorf education, there is a great focus on the whole child, in particular the body, mind, and spirit.<ref name=":2" /> The curriculum is designed to provoke thought processes, create sensitivity in their feelings, and enhance fluency in creative and artistic representations.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://waldorfpeninsula.org/curriculum/|title=Curriculum - Waldorf School of the Peninsula|work=Waldorf School of the Peninsula|access-date=2018-11-08|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.waldorfsingapore.com/about-waldorf-education/|title=About Waldorf Education {{!}}|website=www.waldorfsingapore.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-11-08}}</ref> The Waldorf curriculum consists of storytelling, aesthetics (arts), practical work, imaginative play, and discovery of nature.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://waldorfpeninsula.org/curriculum/early-childhood/|title=Early Childhood - Waldorf School of the Peninsula|work=Waldorf School of the Peninsula|access-date=2018-11-08|language=en-US}}</ref> Modern schools adopting the Waldorf Education are independent, self-governing schools due to the spirituality-based pedagogy.<ref name=":2" /> *The Reggio Emilia Approach was created in a small northern Italian city of [[Reggio Emilia]]. It is influenced by constructivist theories and the progressive education movement, with a commitment to uphold the rights of individuals.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Child development : an active learning approach|last=E.|first=Levine, Laura|others=Munsch, Joyce|isbn=9781506386737|edition= Third|location=Los Angeles ; London ; New Delhi ; Singapore ; Washington DC ; Melbourne|oclc=992503617|date = 2017-05-02}}</ref> Key concepts in a Reggio Emilia school include the child's right to education, the importance of interpersonal relationships amongst children, teachers and parents, and children's interactions through work and play.<ref name="The Compass School">{{Cite news|url=https://www.thecompassschool.com/about/reggio-emilia-inspired-philosophy/|title=The Reggio Emilia Philosophy of Learning {{!}} The Compass School|work=The Compass School|access-date=2018-11-08|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.reggiochildren.it/identita/reggio-emilia-approach/?lang=en|title=Reggio Emilia Approach {{!}} Reggio Children|website=Reggio Emilia Approach {{!}} Reggio Children|language=en-US|access-date=2018-11-08}}</ref> The curriculum emerges from the children's interest and developed through projects and inquiry.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://mulberrylearning.com/reggio-emilia-approach-works/|title=The Reggio Emilia Approach And Why It Works - Mulberry|date=2016-05-16|work=Mulberry|access-date=2018-11-08|language=en-US}}</ref> Each individual plays an important role in the school and parental involvement is a key aspect of the child's learning and development.<ref name="The Compass School"/> *
==== Primary Education ==== Curriculum development at the primary education focuses on the foundations of subjects. The curriculum covers the various aspects of Subject Disciplines, Knowledge Skills, and Character Development.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.moe.gov.sg/education/primary/primary-school-curriculum|title=Primary School Curriculum|website=www.moe.gov.sg|access-date=2018-10-31}}</ref> Subject disciplines comprise the various core and foundational subjects of Language, Science, Humanities, Arts, Technology, and Social Studies.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/national-curriculum-in-england-primary-curriculum|title=National curriculum in England: primary curriculum|website=GOV.UK|language=en|access-date=2018-10-31}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cambridgeschool.eu/en/curriculum-learning/primary-curriculum/|title=Primary Curriculum - Primary School Curriculum|website=www.cambridgeschool.eu|language=en|access-date=2018-10-31}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.australiancurriculum.edu.au/resources/primary-curriculum/illustrations-of-practice/landsdale-primary-school/|title=Landsdale Primary School|website=www.australiancurriculum.edu.au|language=en|access-date=2018-10-31}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.australiancurriculum.edu.au/f-10-curriculum/learning-areas/|title=Learning areas|website=www.australiancurriculum.edu.au|language=en|access-date=2018-10-31}}</ref> Knowledge skills involve personal skills and attributes such as communication, critical thinking, teamwork, and judgement. These skills are developed through unique learning experiences based on the school's pedagogical practices, which are aligned with the mission and vision.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Primary School Education: Preparing Your Child For The Future|last=Ministry of Education, Singapore|publisher=Ministry of Education, Singapore|year=2018|isbn=|location=Singapore|pages=}}</ref> Character development, according to Eisner, is defined as the implicit curriculum, otherwise known as the hidden agenda of the school.<ref>{{Cite book|url=http://teaching.up.edu/edresearch/pages/Eisner.html|title=Five conceptions of curriculum: Their roots and implications for curriculum planning|last=Eisner|first=E. W.|last2=Vance|first2=E.|publisher=McCutchan Publishing Company|year=1974|isbn=|location=Berkeley, CA|pages= 1–14}}</ref> Character traits and attributes include resilience, self-discipline, empathy, and compassion which primarily focuses on the social-emotional development of each student.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Developing character skills in schools: Summary report|last=Department of Education|publisher=Department of Education|year=2017|isbn=978-1-78105-759-9|location=United Kingdom|pages=}}</ref> The curriculum development serves as a springboard towards personal and social capabilities, ethical and intercultural understanding, and sound moral judgement.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.australiancurriculum.edu.au/f-10-curriculum/general-capabilities/|title=General capabilities|website=www.australiancurriculum.edu.au|language=en|access-date=2018-10-31}}</ref>
==== Secondary Education ==== Curriculum development varies based on the course or stream the student is enrolled in.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://beta.moe.gov.sg/courses/|title=Courses and subjects for secondary schools {{!}} Ministry of Education|website=beta.moe.gov.sg|language=en|access-date=2018-11-07}}</ref> Curriculum development primarily focuses on core subjects such as Language, Mathematics, Science, and Humanities.<ref name=":9">{{Cite web|url=https://beta.moe.gov.sg/courses/express/|title=Express course for secondary school {{!}} Ministry of Education|website=beta.moe.gov.sg|language=en|access-date=2018-11-07}}</ref><ref name=":10">{{Cite web|url=http://www.ncdc.go.ug/content/o-level-curriculum|title=O Level Curriculum|last=National Curriculum Development Centre (NCDC)|date=2018|website=National Curriculum Development Centre (NCDC)|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=7 November 2018}}</ref><ref name=":11">{{Cite web|url=https://www.edb.gov.hk/en/curriculum-development/renewal/guides.html|title=Ongoing Renewal of The School Curriculum|last=|publisher=Education Bureau|date=2013|website=The Government of the Hong Kong Special Administration Region|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=7 November 2018}}</ref> The learning experiences, strategic goals, national frameworks, and school philosophy are also considered in curriculum development.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://beta.moe.gov.sg/schools/how-to-choose/|title=How to choose secondary schools {{!}} Ministry of Education|website=beta.moe.gov.sg|language=en|access-date=2018-11-07}}</ref> Schools also consider values and progressive skills in the development of a holistic curriculum.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.edb.gov.hk/attachment/en/curriculum-development/renewal/Guides/SECG%20booklet%202_en_20180831.pdf|title=Learning Goals, School Curriculum Framework and Planning|last=The Government of The Hong Kong Administrative Region|publisher=Education Bureau|year=2017|isbn=|location=Hong Kong|pages=4}}</ref> Special elective and vocational programmes are also offered which includes social studies, art and music, design and technology and computer studies.<ref name=":9" /><ref name=":10" /><ref name=":11" /> Specialised schools integrate programmes with corporate partners to include programmes such as Information and Communication Technology, Entrepreneurship, Art, Design, Media and Da Vinci.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.sst.edu.sg/programmes/extended-curriculum/|title=Extended Curriculum|website=School of Science and Technology, Singapore|access-date=2018-10-31}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nushigh.edu.sg/academic-curriculum/nus-high-school-diploma|title=NUS High School Diploma|website=www.nushigh.edu.sg|language=en|access-date=2018-10-31}}</ref> Additionally, enhanced programmes in sports, arts, and language are offered in schools with specified goals in education and curriculum.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Secondary School Education: Shaping the Next Phase of your Child's Learning Journey|last=Ministry of Education, Singapore|publisher=Ministry of Education, Singapore|year=2018|isbn=|location=Singapore|pages=}}</ref>
==== Tertiary Education ==== Curriculum development at the tertiary education level involves specific course design and development. Griffith University describes planning as based on previously collected evidence; the process also involves assessment, technologically informed learning and discipline-based capabilities.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=https://www.griffith.edu.au/learning-futures/our-practice/curriculum-development|title=Curriculum development|last=Searles|first=Ainslie|website=www.griffith.edu.au|language=en|access-date=2018-10-04}}</ref> Thus, this process aims to prepare students for the workforce, while enhancing their understanding of the subject. Griffith University, for example, considers five key elements in curriculum development; specifically, Learning Analytics, External Peer Review, Peer-based Professional Learning and Professional Learning Workshops.<ref name=":1" />
=== Educational Technology === Educational technology involves the integration, planning, implementation and management of [[Information and communications technology]] (ICT) for effective learning and teaching.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.edx.org/learn/educational-technology|title=Educational Technology|date=2018-04-09|work=edX|access-date=2018-11-09|language=en}}</ref> The function of the educational technology branch in the education system is for conceptualisation and development of ICT in education, integration into existing curriculum frameworks, staff development, and management.
In modern times, the focus of educational technology has shifted to online and web-based applications, learning portals, flipped classrooms and a whole variety of social networks for the purposes of teaching and learning.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.useoftechnology.com/information-technology-education/|title=6 USES OF INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY IN EDUCATION|last=Ramey|first=Karehka|date=December 2, 2012|website=Useoftechnology.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=9 November 2018}}</ref>
Educational technology includes ICT but is not limited to the use of both physical hardware and educational theoretics. It encompasses several domains including collaborative learning, [[Learning theory (education)|learning theory]], linear learning, online portal learning, and where mobile technologies are used, [[m-learning]].<ref>{{Citation|title=Educational technology|date=2018-09-29|url=https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Educational_technology&oldid=861765814|work=Wikipedia|language=en|access-date=2018-10-04}}</ref> These domains contribute to a personalised learning model promotes self-directed learning as students take charge and are responsible for their own learning.
=== Finance and Budget === This department oversees financial policies regarding the various educational institutes that provides administrative support to schools relating to financial assistance, revenue operations and school funds.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.education.go.ug/data/smenu/9/Finance%20and%20Administration.html|title=Finance and Administration|website=www.education.go.ug|access-date=2018-11-09}}</ref> Financial assistance schemes include subsidies, allowances, and grants funded by the government, that are applied according to income levels and other factors, such as age or institution.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://moey.gov.jm/node/111|title=Finance Division {{!}} Ministry of Education, Youth and Information|website=moey.gov.jm|language=en|access-date=2018-11-09}}</ref> There are also scholarships and awards accorded by merit; however, these may also be reserved for some particular categories of students.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.moe.gov.sg/about/org-structure/fdd|title=Finance & Procurement|website=www.moe.gov.sg|access-date=2018-11-09}}</ref>
=== Health and Physical Development === This department's primary role is to develop safe and effective programmes for educating students on healthy living and physical education. This involves a mastery in a certain sport and a focus on acquiring basic movement skills.<ref name=":4">{{Cite web|url=https://www.shapeamerica.org/publications/resources/teachingtools/teachertoolbox/curriculum.aspx|title=Curriculum in Physical Education: SHAPE America|access-date=2018-10-31}}</ref> The department develops curriculum based on sequential key stage outcomes and the physical abilities of students.<ref name=":4" /> An instructional model may be used as a plan for teaching that includes a theoretical foundation, learning outcomes, sequenced activities and unique task structures.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.phitamerica.org/PE_In_School.htm|title=PE In School - 'The Solution'|website=www.phitamerica.org|access-date=2018-10-31}}</ref> The department may promote parental involvement through partnerships with families and communities and may also rely on support from dieticians, physiotherapists, community health services and sporting associations.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://qed.qld.gov.au/earlychildhood/news/Documents/pdf/aedc-health.pdf|title=Guide to physical health and wellbeing: Resources for Queensland early childhood education and care services|last=Australian Early Development Census|publisher=Australian Early Development Census|year=2018|isbn=|location=Australia|pages=}}</ref>
=== Human Resources === The primary goals of the human resources department are attracting, developing, and retaining staff in the education ministry. They formulate operational policies and systems that directly affect staff's performance and attitudes.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Rafiei|first=Nafiseh|last2=Davari|first2=Fereshte|date=February 2015|title=The Role of Human Resources Management on Enhancing the Teaching Skills of Faculty Members|journal=Journal of the Academy of Medical Sciences of Bosnia and Herzegovina.|volume=27|issue=1|pages=35–38|doi=10.5455/msm.2014.27.35-38|pmid=25870529|pmc=4384864}}</ref> The objectives of the department include a review of organisational structures and procedures, staff skills development and enhancement, and leadership succession and transitions.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.moe.gov.sg/about/org-structure/hr-group|title=Human Resource Group|website=www.moe.gov.sg|access-date=2018-10-31}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://moe.gov.tt/services/hr|title=Ministry of Education|website=moe.gov.tt|language=en-US|access-date=2018-10-31}}</ref> These are aimed at fostering greater staff involvement and expansion, eventually leading to the overall goals of the education system.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://minedu.fi/en/administrative-branch|title=Administrative branch|website=Opetus- ja kulttuuriministeriö|language=en-US|access-date=2018-10-31}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.edu.gov.on.ca/eng/about/whoweare.html|title=Who We Are|last=Ontario|first=Government of|website=www.edu.gov.on.ca|language=en|access-date=2018-10-31}}</ref>
=== Information Technology === Information technology refers to the harnessing of high-quality and calibre technology to facilitate efficient administration, management and hence education.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.moe.gov.sg/about/org-structure/itb|title=Information Technology Branch|website=www.moe.gov.sg|access-date=2018-11-09}}</ref> This requires the need for perpetual, up-to-date staff training to ensure educators of all levels are fully equipped with the skill sets needed; hence the managerial level has to identify and conceptualise relevant information that is needed to be taught to teachers for the implementation of these IT systems.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Hamidi|first=Farideh|last2=Meshkat|first2=Maryam|last3=Rezaee|first3=Maryam|last4=Jafari|first4=Mehdi|date=2011|title=Information technology in education|journal=Procedia Computer Science|volume=3|pages=369–373|doi=10.1016/j.procs.2010.12.062|issn=1877-0509}}</ref> It is also essential to ensure that these IT systems are reliable, accessible and well assimilated by educators. The department faces numerous challenges as IT systems are vulnerable to perpetrators and hackers. A period of close examination during integration may be necessary to guarantee that educators are using the new applications relevantly and correctly. The information management team is also required to conduct surveys to reflect if the implications of new IT policies in the real-world scenario.
=== Psychological === The department is at the forefront of ensuring that students with disabilities are able to participate in the student curriculum on the same basis as their peers.<ref name=":5">{{Cite web|url=https://www.australiancurriculum.edu.au/resources/student-diversity/students-with-disability/|title=Students with disability|website=www.australiancurriculum.edu.au|language=en|access-date=2018-10-31}}</ref> It involves all schools including specialists schools and support classes.<ref name=":5" /> This is key to contributing to fair and equal student diversity. Special support services include reasonable adjustments, consultations, and personalised learning. Allied educators are important in providing a high quality of interaction with each child.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.moe.gov.sg/careers/allied-educators|title=Allied Educators|website=www.moe.gov.sg|access-date=2018-10-31}}</ref> In addition, a multidisciplinary team consisting of psychologists, special educators, and therapists, is crucial in fostering appropriate and meaningful learning.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Educating exceptional children|last=1904-|first=Kirk, Samuel A. (Samuel Alexander)|others=Gallagher, James,, Coleman, Mary Ruth|isbn=9781473732063|edition= Fourteenth |location=Australia|oclc=912318370}}</ref>
=== Special Education === Special Education is aimed to facilitate a healthy learning environment for children with special needs or disabilities so that all children can gain an insightful and fruitful learning experience.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://aase.edu.au/about/about-aase|title=About AASE - Australian Association of Special Education|work=Australian Association of Special Education|access-date=2018-11-07|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.european-agency.org/country-information/finland/teacher-education-for-inclusive-education|title=Country information for Finland - Teacher education for inclusive education {{!}} European Agency for Special Needs and Inclusive Education|website=www.european-agency.org|language=en|access-date=2018-11-07}}</ref> Special Education can take place on two fronts, firstly, in mainstream schools and secondly, in specialised schools.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.britannica.com/topic/special-education|title=Special education|work=Encyclopedia Britannica|access-date=2018-11-07|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.sgenable.sg/pages/content.aspx?path=/for-youths/education-learning/mainstream-education-for-children-with-special-needs/|title=Mainstream Education for Children with Special Needs|website=www.sgenable.sg|language=en-us|access-date=2018-11-07}}</ref> The appropriate choice of learning institution depends on the child's needs and the relevant services available. For example, children may display learning difficulties and/or require additional materials while learning. Relevant courses are designed for children with disabilities such as Autism Spectrum Disorders, Intellectual Disability, Visual Impairment, Hearing Loss and Cerebral Palsy.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.moe.gov.sg/education/special-education|title=Special Educational Needs|website=www.moe.gov.sg|access-date=2018-11-07}}</ref> Additional assistance may be provided by applicable social service organisations, non-government organisations, voluntary welfare organisations, and corporate partners.
=== Student Development === This department's primary role is to create curriculum and programmes that help promote character, arts, citizenship and moral education, and global awareness.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://dfat.gov.au/aid/topics/investment-priorities/education-health/education/Documents/australian-education-system-foundation.pdf|title=The Australian Education System: Foundation Level|last=Australian Government|publisher=Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade|year=2018|isbn=|location=Australia|pages=}}</ref> They operate on the mission of promoting individual student excellence, inciting collaboration and discovery, and challenge students to take responsibility.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.justlanded.com/english/United-States/USA-Guide/Education/Elementary-and-Secondary-Education|title=Elementary and Secondary Education|work=Just Landed|access-date=2018-11-07|language=en}}</ref> This will equip students with future-ready qualities prepared with 21st-century competencies. Furthermore, schools adopt numerous guiding principles that focus on values, collaboration, culture, integration to approach student development programmes.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://westwoodsec.moe.edu.sg/co-curriculum/student-development|title=Student Development|website=westwoodsec.moe.edu.sg|language=en|access-date=2018-11-07}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.sst.edu.sg/programmes/student-development/|title=Student Development|website=School of Science and Technology, Singapore|access-date=2018-11-07}}</ref> Overseas learning opportunities could be integrated to enable students to become more aware of diverse cultures and backgrounds, with the goal of global connectivity and collaboration.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.sst.edu.sg/global-citizenship-programme-gcp/|title=Overseas Learning Experience (OLE)|website=School of Science and Technology, Singapore|access-date=2018-11-07}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.np.edu.sg/publications/Pages/overseas_exposure_2016_2017.aspx|title=overseas_exposure_2016_2017|website=www.np.edu.sg|language=en-SG|access-date=2018-11-07}}</ref>
== Objectives ==
=== At the Ministry/Department Level === The ministries and departments of education are responsible for the "design, implementation, monitoring and evaluation of educational legislation, policies, and programmes".<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.education.gov.fj/index.php/g/ministry-of-education-heritage-arts/roles-responsibilities|title=ROLES & RESPONSIBILITIES|website=www.education.gov.fj|language=en-gb|access-date=2018-10-18}}</ref> They provide structured support in strategic leadership, human resources, budget and administrative and management to ensure that the education system functions effectively and efficiently at the optimum levels.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.education.govt.nz/ministry-of-education/our-role-and-our-people/what-we-do/|title=The role of the Ministry of Education|last=Zealand|first=Education in New|website=Education in New Zealand|language=en-NZ|access-date=2018-10-18}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://old.moe.gov.cn/publicfiles/business/htmlfiles/moe/moe_2797/200907/49988.html|title=The Responsibilities Of the Ministry of Education_MOE.GOV.CN|website=old.moe.gov.cn|access-date=2018-10-18}}</ref>
=== At the Institutional Level === The [[Board of education|Board of Education]] and [[Head teacher|Principals]] are responsible for the management of daily operations of the institution.
The school board formulates policies and has decision-making powers.<ref name="sdhc.k12.fl.us">{{Cite web|url=https://www.sdhc.k12.fl.us/doc/239/school-board/about/|title=School Board - Hillsborough County Public Schools|website=www.sdhc.k12.fl.us|language=en|access-date=2018-11-09}}</ref> Furthermore, their responsibilities include the regulation of the budget for school expenditure, formulation of strategic vision and mission for the school, and review and enhancement of school policies.<ref name="sdhc.k12.fl.us"/> Additionally, the school board monitors school performance and report to key stakeholders such as the Director-General and parents. They are also important in build collaborations with community partners such as parents, government and non-government organisations.<ref name=":13">{{Cite web|url=https://www.nsba.org/about-us/what-school-boards-do|title=What School Boards Do {{!}} National School Boards Association|website=www.nsba.org|language=en|access-date=2018-11-09}}</ref> It is also important to note that the Board of Education can make legal decisions on behalf of the school such as entering contracts and the provision of land.<ref name=":13" />
The principal serves a professional and administrative role in the function of the school.<ref name=":14">{{Cite web|url=https://www.is.vic.edu.au/managing-a-school/governance-guidelines/across-the-board-landing-page/19-the-key-roles-of-the-principal|title=19. The Key Roles of the Principal|website=www.is.vic.edu.au|language=en|access-date=2018-11-09}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.wallacefoundation.org/knowledge-center/pages/the-school-principal-as-leader-guiding-schools-to-better-teaching-and-learning.aspx|title=The School Principal as Leader: Guiding Schools to Better Teaching and Learning|access-date=2018-11-09|language=en-US}}</ref> Together with the school board, they chart the strategic goals of the school which reflect the mission, vision, and philosophy of the school. The professional duties of the principal are to supervise teaching and non-teaching staff to coordinate and manage day-to-day operations.<ref name=":14" /> They are also in charge of the procurement of necessary resources for the school to achieve its strategic goals, and ensuring the staff are trained and equipped with specialised skills (e.g. first-aid, pedagogical practices). Principals are also required to engage parents and community partners and communicate [[Performance indicator|Key Performance Index]] with the Ministry of Education.<ref name=":3" />
Principals "build school culture" to sustain enhancement programmes and campaigns within the institution.<ref>{{Cite journal|title=SAGE Journals: Your gateway to world-class journal research|journal=Educational Management Administration & Leadership|volume=46|issue=6|pages=883–887|language=en|doi=10.1177/1741143218795731|date=November 2018|last1=Bush|first1=Tony}}</ref>
The strategic goals of a school include achieving excellence and engagement in learning, building character and leadership, develop staff competencies, collaborative partnerships, holistic education, quality student outcomes, lifelong learners, and future-ready.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.homebushpublicschool.com.au/our-school/hps-school-plan-2015-2017/447-school-plan|title=School Plan - Homebush Public School|website=www.homebushpublicschool.com.au|language=en-gb|access-date=2018-10-17}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://glebe-p.schools.nsw.gov.au/about-our-school/glebe-public-school-history.html|title=Glebe Public School History - Glebe Public School|website=glebe-p.schools.nsw.gov.au|language=en-AU|access-date=2018-10-17}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://fmsp.moe.edu.sg/about-us/school-information|title=School Information|website=fmsp.moe.edu.sg|language=en|access-date=2018-10-17}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://resourced.prometheanworld.com/school-strategy/|title=School strategy: A guide to meeting strategic goals and challenges in schools|date=2018-05-01|work=ResourcEd|access-date=2018-10-17|language=en-US}}</ref>
=== At the Educator Level === Teachers plan and implement lessons based on pedagogical practices in educational frameworks.<ref name=":12">{{Cite book|title=The skillful teacher : building your teaching skills|last=Jon.|first=Saphier|date=2008|publisher=Research for Better Teaching, Inc|others=Haley-Speca, Mary Ann., Gower, Robert R.|isbn=978-1886822108|edition= 6th|location=Acton, MA|oclc=85019196}}</ref> They are also required to manage and update student portfolios to recognise, and assess the diverse domains of development. These domains of development include social, emotional, intellectual, physical, moral and aesthetic. Pedagogical practices are supported by the curriculum philosophy, the goals and objectives of the subject matter, the individual student learning and developmental needs, as well as the teaching profession.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.iiep.unesco.org/en/our-mission/teacher-management|title=Teacher management|date=2014-11-20|work=IIEP-UNESCO|access-date=2018-11-09|language=en}}</ref> The processes involved in educational management at the educator's level are similar to that of the educational ministry.<ref>{{Cite book|title=What teachers want : better teacher management|last=Ben|first=Jensen|others=Grattan Institute|isbn=9781925015041|location=[Carlton, Victoria]|oclc=861217361|year = 2010}}</ref> However, the planning, managing, developing and monitoring focuses on individual students specifically.<ref name=":12" /> Teachers also adopt classroom management strategies, incorporate instructional approaches that promote independence, discipline, and positive learning mindsets. The teacher's classroom management style influences many aspects of the learning environment. The four styles of classroom management include Authoritarian, Authoritative, Permissive and Disengaged.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Djigic|first=Gordana|last2=Stojiljkovic|first2=Snezana|date=2011|title=Classroom management styles, classroom climate and school achievement|url=https://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S1877042811027716|journal=Procedia - Social and Behavioral Sciences|volume=29|pages=819–828|doi=10.1016/j.sbspro.2011.11.310|issn=1877-0428}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.edglossary.org/classroom-management/|title=Classroom Management Definition|last=Partnership|first=Great Schools|date=2013-05-15|work=The Glossary of Education Reform|access-date=2018-11-09|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|title=Guidance of young children|last=1946-|first=Marion, Marian|isbn=9780133427226|edition= Ninth |location=Boston|oclc=867605709|date = 2014-03-12}}</ref> Furthermore, teachers utilise a variety of positive guidance and discipline strategies to refocus the student's attention or manage conflicts and disagreements.<ref>{{Cite book|title=A Guidance Approach for the Encouraging Classroom|last=Daniel.|first=Gartrell|date=2013|publisher=Wadsworth Cengage Learning|isbn=9781133938934|edition= 6th|location=Belmont, CA|oclc=800031986}}</ref>
== Organisation by Country ==
=== Organisational Structure of Education System By Country ===
==== Australia ==== The structure of [[Education in Australia|Australia's education system]] is [[Organizational structure#Bureaucratic structures|bureaucratic]] in nature. The national and [[States and territories of Australia|state]] departments of education are responsible for the regulation of funding of education.
The education system in Australia is governed by the [[Department of Education and Training (Australia)|Department of Education and Training]] which is responsible for national policies and programs. Each state is responsible for the delivery and coordination of their state run programmes and policies.
===== Organisational Structure of National [[Department of Education and Training (Australia)|Department of Education and Training]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://docs.education.gov.au/system/files/doc/other/org_chart_september_2018_published.pdf|title=Department of Education and Training - Organisation Chart|last=|first=|date=|website=Australian Government Department of Education and Training|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> ===== The department reports to two Ministers, while the secretaries are responsible for the delivery of the department's services. These services include corporate strategy, early childhood and childcare, school and youth, higher education, research and international, and skills and training.
===== Departments of Education by State =====
* [[Department of Education (New South Wales)]] * [[Department of Education (Western Australia)]] * [[Department of Education and Training (Queensland)]] * [[Department for Education (South Australia)]] * [[Department of Education and Training (Victoria)]] * [[Department of Education (Tasmania)]]
==== Finland ==== The structure of [[Education in Finland|Finland's Education System]] is [[Organizational structure#Bureaucratic structures|bureaucratic]] in nature.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.oph.fi/english/education_system|title=Finnish National Agency for Education - Education system|website=www.oph.fi|language=en|access-date=2018-11-09}}</ref>
===== Departments and units of the [[Ministry of Education and Culture (Finland)|Ministry of Education and Culture]] ===== The Ministry of Education and Culture comprises<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.oph.fi/english/about_us/task_services_and_organisation|title=Finnish National Agency for Education - Tasks, services and organisation|website=www.oph.fi|language=en|access-date=2018-11-09}}</ref>
* Department for General Education and Early Childhood Education * Department for Vocational Education and Training * Department for Higher Education and Science Policy * Department for Art and Cultural Policy * Department for Youth and Sport Policy * Unit for Upper Secondary School Reform
====== The Ministry’s common functions are attended to by ======
* Administrative Unit * Finance Unit * Secretariat for International Relations * Communications Unit
==== Singapore ==== The structure of [[Education in Singapore|Singapore's education system]] is [[Organizational structure#Functional structure|functional]] in nature. Education in Singapore is managed by the [[Ministry of Education (Singapore)|Ministry of Education]] (MOE).<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.moe.gov.sg/home|title=Home|website=www.moe.gov.sg|access-date=2018-10-18}}</ref>
The organisation structure consists of:<ref name=":3">{{Cite web|url=https://www.moe.gov.sg/about/org-structure|title=Organisational Structure|website=www.moe.gov.sg|access-date=2018-10-04}}</ref>
* Political Heads * The Academy of Singapore Teachers is intended to build a teacher-led culture of professional excellence centred on the holistic development of the child. The function of the academy is to champion the ethos of the profession, foster a teacher-led culture of collaborative professionalism, build a culture of continuous learning and improvement, and strengthen the enablers of professional development.<ref name=":3" /> * The Communications and Engagement Group is split into two divisions, communications division, and engagement and research division respectively. The communications division proactively manages strategic messaging and promotes effective communication of education policies and programmes to local and international media as well as the general public.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.moe.gov.sg/about/org-structure/ceg|title=Communications and Engagement Group|website=www.moe.gov.sg|access-date=2018-10-18}}</ref> The engagement and research division interacts directly and indirectly with, and engage MOE's key stakeholder groups. It will also build broader MOE capabilities for effective engagement and sense-making which feeds into MOE's policy and implementation process.<ref name=":3" /> * The Curriculum Planning & Development division develops a curriculum with the goal to meet the needs of the nation, community and individual. The responsibilities include syllabus design and review, teaching approaches and assessment modes, programmes, resources, library services, language centres, and consultancy services.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.moe.gov.sg/about/org-structure/cpdd|title=Curriculum Planning & Development|website=www.moe.gov.sg|access-date=2018-10-18}}</ref> * The Curriculum Policy Office functions to develop and review policies involved in the national curriculum. Additionally, the office facilitates sound, balanced, purposeful and effective curriculum, pedagogy, and assessment practices.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.moe.gov.sg/about/org-structure/cpo|title=Curriculum Policy Office|website=www.moe.gov.sg|access-date=2018-10-18}}</ref> * The Educational Technology division provides the strategic direction, leadership, conceptualisation and development of effective integration of ICT in the ICT Masterplan in Education.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.moe.gov.sg/about/org-structure/etd|title=Educational Technology|website=www.moe.gov.sg|access-date=2018-10-18}}</ref> * The Finance & Procurement division is split between the finance department and the procurement department. The finance department manages the ministry's budget and oversees and formulate policies. The procurement department oversees policies and manages contracts and tenders in the procurement process. * The Higher Education Group formulates, implements and reviews policies relating to tertiary institutions such as universities and polytechnics. * The Human Resource Group "oversee recruitment and appointment, management of establishment matters for Education Officers, Executive & Administrative Staff, Allied Educators (EO/EAS/AED), employee engagement and HR partnerships with schools and HQ Divisions".<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.moe.gov.sg/about/org-structure/hr-group|title=Human Resource Group|website=www.moe.gov.sg|access-date=2018-10-18}}</ref> * The Information Technology Branch is the operations department to integrate technology in the different levels of education, including administration and management.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.moe.gov.sg/about/org-structure/itb|title=Information Technology Branch|website=www.moe.gov.sg|access-date=2018-11-06}}</ref> They provide expert advice and support on the distribution of information and communication technologies for the purpose of teaching and learning. Additionally, they serve and provide the MOE HQ with the relevant processes and procedures to implement IT infrastructure strategically and effectively. * The Infrastructure & Facility Services consists of four branches.<ref name=":6">{{Cite web|url=https://www.moe.gov.sg/about/org-structure/ifsd|title=Infrastructure & Facility Services|website=www.moe.gov.sg|access-date=2018-11-06}}</ref> The first branch School Campus Department deals with infrastructure planning through the various building and upgrading programmes.<ref name=":6" /> They are also in charge of monitoring and reviewing the Urban Redevelopment Authority's policies and plans for land use. The second branch consists of the HQ services branch which oversees policies and planning of the physical infrastructure in the MOE's HQ purview.<ref name=":6" /> They also provide administrative policy support for services offered in schools.<ref name=":6" /> The School Campus Department is the third branch that manages the school building and infrastructure work. Furthermore, it reviews and develops policies for existing and new schools. The last branch is the Safety, Security and Emergency Branch oversees the system and emergency operations and procedures of schools and the MOE HQ. They are also responsible for the development and implementation of a 'safety culture' in school programmes.<ref name=":6" /> * The Internal Audit Branch ensures checks and balances in the Singapore education system and ministry. They operate independently to monitor and handle financial and operational audits.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.moe.gov.sg/about/org-structure/iab|title=Internal Audit Branch|website=www.moe.gov.sg|access-date=2018-11-06}}</ref> Special investigations and reviews are a few of the numerous functions the Internal Audit Branch serves. * The Planning department main role is to "manage and analyse key <abbr>MOE</abbr> data to support <abbr>MOE</abbr> management in decision-making".<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.moe.gov.sg/about/org-structure/pld|title=Planning|website=www.moe.gov.sg|access-date=2018-11-06}}</ref> They function through the Education Policy Branch, Corporate Planning Office, and International Cooperation Branch. * The Research & Management Information department conducts research and analyses data that are essential for MOE strategic goals. It consists of the Management Information Branch, Psychological Assessment Research Branch, Research & Evaluation Branch, and Corporate management Branch.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.moe.gov.sg/about/org-structure/research-and-management-information|title=Research & Management Information|website=www.moe.gov.sg|access-date=2018-11-06}}</ref> * The Schools department ensures that there is leadership is of a good standard in schools. It comprises the Schools Division; School Branch North, South, East & West; Pre-school Education Branch; School Appraisal Branch; School Cockpit Administration Centre. Each branch serves a management, administrative support, implementation and consultancy, and an integration role respectively.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.moe.gov.sg/about/org-structure/sd|title=Schools|website=www.moe.gov.sg|access-date=2018-11-06}}</ref> * The Special Educational Needs serve and support students in inclusive environments, as well as special education institutions. They chart the direction for MOE in supporting students with special educational needs.<ref name=":7">{{Cite web|url=https://www.moe.gov.sg/about/org-structure/special-educational-needs|title=Special Educational Needs|website=www.moe.gov.sg|access-date=2018-11-06}}</ref> Also, they develop and review curriculum to enrich the learning experiences for students with special educational needs.<ref name=":7" /> * The Student Placement & Services Division primary role is the management and administration of admission and scholarship matters. They are also responsible for managing the MOE HQ's Customer Service Centre through the strategic implementation of services to "improve the quality of service delivery across all MOE public touch points".<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.moe.gov.sg/about/org-structure/spsd|title=Student Placement & Services Division|website=www.moe.gov.sg|access-date=2018-11-06}}</ref> * The Student Development Curriculum delivers a curriculum that meets the desired goals and vision of Singapore's education system.<ref name=":8">{{Cite web|url=https://www.moe.gov.sg/about/org-structure/sdcd|title=Student Development Curriculum|website=www.moe.gov.sg|access-date=2018-11-06}}</ref> They oversee the formal curriculum and co-curricular programme, collaborate with key stakeholders to review and revise curriculum, ensure successful implementation of national programmes, and enhance student talent and development.<ref name=":8" />
== See also ==
* [[Education]] *[[Educational leadership|Educational Leadership]] * [[Management]]
== References == {{reflist}}
== Further reading == [http://journals.sagepub.com/doi/abs/10.1177/1741143217745880#articleCitationDownloadContainer The Difference Between Educational Management and Educational Leadership and the Importance of Educational Responsibility in Educational Management Administration & Leadership by Michael Connolly, Chris James and Michael Fertig.]
[https://www.researchgate.net/publication/300048835_Theories_of_Educational_Management_and_Leadership_A_Review Theories of Educational Management and Leadership: A Review by Majid Ghasemy and Sufean Hussin.]
[https://learn.org/articles/What_is_Educational_Management.html What is Educational Management? by Learn.org]
[https://www.researchgate.net/publication/283081929_UNIVERSAL_CONCEPTS_NATURE_AND_BASICS_PRINCIPLES_OF_EDUCATIONAL_MANAGEMENT_IMPLICATION_FOR_PRESENT_DAY_SCHOOL_MANAGEMENT Universal Concepts, Nature, and Basic Principles of Educational Management: Implication for Present Day School Management by Nwachukwu Prince Ololube, Erebagha Theophilus, Ingiabuna Ii, and Comfort N. Agbor.]
[[Category:Educational administration]]
{{cat improve|date=November 2018}}
