revision.text:
{{Infobox soap character | series = Home and Away | name = Mason Morgan | image = [[File:Mason_Morgan.jpg|200px]] | portrayer = [[Orpheus Pledger]] | introducer = Lucy Addario | first = 7 June 2016 | years = 2016– | classification = [[List of current Home and Away characters#Present characters|Present; regular]] | alias = Michael Lee (birth name) | occupation = {{plainlist| *Medical student *Waiter *Lifeguard *Gym co-manager }} | home = [[Summer Bay#13 Healey Road|13 Healey Road]] | father = Koby Lee | mother = [[Kate Lee (Home and Away)|Kate Lee]] | sisters = [[Tori Morgan]] | brothers = [[Justin Morgan (Home and Away)|Justin Morgan]]
[[Brody Morgan]] | halfsisters = [[Raffy Morrison]] | nieces = [[Ava Gilbert]] }} '''Mason Morgan''' is a fictional character from the Australian soap opera ''[[Home and Away]]'', played by [[Orpheus Pledger]]. The actor relocated to Sydney from Melbourne upon being offered the role. He began filming his first scenes in early December 2015. Pledger made his first appearance as Mason during the episode broadcast on 7 June 2016. Mason was introduced to the show along with his three older siblings; [[Tori Morgan]] ([[Penny McNamee]]), [[Justin Morgan (Home and Away)|Justin Morgan]] ([[James Stewart (Australian actor)|James Stewart]]) and [[Brody Morgan]] ([[Jackson Heywood]]). Mason is portrayed as being a positive, family orientated "free spirit". He is studying to be a doctor like his sister, who he shares a close bond with. For the first few weeks after their arrival, Mason and his siblings concealed the fact that they were in [[witness protection]]. Mason was the first member of the family to reveal the secret, which resulted in them being held hostage. Subsequent storylines for Mason have revolved around his romantic relationships with [[Evelyn MacGuire]] (Phillipa Northeast), [[Olivia Fraser Richards]] ([[Raechelle Banno]]), and [[Beth Ellis (Home and Away)|Beth Ellis]] (Anneliese Apps), with the latter helping to bring awareness to [[organ donation in Australia]]. The character has also been used to show the effects of temporary [[paralysis]], after he is injured in a car crash with his brother Brody. ==Casting== On 5 December 2015, Jonathon Moran from ''[[The Daily Telegraph (Sydney)|The Daily Telegraph]]'' reported actors [[Orpheus Pledger]], [[Jackson Heywood]] and [[James Stewart (Australian actor)|James Stewart]] had joined the cast of ''Home and Away'' as brothers Mason, Brody and Justin Morgan respectively.{{cite news|url=http://www.dailytelegraph.com.au/entertainment/sydney-confidential/jessica-marais-and-ex-james-stewart-go-head-to-head-on-rival-networks/story-fni0cvc9-1227635050696|title=Jessica Marais and ex James Stewart go head-to-head on rival networks|last=Moran|first=Jonathon|date=5 December 2015|work=[[The Daily Telegraph (Sydney)|The Daily Telegraph]]|accessdate=2 April 2018}} The family drew immediate comparisons to the show's Braxton brothers, who were introduced to the show in 2011. All three actors began filming their first scenes during the following week, ahead of their on-screen debut in 2016. Pledger was living with his mother and brother in Melbourne when he was offered the role of Mason, which required him to move to Sydney, where the show's studios are located.{{cite news|url=https://www.stuff.co.nz/entertainment/tv-radio/94881321/home-and-aways-orpheus-pledges-big-things-to-come-for-good-boy-mason|title=Home And Away's Orpheus pledges big things to come for good boy Mason|last=Harvey|first=Kerry|date=24 July 2017|publisher=[[Stuff.co.nz]]|accessdate=4 April 2018}} Pledger said his 2011 role as [[Noah Parkin]] on fellow Australian soap opera ''[[Neighbours]]'' helped him prepare for the workload and the pace of filming. Pledger made his first appearance on 7 June 2016, alongside Heywood and Stewart.{{cite web|url=http://www.tvtonight.com.au/2016/05/james-stewart-heads-up-new-home-away-family.html|title=James Stewart heads up new Home & Away family|last=Knox|first=David|date=12 May 2016|publisher=[[TV Tonight]]|accessdate=2 April 2018}} ==Development== ===Characterisation and introduction=== Ahead of his screen debut, Pledger described Mason as having a "positive outlook on life", being family orientated, and "a hopeless romantic". He also said Mason "leads with his gut and stands up for what he believes in and will always stick up for the little guy." Pledger later called his character "a free spirit" and a positive person to be around.{{cite journal|last=Cromarty|first=Ali|last2=Downie|first2=Stephen|date=4–10 June 2016|title=Meet the Morgans|journal=[[TV Week]]|issue=23|page=12}} The actor explained that following the death of their parents, Mason's siblings helped him to grow up and unlike them, Mason has not had to take on many responsibilities. Of the comparisons to the Braxton brothers, Heywood said the Morgans had a different dynamic, while Pledger added that family comes first for the Morgans.{{cite journal|last=Ellis|first=Sarah|date=23–29 July 2016|title=Meet the Morgans!|journal=[[Inside Soap]]|issue=29|page=23}} Mason is a medical student, who struggles to fit in a social life in between studying and working out in the gym. Pledger called Tori a good role model for Mason and as a result, they share a very close relationship. Pledger shares some similarities with Mason, particularly his dedication to attaining his dream job. The actor explained, "I've done that in my life with acting. Maybe it's not the same formality as studying to be a doctor and having to do a seven-year introduction to it before you even start but, definitely, if I was passionate about it, I would definitely do it." The character's appearance changed in 2017 when Pledger shaved his "trademark" curly hair in favour of a shorter haircut.{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.com/soaps/home-and-away/news/a816366/home-and-away-mason-morgan-looks-different-after-losing-curls-haircut/|title=Home and Away's Mason Morgan is looking very different after losing his curls|last=Dainty|first=Sophie|date=8 December 2016|work=[[Digital Spy]]|accessdate=2 April 2018}} Pledger later said that he thought a shorter haircut was best for his character at that point, but that he was beginning to grow it longer for Mason again.{{cite journal|date=19–25 May 2018|title=You ask... they answer! Orpheus Pledger faces your questions!|journal=[[Inside Soap]]|issue=20|pages=52–53}} Mason, Justin and Brody, along with their dog [[Buddy (Home and Away)|Buddy]], are almost involved in a car crash with [[Martin Ashford (Home and Away)|Martin "Ash" Ashford]] ([[George Mason (actor)|George Mason]]) while they are driving to [[Summer Bay]] to join their sister, Tori.{{cite journal|last=Downie|first=Stephen|date=4–10 June 2016|title=Face off!|journal=[[TV Week]]|issue=23|page=8}} Ash swerves across the road in front of them while texting. After coming to a stop, Justin immediately gets out of the car to confront Ash, and Brody and Mason desperately try to keep them from getting into a physical fight. The Morgans continue their journey to the Bay, where they find Ash talking with Tori and [[Alf Stewart]] ([[Ray Meagher]]) on the beach and another fight almost breaks out, until Tori reveals that Justin, Brody and Mason are her brothers. Ash accepts that he was in the wrong, while Justin is glad his family have made it to the Bay safely. The siblings also wonder if they will be able to stay in their new home, leading to the start of their first major storyline. ===Witness protection=== An ''[[Inside Soap]]'' columnist observed that the Morgans had been hiding something about their past from the Bay's residents.{{cite journal|date=13–19 August 2016|title=The Morgans' history revealed!|journal=[[Inside Soap]]|issue=32|page=28}} They initially keep to themselves and Justin warns Tori against befriending local doctor [[Nate Cooper]] ([[Kyle Pryor]]). Stewart explained that there were a set of rules that the Morgans had to live by, which related to their secret.{{cite journal|last=Downie|first=Stephen|date=25 June – 1 July 2016|title=The secret is out!|journal=[[TV Week]]|issue=26|page=10}} While studying at home one day, Mason is visited by his former girlfriend [[Lara Adams]] (Elle Harris). Lara tells Mason off for not staying in contact with her. Justin arrives home shortly after and finds Lara and Mason together.{{cite journal|last=Downie|first=Stephen|date=11–17 June 2016|title=Blast from the past|journal=[[TV Week]]|issue=24|page=11}} He orders Lara to leave, while warning Mason that he has compromised the family. Stewart confirmed that Justin's reaction had something to do with the family's secret. Lara comes to the hospital to see Mason, who asks her to leave in case she is seen. Later, while he is looking for Lara, Mason comes across an upset [[Evelyn MacGuire]] (Philippa Northeast) and he comforts her. Lara sees them together and assumes Mason is also dating Evie. In an effort to reconnect with Lara, Mason tells her that his family are in [[witness protection]]. Later that day, Brody mentions that he is being followed, so Mason admits that he told Lara about their secret. Justin decides that they need to pack up and leave. After Tori is threatened by [[Spike Lowe]] (Jason Montgomery), the family's police liaison officer [[Atticus Decker]] ([[John Adam (actor)|John Adam]]) has them moved to a [[safe house]]. As they wait to find out where they will be moved to next, the family agree that they are tired of running from the people who killed their parents.{{cite journal|date=27 August – 2 September 2016|title=Witless protection|journal=[[Inside Soap]]|issue=34|page=32}} When his siblings begin arguing, Mason slips outside to meet up with Lara. However, he soon learns that she is working for Spike and [[Blaine Varden]] (Ashley Lyons), the man who killed the Morgan's parents. Spike and Blaine trick Mason into telling them where the safe house is and they hold the family hostage. Blaine produces a gun and threatens to kill them all, before revealing that Justin knew the truth about the circumstances that led to their parents' deaths. Mason is one of nine characters involved in a plane crash, after Spike sabotages a plane being used for Tori's birthday trip. Justin attempts to warn the pilot, [[Duncan Stewart (Home and Away)|Duncan Stewart]] ([[Benedict Wall]]), but a broken pipe leaks carbon dioxide into the cabin and everyone passes out. However, Duncan does manage to crash land the plane in the sand first.{{cite journal|last=Cromarty|first=Ali|date=20–26 August 2016|title=Plane crash horror|journal=[[TV Week]]|issue=34|pages=8–9}} While most of the passengers escape major injury, Mason is "panic-stricken" when he realises that Brody is missing.{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.com/soaps/home-and-away/news/a808065/soap-spoilers-home-and-aways-explosive-plane-crash-leaves-brody-morgan-feared-dead/|title=Soap spoilers: Home and Away's Brody Morgan is feared dead after explosive plane crash|last=Dainty|first=Sophie|date=17 September 2016|work=[[Digital Spy]]|accessdate=3 April 2018}} Later developments in the storyline saw the Morgans meet Decker's nieces [[Hope Morrison|Hope]] ([[Jessica Falkholt]]) and [[Raffy Morrison]] (Olivia Deeble). They soon realise that Raffy could be their half-sister, after Decker admits to having an affair with their mother.{{cite journal|date=26 November – 2 December 2016|title=No Hope!|journal=[[Inside Soap]]|issue=47|page=31}} A DNA test confirms their suspicions, but before they tell Raffy, Hope steals Mason's car and attempts to leave town with her. The Morgans eventually tell Raffy she is their half-sister and that they had to go into witness protection because their parents were killed by drug dealers.{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.com/soaps/home-and-away/news/a819951/soap-spoilers-home-and-away-morgan-secret-threat-tori-nate-romance/|title=Soap spoilers: Home and Away's Morgan family secret comes under threat, while Tori goes for it with Nate|last=Kilkelly|first=Daniel|date=28 January 2017|work=[[Digital Spy]]|accessdate=6 April 2018}} The Morgan's secret is soon revealed to the rest of the Bay in the local newspaper.{{cite journal|last=Downie|first=Stephen|date=10–16 December 2016|title=On with the showdown!|journal=[[TV Week]]|issue=50|pages=15–16}} ===Relationships=== ====Evelyn MacGuire==== Mason shares a drunken kiss with Evie after a night out. The following week, they have dinner together and Mason confronts Evie about her drinking and partying. However, instead of talking to him about her issues, Evie just kisses Mason again and they have sex.{{cite journal|last=Cromarty|first=Ali|date=30 July – 5 August 2016|title=Girl just wants to have fun|journal=[[TV Week]]|issue=31|page=23}} They agree to a [[Casual sex|friends with benefits]] arrangement.{{cite journal|last=Barrett|first=Kerry|date=22 October – 4 November 2016|title=Booty call!|journal=[[All About Soap]]|issue=386|page=30}} Mason becomes concerned when Evie insists that she survived the plane crash because her deceased brother [[Oscar MacGuire]] (Jake Speer) is watching over her.{{cite journal|date=8–14 October 2016|title=Evie lost at sea!|journal=[[Inside Soap]]|issue=40|page=28}} Determined to prove her theory, Evie takes Mason out in her car and begins driving recklessly, as she is convinced that she will not crash. Mason is "petrified" by her stunt and when they stop, he "lets rip at her". Mason eventually develops feelings for Evie, but she reacts angrily to his admission and tells him she is not interested in a relationship with him. A reporter for ''The Daily Telegraph'' noted the arrangement would not last long, after Northeast was photographed filming a kissing scene with Alec Snow, who plays [[Matt Page]].{{cite news|url=https://www.dailytelegraph.com.au/entertainment/sydney-confidential/home-and-away-interesting-storylines-ahead-for-evie-matt-and-leah-as-things-get-heated-on-set/news-story/3f97ee9832e0b056c3a624749c414509?nk=cfb429b18655ca0e93ccfee99540e4e4-1522766860|title=Home and Away: Interesting storylines ahead for Evie, Matt and Leah as things get heated on set|date=8 September 2016|work=[[The Daily Telegraph (Sydney)|The Daily Telegraph]]|accessdate=3 April 2018}} ====Olivia Fraser Richards==== [[File:Raechelle Banno 2.jpg|thumb|155px|right|Mason is involved in a love triangle when he dates Olivia Fraser Richards, played by Raechelle Banno (''pictured'').]] Producers later paired Mason with [[Olivia Fraser Richards]] ([[Raechelle Banno]]) and formed a love triangle storyline with her ex-boyfriend [[Hunter King (Home and Away)|Hunter King]] (Scott Lee).{{cite journal|last=Downie|first=Stephen|date=10–16 December 2016|title=Olivia's romance dilemma|journal=[[TV Week]]|issue=50|pages=15–16}} Mason shows an interest in dating Olivia and she is "drawn to him". Pledger told Alison Gardner of ''[[What's on TV]]'' that Mason "really likes" Olivia and readily accepts her invitation to accompany her to the [[Prom#Oceania|formal]].{{cite web|url=http://www.whatsontv.co.uk/home-away/home-away-news/mason-girl-home-away-453239/|title=Mason gets his girl in Home and Away. Or does he? Orpheus Pledger reveals all|last=Gardner|first=Alison|date=6 March 2017|work=[[What's on TV]]|accessdate=3 April 2018}} The pair soon learn that Hunter is also attending, and Mason realises that Olivia still has feelings for him. Olivia leaves Mason at the bar and begins dancing with Hunter, but she explains that she was just passing the time while she waited for Mason to return. Pledger continued, "As the evening goes on, it's clear Olivia's still into Hunter. Mason's had so much to deal with because of his family's problems that he doesn't need Olivia to bring him even more heartache." The following morning, Olivia visits Mason at the lifeguard station, where he is starting his new job, to tell him that what happened with Hunter meant nothing, but Mason replies that he does not need any more stress in his life. Later that day, Mason gets into a fight with Hunter. Pledger said that Mason "acts completely out of character" when he hits Hunter and is left feeling ashamed after Alf breaks up the fight. Olivia asks Mason if they can start their relationship over, but Mason rejects the idea. However, when they attend the Summer Grooves music festival, Mason and Olivia kiss. Olivia later admits to Mason that she is worried about Hunter's decision not to return to school and he attempts to talk to Hunter, as he is annoyed that she is worrying about him all the time. They pair have to separated by Alf again, and Lee commented that while Hunter does not have a friendship with Mason, he wants to get better at dealing with things. Mason and Olivia are soon caught having sex at the Summer Bay Auto garage by Brody and [[Irene Roberts]] ([[Lynne McGranger]]).{{cite journal|last=Downie|first=Stephen|date=4–10 February 2017|title=Man under fire|journal=[[TV Week]]|issue=5|pages=14–15}} When Mason comes to The Diner to help Olivia out, he notices she is acting strangely. He soon learns from Alf that Hunter helped Olivia at The Diner the night before, leaving Olivia feeling guilty she did not tell Mason herself. Mason then confronts Hunter and asks him if he wants to get back together with Olivia, but Hunter says no.{{cite journal|last=Cullen|first=Tamara|last2=Downie|first2=Stephen|date=18–24 February 2017|title=Close encounters|journal=[[TV Week]]|issue=7|page=9}} Mason and Olivia's relationship becomes strained as he worries that she still has feelings for Hunter,{{cite journal|last=Cullen|first=Tamara|last2=Downie|first2=Stephen|date=4–10 March 2017|title=Three's a crowd|journal=[[TV Week]]|issue=9|page=7}} and when she admits that he is right, but wants to still date him, Mason breaks up with her.{{cite web|url=https://au.tv.yahoo.com/shows/home-and-away/watch/34490222/mason-olivia-breakup-hunter-home-and-away/|title=Breaking up|publisher=[[Yahoo7]]|accessdate=5 April 2018}} ====Beth Ellis==== A new love interest for Mason was introduced in the form of guest character [[Beth Ellis (Home and Away)|Beth Ellis]] (Anneliese Apps) in August 2017.{{cite news|url=http://metro.co.uk/2017/06/27/home-and-away-spoilers-all-the-rumoured-new-arrivals-at-the-bay-this-summer-6737439/|title=Home and Away spoilers: All the rumoured new arrivals at the Bay this summer|last=Groome|first=Imogen|date=27 June 2017|work=[[Metro (British newspaper)|Metro]]|accessdate=6 April 2017}} Beth tells Mason that she is a nurse and they soon bond while he is a patient in the hospital. Beth's friendship helps Mason's recovery from injuries he sustained in a car crash.{{cite journal|date=30 September – 6 October 2017|title=Dying to know you|journal=[[Inside Soap]]|issue=39|page=26}} While looking for Beth, Mason soon learns that she is actually a patient. Mason is "furious" that Beth has lied to him, but she soon reveals that she is dying. Beth explains that she needs a heart transplant, after being diagnosed with a serious heart condition five years prior. Mason urges Beth not to give up hope that she will get the transplant and they share "a heartfelt moment", which led a ''[[New Idea (magazine)|New Idea]]'' columnist to speculate that they could be more than just friends.{{cite web|url=https://www.newidea.com.au/home-and-away-mason-and-beth-storyline|title=Home and Away heartache: I'm dying|last=Black|first=Nikki|date=11 September 2017|work=[[New Idea (magazine)|New Idea]]|accessdate=7 April 2018}} Mason later asks Beth out on a date and she accepts. Of their romance, Pledger told Tamara Cullen of ''[[TV Week]]'', "Beth brings out the best in Mason. He's playful and has no inhibitions with her."{{cite journal|last=Cullen|first=Tamara|date=23–29 September 2017|title=Taking chances|journal=[[TV Week]]|issue=38|pages=12–13}} When Mason finds Beth's [[wikt:bucket list|bucket list]], she tells him that she accepts that she is not getting any better and is starting to reconsider her treatment. When Mason tries to reassure her that she will be fine, Beth gets angry and Mason is forced to apologise. He then surprises her with a champagne lunch, where they bond further and kiss. Pledger commented, "Mason has never had a connection with anyone else like this." Mason finds Beth's bucket list and sees that she has fun and "romantically charged" things on it, which Mason wants to help her complete. Mason comes up with the idea of a [[James Bond]] style trip to the casino.{{cite journal|date=14–20 October 2017|title=Take a chance on love|journal=[[Inside Soap]]|issue=41|page=32}} During the journey, Beth passes out while she driving. Mason is "petrified" and worried about the harm to Beth's health. He is also left feeling helpless as he cannot do anything about her condition. Mason asks to meets Beth's parents, but she is reluctant. However, Mason later meets Beth and her father [[List of Home and Away characters (2017)#Alan Ellis|Alan Ellis]] ([[Blair McDonough]]) at the beach, so he introduces himself. Alan is unaware that his daughter is dating anyone, but he invites Mason to lunch with Beth and her mother [[List of Home and Away characters (2017)#Jackie Ellis|Jackie]] ([[Rachael Coopes]]), where Mason tries to make a good impression.{{cite journal|date=21–27 October 2017|title=Mason on the spot!|journal=[[Inside Soap]]|issue=42|page=28}} Both Apps and Pledger hoped Beth and Mason's storyline would raise more awareness about organ donation in Australia.{{cite web|url=https://www.newidea.com.au/home-and-aways-anneliese-apps-orpheus-pledger-raise-awareness-organ-donation|title=Home And Away: Young stars' desperate plea|date=22 October 2017|work=[[New Idea (magazine)|New Idea]]|accessdate=6 April 2018}} Pledger also thought the plot could increase the amount of people willing to be organ donors. Both actors found the storyline tough to film, with Pledger calling it "a harrowing experience". The storyline concludes with Beth's death. Mason wants to make the most of the time they have left and organises a lunch on the beach. But Beth collapses and Mason rushes her to the hospital, where she tells him she loves him. Beth goes into cardiac arrest and dies.{{cite journal|date=11–17 October 2017|title=Torn apart!|journal=[[Inside Soap]]|issue=45|page=31}} ===Paralysis=== Mason becomes a victim of his brother Brody's drug addiction when they are in a car crash together, which leaves him with temporary paralysis. The storyline begins when Mason finds Brody searching through the bin for drugs, as he is suffering a relapse. Mason knows that Brody needs help, so he manages to get Brody into his car to drive him to rehab.{{cite journal|date=26 August – 1 September 2017|title=Car crash carnage!|journal=[[Inside Soap]]|issue=34|page=28}} During the journey, Brody is convinced that his dealer [[William Zannis]] (Caleb Alloway) is following them. He suddenly grabs the wheel, causing the car to leave the road and crash. Brody suffers minor injuries, but Mason's condition deteriorates and he is placed in a coma after he loses the feeling in his hand.{{cite news|url=http://metro.co.uk/2017/08/30/home-and-away-spoilers-mason-left-permanently-disabled-after-car-crash-6891176/|title=Home and Away spoilers: Mason left permanently disabled after car crash?|last=Groome|first=Imogen|date=30 August 2017|work=[[Metro (British newspaper)|Metro]]|accessdate=6 April 2018}} Tori is forced to tell Brody, Justin and Raffy that Mason may never walk again, as he has severe spinal damage. The diagnosis prompts Brody to sell his restaurant and leave town for a private rehab.{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.com/soaps/home-and-away/news/a834425/home-and-away-mason-morgan-suffers-life-changing-injuries-car-crash/|title=Home and Away heartbreak as Mason Morgan suffers life-changing injuries after horror car crash|last=Dainty|first=Sophie|date=31 July 2017|work=[[Digital Spy]]|accessdate=6 April 2018}} Weeks later, Tori prepares to take Mason off the ventilator and wake him up, so she can assess how much damage there is to his spinal cord. But Mason fails to wake up and a neurosurgeon informs Tori that they will need to wait until the [[spinal shock]] has worn off. Days later, Mason finally wakes and is able to tell Tori that he cannot feel his legs. As he fears that he may never be able to walk again, Mason undergoes a series of tests and is told that once the swelling goes down, he may regain some feeling back. After Mason is discharged from the hospital, Brody attempts to apologise for causing the accident. Mason "erupts with fury" and attempts to strangle his brother.{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.com/soaps/home-and-away/news/a839347/home-and-away-spoilers-brody-morgan-ziggy-romance-exposed/|title=Soap spoilers: Home and Away's Brody Morgan has his forbidden romance exposed... and faces family drama too|last=Kilkelly|first=Daniel|date=30 September 2017|work=[[Digital Spy]]|accessdate=6 April 2018}} Justin and Tori try to get the brothers to reconcile, but they struggle to get through to "an increasingly-bitter" Mason. Justin later takes Mason to see their parents' graves to remind him that the family needs to stay together. Mason then accepts Brody's handshake, ending their feud. Pledger later posted a photo of himself walking around the outdoor set on his social media, confirming that Mason would recover from his paralysis.{{cite web|url=http://www.nowtolove.com.au/celebrity/tv/home-and-away-orpheus-pledger-heartache-40582|title=Home And Away star Orpheus Pledger's secret heartache|date=1 September 2017|work=[[TV Week]]|accessdate=6 April 2018}} ==Storylines== Mason, Brody and Justin Morgan join their sister Tori in Summer Bay. Mason and Brody have to stop Justin from fighting Martin "Ash" Ashford, who almost ran them off the road. Days after their arrival, Mason's former girlfriend Lara Adams visits him and they have sex. Justin catches them together and warns Lara to stay away. Mason confronts Justin, forcing Brody to stop them from fighting. Mason starts working at Brody's restaurant as a waiter, while he is also given a placement at the local hospital, where he clashes with his supervisor Nate Cooper. Lara sees Mason comforting Evie MacGuire and when she threatens to break up with him, Mason tells Lara that his family is in witness protection, as their parents were murdered by a drug syndicate. After their cover is exposed, the Morgans leave the Bay for a safe house. Mason slips outside to see Lara, but he is kidnapped by Spike Lowe and Blaine Varden, who Lara has been working for. Blaine threatens to kill the Morgans, before revealing that Justin knew that their father was working for the syndicate and that their mother sacrificed herself to save him. Lara frees Mason and the family are saved by the police and their federal protection officer, Decker. Mason and Tori ask Justin to leave the house, after learning that he lied to them. Mason helps Evie out with a charity sleepover at Summer Bay High. They kiss, but she pulls away and he apologises. When Evie gets drunk at a university party, Mason brings her home and lets her stay on his sofa. While they are studying together, Mason and Evie have sex. They both admit that they are not over their former partners and agree to a friends with benefits arrangement. During a plane trip for Tori's birthday, a carbon monoxide leak causes the passengers and captain to pass out. The plane crashes into the desert and Mason has to treat a pregnant [[Billie Ashford]] ([[Tessa de Josselin]]), whose amniotic sac is damaged. Mason burns his arm when he pushes Evie out of the way of a fuel explosion. Evie insists that she was saved by her deceased brother and tries to prove that he is protecting her by driving dangerously with Mason in the car. Mason is forced to apply the handbrake to stop them from crashing. Mason realises he has feelings for Evie and wants more than a casual relationship with her. He eventually ends their arrangement. The Morgans learn Decker's niece Raffy Morrison is actually his daughter and their half-sister. Mason is in favour of telling Raffy the truth and attempts to make her feel like part of the family. After noticing Olivia Fraser Richards arguing with her former boyfriend Hunter King, Mason asks her to go for a walk with him. He asks her out on a date, but she turns him down as she is not ready for a new relationship. Olivia invites Mason to escort her to her formal as friends, where she spends most of the night talking and dancing with Hunter. Mason begins working as a lifeguard and gets into a fight with Hunter on his first day. Mason helps Brody out at the Summer Grooves music festival, and he and Olivia kiss, before leaving to go skinny dipping. Mason and Olivia start dating, but he worries that she still has feelings for Hunter. The couple are later caught having sex at Summer Bay Auto. Olivia eventually admits to Mason that she does still have feelings for Hunter, but she wants to carry on dating him; however, Mason breaks up with her. Olivia later sets Mason up with her friend [[Lena Ascot]] (Felicity McKay), but nothing comes of it after he finds her dealing drugs at a party. Brody later develops a drug addiction and Mason has to take him to the hospital when he is beaten by his dealer. Mason is forced to work with Hunter at the surf club, where they clash again. Mason refuses to fight Hunter when he challenges him and they eventually become friends. Mason realises Brody is suffering a relapse and drives him to rehab. Brody panics when he sees his dealer following them and grabs the wheel, causing the car to crash. Mason suffers spinal damage and is placed on life support. When he wakes, he realises that he has little feeling in his legs. Beth Ellis visits Mason and cheers him up. She tells him she is a nurse, but Mason soon learns she is a patient, who has [[cardiomyopathy]] and needs a heart transplant. Mason helps Beth to complete some things on her bucket list and they kiss. While driving to a casino, Beth collapses and Mason is forced to drive to get help. He later meets Beth's parents and her father Alan asks him to stay away from her, but he changes his mind. Mason and Beth have sex, but Beth collapses at the pier later that night. Mason tries to get her moved up the transplant list and pressures a car crash victim's husband into donating her heart. A complaint is made against him and his placement at the hospital is cancelled. Mason takes Beth out for lunch on the beach where he gives her an eternity ring. However, Beth becomes breathless and Mason rushes her back to the hospital. She goes into cardiac arrest and dies. Mason later sees visions of Beth and attempts to complete the rest of her bucket list. After quitting his university course in the wake of Beth's death, Mason applies for the manager's job at the gym. [[Willow Harris]] ([[Sarah Roberts (actress)|Sarah Roberts]]) also applies and [[John Palmer (Home and Away)|John Palmer]]'s ([[Shane Withington]]) gives it to them both. Mason gives [[Jennifer Dutton]] (Brittany Santariga) a private boxing lesson and she kisses him, but he pulls away and she makes it seem that he had made an unwelcome advance towards her as Hunter walks in. She apologises after Mason tells her about Beth. Mason befriends [[Jasmine Delaney]] ([[Sam Frost (TV personality)|Sam Frost]]) and they bond over their respective medical careers. Mason decides to return to university and he is allowed to continue his placement at Northern Districts hospital. ==Reception== Jonathon Moran of ''The Daily Telegraph'' predicted that Pledger "will no doubt be a hit with the young female fans with his buff body." Sarah Ellis from ''Inside Soap'' branded Mason, Brody and Justin "another trio of troublesome brothers". She also noted their appearances, dubbing them "a tasty trio" and "hunky". Ali Cromarty and Stephen Downie of ''TV Week'' were impressed by the brothers, commenting, "Move over Braxtons, there's a new family of hot brothers in Summer Bay." They also called them "loyal, caring and hard-working". Downie later called the siblings "the mysterious Morgan brothers" and pointed out that they landed in "a whole lot of trouble" upon their arrival. Daniel Kilkelly from ''Digital Spy'' dubbed the Morgans "Summer Bay's unluckiest family".{{cite web|url=http://www.digitalspy.com/soaps/home-and-away/news/a811016/soap-spoilers-home-and-away-justin-morgan-showdown-chris-harrington-exit/|title=Soap spoilers: Home and Away's Justin Morgan faces a violent showdown, and there's big news from Chris|last=Kilkelly|first=Daniel|date=15 October 2016|work=[[Digital Spy]]|accessdate=2 April 2018}} Writing for Stuff.co.nz, Kerry Harvey dubbed Mason "Summer Bay's good boy" and observed that he was "chilled-out". She also named him "the most sensible member of the Morgan clan". ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[https://au.tv.yahoo.com/shows/home-and-away/a/33380807/mason-morgan/ Mason Morgan] at the Official ''Home and Away'' website *[https://www.tvnz.co.nz/shows/home-and-away/characters/mason-morgan Mason Morgan] at [[TVNZ]] {{Home and Away characters|present}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Morgan, Mason}} [[Category:Home and Away characters]] [[Category:Fictional characters introduced in 2016]] [[Category:Fictional orphans]] [[Category:Fictional victims of kidnapping]] [[Category:Fictional medical students]] [[Category:Fictional waiting staff]] [[Category:Fictional lifeguards]] [[Category:Fictional personal trainers]]

[[Wellington Region|WELLINGTON]] 6140 |employees = |budget = Total budgets for 2017/18{{cite web| url=http://www.treasury.govt.nz/budget/2017/summarytables/estimates/09.htm| title=Total Appropriations for Each Vote| work=2017 Budget| publisher=The Treasury| access-date=4 November 2017| archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171107031109/http://www.treasury.govt.nz/budget/2017/summarytables/estimates/09.htm| archive-date=7 November 2017| dead-url=yes| df=dmy-all}}
''Vote Education''
{{increase}}$11,612,418,000
''Vote Tertiary Education''
{{increase}}$3,018,643,000 |minister1_name = [[Chris Hipkins|Hon Chris Hipkins]] |minister1_pfo =
[[Minister of Education (New Zealand)|Minister of Education]] |minister3_name = |minister3_pfo = |chief1_name = Iona Holsted |chief1_position =
Chief Executive and Secretary for Education |chief2_name = |chief2_position = |parent_agency = |child1_agency = [[New Zealand Qualifications Authority]] |website = {{URL|http://www.education.govt.nz}} |footnotes = }} The '''Ministry of Education''' ([[Māori language|Māori]]: ''Te Tāhuhu o te Mātauranga'') is the public service department of New Zealand charged with overseeing the [[Education in New Zealand|New Zealand education system]]. The Ministry was formed in 1989 when the former, all-encompassing Department of Education was broken up into six separate agencies. == History == {{See also|History of education in New Zealand}} The Ministry was established as a result of the [[Picot task force]] set up by the Labour government in July 1987 to review the New Zealand education system. The members were Brian Picot, a businessman, Peter Ramsay, an associate professor of education at the [[University of Waikato]], Margaret Rosemergy, a senior lecturer at the Wellington College of Education, [[Whetumarama Wereta]], a social researcher at the [[Department of Maori Affairs]] and Colin Wise, another businessman.{{sfn|Fiske|Ladd|2000|pp=48}} The task force was assisted by staff from the Treasury and the State Services Commission (SSC), who may have applied pressure on the task force to move towards eventually privatizing education, as had happened with other government services.{{cite web |url=http://www.victoria.ac.nz/nzaroe/1992/pdf/text-dale.pdf |title=Mainstreaming Education: The Role of the State Services Commission |author=Roger Dale and Joce Jesson |work=''New Zealand Annual Review of Education'', 7, 7-34 |year=1993 |accessdate=2010-12-13 }}{{dead link|date=February 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} The mandate was to review management structures and cost-effectiveness, but did not include curriculum, teaching or effectiveness. In nine months the commission received input from over 700 people or organizations.{{sfn|Levin|2001|pp=44}} The Picot task force released its report ''Administering for Excellence: Effective Administration in Education'' in May 1988. The report was critical of the [[Department of Education (New Zealand)|Department of Education]], which it labelled as inefficient and unresponsive. The task force conceived of the school charter as a contract between school boards, the local community and central authority and the government accepted many of the recommendations subsequently published in their response - ''[[Tomorrow's Schools]]''. This recommended a system where each school would be largely independent, governed by a board consisting mainly of parents, although subject to review and inspection by specialized government agencies. Another recommendation was that boards of trustees were made responsible to the Minister of Education, who gained the power to dismiss boards. The Picot report became the basis for a drawn out process of educational reform in New Zealand starting in 1989.{{sfn|Levin|2001|pp=45}} When National was elected in October 1990, it carried out a further series of educational reviews culminating in the publication ''Education Policy: Investing in People, Our Greatest Asset''. This resulted in further modifications to the structure of education reform, and according to one academic, created "a system which is a far cry from the Picot intentions... There has been an ongoing series of changes and reassessments that has caused chaos, confusion and massive insecurity throughout the education sector".[http://www.victoria.ac.nz/education/research/nzaroe/issues-index/1992/abstract-sullivan The Myth of Partnership: Educational Reform and Teacher Disempowerment] In March 2013, Patrick Walsh, the outgoing president of the Secondary Principals' Association said that despite having about 3000 employees, the Ministry had underperformed for more than a decade. He said "in an era of self-managing schools we have a Ministry that is so large and yet not able to perform in an effective and efficient manner". Walsh said the Ministry's poor performance has been confirmed by a number of reviews conducted by the State Services Commission.[http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=10872838 Education ministry 'ineffective'] ==Responsibilities== The Ministry's role is to raise the overall level of educational achievement and reduce disparity. It is not an education provider. That role is met by individual elected Boards of Trustees for every [[state school]] in the country. The ministry has numerous functions - advising government, providing information to the sector, providing learning resources, administering sector regulation and funding, and providing specialist services. The ministry works with other education agencies including the [[Education Review Office]], the [[New Zealand Qualifications Authority]] and [[Learning Media Limited]]. Although the Ministry's role is to raise the level of educational achievement, it is also the mechanism through which the Government of the day implements its education policy. When government changes aspects of its policy on education, the Ministry is responsible for implementing those changes. Sometimes the Ministry ends up in the difficult position of trying to implement political induced changes in education policy to which teachers, parents and boards of trustees may be totally opposed. Changes introduced by the [[Fifth National Government of New Zealand|National Government]] in 2011–2012 are an example. In order for the Ministry to perform its role effectively, it is dependent on taxpayer funding provided by Government. When government increases funding or requires financial cutbacks, this also impacts on the ability of the Ministry to fulfil its role. In 2013, the Government provided about $12.2 billion to fund education in New Zealand.[http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=10863686 Teachers want Government to 'come clean'] == Ministers == The Ministry serves 1 portfolio, 1 minister and 3 associate ministers. {| class="wikitable" |- ! OFFICEHOLDER !! PORTFOLIO(S) !! OTHER RESPONSIBILITY(IES) |- | [[Chris Hipkins|Hon Chris Hipkins]] || Lead Minister (Ministry of Education)
[[Minister of Education (New Zealand)|Minister of Education]] || |- | [[Kelvin Davis (politician)|Hon Kelvin Davis]] || || Associate Minister of Education (Māori Education) |- | [[Jenny Salesa|Hon Jenny Salesa]] || || Associate Minister of Education |- | [[Tracey Martin|Hon Tracey Martin]] || || Associate Minister of Education |} == See also == * [[Education in New Zealand]] * [[History of education in New Zealand]] == References == {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== *{{official website|http://www.education.govt.nz/}} *[https://web.archive.org/web/20071221030845/http://www.teachnz.govt.nz/default.aspx TeachNZ, a business unit of MoE] *[http://www.tki.org.nz/ Te Kete Ipurangi - The Online Learning Centre, an initiative of MoE] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20071203142256/http://www.edgazette.govt.nz/ The Education Gazette, published by MoE] {{coord|-41.275615|174.778782|display=title|region:NZ_type:landmark}} {{NZ Public Service Departments}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Ministry Of Education (New Zealand)}} [[Category:New Zealand Public Service departments|Education]] [[Category:Education in New Zealand]] [[Category:Education ministries|New Zealand]] [[Category:Ministries established in 1989|New Zealand, Education]]

revision.text:
{{More citations needed|date=November 2010}} '''Monographic series''' (alternatively, '''monographs in series''') are scholarly and scientific books released in successive volumes, each of which is structured like a separate book or [[monograph|scholarly monograph]]. [[File:Loeb Classical Library.jpg|thumb|A volume in the [[Loeb Classical Library]]. Each installment in this monographic series is devoted to a Greek or Latin author, and is accompanied by extensive commentary and notes from the editors.]]
==Semantics== In general books that are released serially (in successive parts) once a year, or less often, are called [[Book series|series]]. Publications that are released more often than once a year are known as [[periodical]]s. If the volumes can each stand on their own as a separate book, they are called monographs in series, if not they are called '''book sets'''.
==Associations== The connection among books belonging to such a series can be by discipline, focus, approach, type of work, or geographic location. Examples of such series include "Antwerp Working Papers in Linguistics";<ref>"Antwerp working papers in linguistics" {{OCLC|66592270}}</ref> "Early English Manuscripts in Facsimile" (Rosenkilde & Bagger, Copenhagen);<ref>Early English manuscripts in facsimile" {{ISSN|0070-7856}}</ref> Garland reference library; "Canterbury Tales Project" <ref>Garland reference library; "Canterbury Tales Project" {{ISSN|1351-3435}}</ref> (see ''[[The Canterbury Tales]]''); [[Early English Text Society]].
The ''[[Library of Anglo-Catholic Theology]]'' (a series of 19th-century editions of theological works by [[Church of England]] writers, devoted to significant [[Anglo-Catholic]] figures,<ref>Arthur Middleton, ''Fathers and Anglicans'' (2004), p. 281.</ref> published by [[John Henry Parker]]) is an example of a common usage in naming monographic series; another example is the [[John Harvard Library (series)|John Harvard Library]] which consists of notable works relating to the United States. The [[Loeb Classical Library]] is a series of editions of Greek and Latin texts in which the original texts are accompanied by translations into English; the series was begun by James Loeb and is published by [[Harvard University Press]], Cambridge, Massachusetts<ref>Tracy Lee Simmons, "[https://web.archive.org/web/20070930222542/https://www.weeklystandard.com/Utilities/printer_preview.asp?idArticle=12377 Little Big Books: the red and green guides to the wisdom of the Ancient World]" in ''The Weekly Standard'' no. 40 (3 July 2006)</ref> Series intended for general readers may also have "library" in their titles, e.g. [[Everyman's Library]].
==Categorization== Libraries and indexing services handle them in various ways. The [[Library of Congress]] catalogs each part of them as an individual book with an individual call number and [[ISBN]] and a series note (technically a series added entry for the overall series, which has its [[ISSN]], and usually a call number. As the Library of Congress receives two copies of most scholarly books as [[copyright]] deposits, it normally keeps one by individual call number and one by series call number. Most other libraries do not have that luxury and have to choose. The Anglo-American Cataloging Rules 2nd edition allows either of these options to be used.<ref>American Library Association, et al. ''Anglo-American Cataloguing Rules''; 2nd ed., edited by Michael Gorman and Paul W. Winkler. London: Library Association, 1976; ch. 2, sect. 6</ref>
[[Medical library|Medical libraries]] almost always keep them together as a series. The biomedical indexing service [[PubMed]] from the [[National Library of Medicine]] treat the individual volumes in such a series as if they were volumes in a journal.
* ''[[Advances in Experimental Medicine and Biology]]'' {{ISSN|0065-2598}}
==Themed volumes== In many cases each volume in such a series itself contains individual chapters or articles written by different authors, usually on the same general theme. The Library of Congress does not list each such article separately, but PubMed does.
A frequent occasion for such a themed volume is a celebration in honor of a person's scholarly work. If done at retirement or on an anniversary (e.g. 60th birthday), it is usually called a [[Festschrift]] or celebration volume. If after death, it is usually called a [[memorial]].
The publisher Variorum Reprints began publishing its Collected Studies series in 1970. Each of these volumes contains "a selection of articles by a leading authority on a particular subject ... reprinted from a vast range of learned journals, [[Festschrifts]], conference proceedings ...". These volumes are published by [[Ashgate Publications]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.ashgate.com/default.aspx?page=1449|title=Variorum Collected Studies|publisher=[[Ashgate Publishing]]|accessdate=30 August 2012}}</ref>
==See also== {{main cat|Monographic series}} * [[Book series]] * [[Collection (publishing)]] * [[Serials, periodicals and journals]] * [[Academic publishing]] * [[Edited volume]]
== References == {{reflist}}
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Monographic Series}} [[Category:Monographic series|*]] [[Category:Academic publishing]] [[Category:Books by type]]

{{Infobox organization | name = MormonLeaks | native_name = | native_name_lang = | named_after = [[Mormon]] and [[WikiLeaks]] | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | logo = MormonLeaks.jpg | logo_size = 300px | logo_alt = MormonLeaks logo | logo_caption = MormonLeaks logo | map = | map_size = | map_alt = | map_caption = | map2 = | map2_size = | map2_alt = | map2_caption = | abbreviation = | motto = | predecessor = MormonWikiLeaks | merged = | successor = | formation = {{start date and age|2016|12|19}} | founder = Ryan McKnight | founding_location = | extinction = <!-- use {{end date and age|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | merger = | type = [[Archive|Document archive]] and [[Whistleblowing|disclosure]] | tax_id = <!-- or | vat_id = (for European organizations) --> | registration_id = <!-- for non-profit org --> | status = | purpose = Publicize secret [[The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints|LDS Church]] documents | headquarters = | location = | coords = <!-- {{coord|LAT|LON|display=inline, title}} --> | region = [[Las Vegas]], Nevada, United States | services = | products = | methods = | fields = | membership = | membership_year = | language = English | owner = <!-- or | owners = --> | sec_gen = | leader_title = | leader_name = | leader_title2 = | leader_name2 = | leader_title3 = | leader_name3 = | leader_title4 = | leader_name4 = | board_of_directors = | key_people = | main_organ = | parent_organization = | subsidiaries = | secessions = | affiliations = | budget = | budget_year = | revenue = | revenue_year = | disbursements = | expenses = | expenses_year = | endowment = | staff = Five volunteers and one attorney | staff_year = | volunteers = 5 | volunteers_year = | slogan = | mission = | website = {{URL|https://mormonleaks.io}} | remarks = | formerly = MormonWikiLeaks | footnotes = }} '''MormonLeaks''' (formerly '''Mormon WikiLeaks''') is a [[whistleblowing]] organization inspired by [[WikiLeaks]], which focuses on exposing documents from the leadership of [[The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints]] (LDS Church). It began in October 2016 as a leaked series of videos on the [[YouTube]] channel '''Mormon Leaks'''. In total, 15 videos were initially leaked via the Mormon Leaks channel from meetings of high-ranking LDS leaders including the [[Quorum of the Twelve]]. They discussed topics including the "[[homosexual agenda]]", the [[subprime mortgage crisis]], and a debate over the [[sexual orientation]] of [[Chelsea Manning]]. Politicians featured in the videos included former Utah governor [[Mike Leavitt]] and former U.S. Senator from Oregon [[Gordon H. Smith]].
Ryan McKnight, founder of MormonLeaks, was interviewed by ''[[The New York Times]]'' about his YouTube channel Mormon Leaks, and this led to contacts from [[Reddit]] who asked him for a secure way to send files. He set up a website to allow whistleblowers to protect their [[anonymity]]. The submission process ensures [[confidentiality]], including erasure of [[IP address|IP addresses]], asking leakers to use the privacy browser [[Tor (anonymity network)|Tor]], sending documents via [[SecureDrop]], and additional [[encryption]] methods. Initial funding was raised through [[GoFundMe]], and an official [[Twitter]] account was set up. The site's intent is to increase transparency of LDS Church leadership, and would not leak names of lower-level employees, instead focusing on the Quorum of the Twelve and the [[First Presidency (LDS Church)|First Presidency]].
[[University of Tampa]] professor Ryan Cragun said scholars were interested in finding out what documents would be revealed, noting there was a dearth of information available about the [[Finances of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints|finances of the LDS Church]]. He said active Mormons were unlikely to view the leaked materials, but the material would have a more significant impact on those who were questioning or had already resigned their membership status. Mormon scholar and columnist [[Jana Riess]] gave a mixed assessment, criticizing their tactics regarding privacy while saying it could help to increase LDS Church leadership transparency. Utah attorney and Mormon blogger Steve Evans said the practice of leaking was criminal publication of stolen property, and said LDS Church employees who leaked material were likely violating a [[non-disclosure agreements|non-disclosure agreement]].
==Organization== ===Beginnings on YouTube === [[File:LDS Conference Center-up.jpg|thumb|Videos were posted to the YouTube channel Mormon Leaks on the last day of the October 2016 LDS [[General Conference (LDS Church)|General Conference]].<ref name=mattcanham /><ref name=conferenceweekend />]]
Ryan McKnight, the site's founder, had previously gained attention in October 2016 when he was interviewed by ''[[The New York Times]]'' about his [[YouTube]] channel ''Mormon Leaks'', which released videos of top LDS leadership executive discussions.<ref name=leakedvideos>{{citation|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/10/07/us/mormon-videos-leaked.html|accessdate=December 20, 2016|work=[[The New York Times]]|title=Leaked Videos Pull Back Curtain on Mormon Leadership|first=Laurie|last=Goodstein|date=October 2, 2016}}</ref><ref name="chandler">{{citation|last=Chandler|first=Michael Alison|title=Former church member launches ‘Mormon Wikileaks’ for anonymous sharing of documents and videos|date=December 20, 2016|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/acts-of-faith/wp/2016/12/20/mormon-wikileaks-launched-by-former-church-member|work=[[The Washington Post]]|accessdate=December 20, 2016}}</ref><ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=http://news.nationalpost.com/news/religion/former-church-member-launches-mormon-wikileaks-site-our-goal-is-pure-and-simple-transparency|title=Former church member launches 'Mormon Wikileaks' site: 'Our goal is, pure and simple, transparency'|newspaper=National Post|access-date=2016-12-28}}</ref> McKnight is a former Mormon, having resigned from the LDS Church in 2014,<ref name="chandler" /><ref name=":0" /><ref name=exmormoncreates /> residing in [[Las Vegas, Nevada]].<ref name=newwebsiteplans>{{citation|url=http://www.sltrib.com/lifestyle/faith/4725913-155/new-website-plans-to-showcase-leaked|accessdate=December 20, 2016|work=[[The Salt Lake Tribune]]|title=New website plans to showcase leaked Mormon documents|first=Peggy Fletcher|last=Stack|date=December 17, 2016}}</ref><ref name=mandyvelez>{{citation|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/former-church-member-launches-mormon-wikileaks-a7487536.html|work=[[The Independent]]|accessdate=December 20, 2016|date=December 20, 2016|first=Mandy|last=Velez|title=Former church member launches ‘Mormon Wikileaks’ for anonymous tips and whistleblowers}}</ref> The anonymous individual who sent him the videos via email, according to McKnight, had been holding onto them for a period of years but with the intention to do something with them eventually.<ref name=notapproval /><ref name=manbehind>{{citation|url=http://fox13now.com/2016/10/03/man-behind-postings-of-lds-church-leaked-videos-says-clips-were-anonymously-emailed-to-him/|title=Man behind postings of LDS Church leaked videos says clips were anonymously emailed to him|first1=Tiffany|last1=Demasters|first2=Jeff|last2=McAdam|date=October 3, 2016|accessdate=December 21, 2016|work=[[KSTU]]}}</ref> Within a time span of under a month the YouTube channel had garnered 2,200 followers.<ref name=alexjohnson />
The LDS Church did not publicly question the veracity of the videos,<ref name=newwebsiteplans /> which included top leadership debating the "[[homosexual agenda]]".<ref name=alexthompson>{{citation|url=https://news.vice.com/article/mormon-church-leaders-discuss-homosexual-agenda-in-leaked-videos|accessdate=December 20, 2016|work=[[Vice (magazine)|Vice]]|first=Alex|last=Thompson|title=Mormon church leaders discuss 'homosexual agenda' in leaked videos|date=October 3, 2016}}</ref> Additional topics discussed by the high-level LDS Church leadership in the videos included [[marijuana]], [[Islam]], the [[subprime mortgage crisis]], and a debate over the [[sexual orientation]] of [[Chelsea Manning]].<ref name=conferenceweekend /><ref name=mattcanham>{{citation|url=http://www.sltrib.com/lifestyle/faith/4423214-155/leaked-videos-show-mormon-apostles-discussing|first=Matt|last=Canham|title=Leaked videos show Mormon apostles discussing political influence, gay marriage, marijuana and more|work=[[The Salt Lake Tribune]]|accessdate=December 21, 2016|date=October 2, 2016}}</ref><ref name=brieflook>{{citation|url=http://www.sltrib.com/news/lds/4424105-155/a-brief-look-at-whats-in|work=[[The Salt Lake Tribune]]|title=A brief look at what’s in leaked Mormon videos|first1=Matt|last1=Canham|first2=David|last2=Noyce|first3=Benjamin|last3=Wood|first4=Peggy Fletcher|last4=Stack|date=October 2, 2016|accessdate=December 21, 2016}}</ref> LDS Church spokesman Eric Hawkins provided an official response, which stated: "In these committee meetings, presentations are routinely received from various religious, political and subject matter experts on various topics. The purpose is to understand issues that may face the Church, and is in pursuit of the obligation Church leaders feel to be informed on and have open discussion about current issues. This is an informational forum, not a decision-making body."<ref name=conferenceweekend /><ref name=seeitnow /><ref name=aldovazquez /> Hawkins pointed out the videos were from a timeframe of 2007 through 2012.<ref name=conferenceweekend /><ref name=seeitnow /><ref name=aldovazquez>{{citation|url=http://www.good4utah.com/news/local-news/videos-of-private-meetings-between-lds-leaders-leaked-online/590861820|work=[[KTVX]]|accessdate=December 21, 2016|date=October 2, 2016|title=Videos of private meetings between LDS leaders leaked online|first=Aldo|last=Vazquez}}</ref>
In total the 15 videos were published to YouTube on the last day of the October 2016 LDS [[General Conference (LDS Church)|General Conference]].<ref name=mattcanham /><ref name=conferenceweekend>{{citation|work=[[KSTU]]|accessdate=December 21, 2016|date=October 13, 2016|author=Fox 13 News|title=Videos of high-ranking LDS leaders discussing social issues anonymously released on conference weekend|url=http://fox13now.com/2016/10/02/videos-of-high-ranking-lds-leaders-discussing-social-issues-anonymously-released-on-conference-weekend/}}</ref><ref name=seeitnow>{{citation|accessdate=December 21, 2016|title=See it now: Mormon Leaks shares video of closed-door briefings of LDS Church leaders|date=October 2, 2016|url=http://gephardtdaily.com/local/mormon-leaks-videos/|work=Gephardt Daily}}</ref> Most of the videos were from closed session events only attended by high-level LDS Church leadership.<ref name=seeitnow /> The majority of them depicted lectures given to the [[Quorum of the Twelve]], the second-highest ranking leadership group within the LDS Church.<ref name=mattcanham /> [[Mike Leavitt]], former governor of Utah, appeared in a video filmed in 2012 and gave a presentation on [[State Religious Freedom Restoration Acts]].<ref name=mattcanham /> [[Gordon H. Smith]], former U.S. senator from Oregon, was shown in another video talking to the LDS Church leadership.<ref name=jeffmapes /><ref name=wweek>{{citation|url=http://www.wweek.com/news/2016/10/03/mormon-leaks-video-features-former-u-s-sen-gordon-smith-r-ore/|accessdate=December 21, 2016|date=October 3, 2016|first=Nigel|last=Jaquiss|title=Mormon Leaks Video Features Former U.S. Sen. Gordon Smith (R-Ore.)|work=[[Willamette Week]]}}</ref> Smith lectured the LDS Church leaders about the "inestimable power" yielded from being able to contact U.S. Senators whenever necessary for assistance.<ref name=jeffmapes>{{citation|first=Jeff|last=Mapes|work=[[KUOW-FM]]|accessdate=December 21, 2016|date=October 3, 2016|url=http://kuow.org/post/mormon-leaks-show-former-oregon-senator-who-did-favors-church|title='Mormon Leaks' Show Former Oregon Senator Who Did Favors For Church}}</ref> The lectures given to LDS Church leadership in this fashion were businesslike, with [[statistics]] and [[Microsoft PowerPoint]] presentations.<ref name=marybarker>{{citation|url=http://religiondispatches.org/mormon-leaks-boring-meetings-with-interesting-implications/|accessdate=December 21, 2016|work=[[Religion Dispatches]]|title=Mormon Leaks: Boring Meetings with Interesting Implications|date=November 1, 2016}}</ref>
McKnight suddenly found himself the point-person on the Internet for those wishing to maintain anonymity and yet simultaneously publicize secret documents from the LDS Church.<ref name=tareqhaddad>{{citation|url=http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/disillusioned-ex-church-member-starts-mormon-wikileaks-shed-light-secretive-organisation-1597492|accessdate=December 21, 2016|date=December 21, 2016|work=[[International Business Times]]|title=Disillusioned ex-church member starts 'Mormon Wikileaks' to shed light on secretive organisation|first=Tareq|last=Haddad}}</ref> After the videos engendered debate and attention from Mormons and the wider Internet community, McKnight was asked to add more videos from people who messaged him on [[Reddit]].<ref name=valkenburg /><ref name=leakedvideos /> After another anonymous user on Reddit asked him, he publicized documents from the LDS Church detailing a rules modification about homosexual partners.<ref name=exmormoncreates /> Reddit users asked him for a more secure means of submitting documents about the LDS Church.<ref name=bixenspan />
===Transition to dedicated website=== {{multiple image | width = 150 | image1 = Tor-logo-2011-flat.svg | alt1 = Tor | image2 = SecureDrop logo.svg | alt2 = SecureDrop | footer =MormonLeaks uses [[Tor (anonymity network)|Tor privacy browser]] and [[secure communication]] [[SecureDrop]] to protect confidentiality.<ref name=alexjohnson /><ref name=notapproval /> }} McKnight decided to found MormonLeaks so whistleblowers could protect their [[anonymity]].<ref name=valkenburg /> Since his increased attention from the October videos and the November policy change leaks, McKnight has been contacted by 25 sources inside and outside of the LDS Church with potential material to release.<ref name=exmormoncreates /> McKnight and his team spent six months planning creation of the organization.<ref name=exmormoncreates /> He estimated approximately a potential for between hundreds to thousands of additional invididuals who may wish to leak information through the site.<ref name=notapproval /> The organization has no affiliation with [[Fred Karger#LDS Church|Fred Karger]] or his website [http://mormontips.com/ MormonTips.com], which also publicizes confidential documents from the LDS Church.<ref name=exmormoncreates /> MormonLeaks takes steps to protect [[confidentiality]] of their sources, including erasing all IP addresses from submissions and removing watermarks from submitted materials.<ref name=exmormoncreates /> The site asks users who wish to submit secret documents to use the [[Tor (anonymity network)|Tor privacy browser]] to protect themselves.<ref name=alexjohnson /> Users then send the documents to MormonLeaks via [[SecureDrop]].<ref name=notapproval>{{citation|accessdate=December 21, 2016|date=December 20, 2016|url=http://gephardtdaily.com/local/mormonwikileaker-seeks-lds-church-transparency-not-approval/|work=Gephardt Daily|title=MormonWikiLeaker seeks LDS Church ‘transparency,’ not approval}}</ref> [[Encryption]] methods are further incorporated to mask the identity of the whistleblowers.<ref name=tareqhaddad /> The motivation behind the organization is to increase transparency of LDS Church leadership.<ref name=sharesecret>{{citation|url=http://www.kivitv.com/news/former-lds-member-starts-mormon-wikileaks-to-share-secret-church-documents|accessdate=December 21, 2016|date=December 20, 2016|title=Former LDS member starts Mormon Wikileaks to share secret church documents|work=[[KIVI-TV]]}}</ref><ref name=sirinkale>{{citation|first=Sirin|last=Kale|accessdate=December 21, 2016|work=[[Vice (magazine)|Vice]]|url=https://broadly.vice.com/en_us/article/the-ex-mormon-exposing-the-lds-church-with-a-whistle-blowing-website|title=The Ex-Mormon Exposing the LDS Church With a Whistle-Blowing Website|date=December 21, 2016}}</ref>
MormonLeaks launched on December 19, 2016.<ref name=valkenburg>{{citation|url=http://gephardtdaily.com/religion/mormon-wikileaks-twitter-page-going-online-monday/|accessdate=December 20, 2016|title=Developing: Mormon WikiLeaks website, Twitter page going online Monday|first=Nancy |last=Van Valkenburg |date=December 15, 2016|work=Gephardt Daily}}</ref><ref name=exmormoncreates>{{citation|accessdate=December 20, 2016|url=http://kutv.com/news/local/ex-mormon-creates-mormonwikileaks-website-set-to-launch-on-monday|title=Ex-Mormon creates MormonWikiLeaks website, set to launch on Monday|first= Cimaron |last=Neugebauer|date= December 18, 2016|work=[[KUTV]]}}</ref><ref name=bixenspan>{{citation|url=http://www.mediaite.com/online/former-lds-member-starts-mormonwikileaks-for-church-documents/|work=[[Mediaite]]|publisher=[[Dan Abrams|Abrams Media]]|accessdate=December 20, 2016|date=December 20, 2016|title=Former LDS Member Starts MormonWikiLeaks for Church Documents|first=David |last=Bixenspan }}</ref> The organization was started with a website and accompanying [[Twitter]] page.<ref name=valkenburg /> The MormonLeaks team works to verify documents before posting them live.<ref name=newwebsiteplans /><ref name=exmormoncreates /> This fact-checking team includes five volunteers and an attorney.<ref name=mandyvelez /> MormonLeaks does not take funding through advertising.<ref name=newwebsiteplans /> Funds to start MormonLeaks itself were initially raised through donations from [[GoFundMe]].<ref name=exmormoncreates /><ref name=mandyvelez /> The hope of its founder was that MormonLeaks would demonstrate the LDS Church's profitable nature as a business as opposed to its assertion of religious status.<ref name=newwebsiteplans /> The founder said it was highly unlikely the LDS Church would voluntarily publicize more of its innermost proceedings, saying it "will never be voluntarily transparent, they have nothing to gain from it".<ref name=exmormoncreates /> The site's intention was to avoid publishing specific lists of names of membership, and instead focus on economic information and internal organization policies and procedures.<ref name=witham /><ref name=sirinkale /> The site intended to limit disclosure of actual people's names to high-ranking officials including the [[Quorum of the Twelve]] and the [[First Presidency (LDS Church)|First Presidency]].<ref name=witham /><ref name=mattmcdonald>{{citation|accessdate=December 20, 2016|first=Matt|last=McDonald|work=[[KSTU]]|title=‘MormonWikileaks’ website launched, seeking transparency in LDS Church|date=December 20, 2016}}</ref>
The organization's first leaks appeared on December 19, 2016, in the form of LDS Church documents from 2010.<ref name=mandyvelez /><ref name=alexjohnson>{{citation|work=[[NBC News]]|date=December 20, 2016|accessdate=December 21, 2016|first=Alex|last=Johnson|title=A 'Wikileaks' for Secret Church Documents Launches for Concerned Mormons|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/wikileaks-secret-church-documents-launches-concerned-mormons-n698496}}</ref> It published four files onto its account on Facebook as of December 20, 2016.<ref name=witham>{{citation|url=https://www.stgeorgeutah.com/news/archive/2016/12/20/jcw-mormon-wiki-leaks-launched|work=St George News|location=[[St. George, Utah]]|title=Former Mormon launches MormonWikiLeaks website seeking church transparency|first= Joseph |last=Witham|date=December 20, 2016|accessdate=December 20, 2016}}</ref> The first documents publicized by MormonLeaks included memos about legal procedures, a letter to the temple department's executive director regarding unsanctioned materials on the Internet, and an [[organizational chart]] for the [[intellectual property]] division of the LDS Church.<ref name=mattmcdonald /> MormonLeaks asserts to have been offered documents from two separate individuals who were employees of the LDS Church concerning [[tithing (Latter Day Saints)|tithing]] information of famous Mormons, including American football quarterback [[Steve Young]].<ref name=mattmcdonald />
After MormonLeaks had posted a handful a number of LDS Church documents for four months, the Church sent a [[cease-and-desist letter]] alleging [[copyright infringement]] with regard to a leaked Church leadership [[Microsoft PowerPoint|PowerPoint]] [[slide show|presentation]] published by MormonLeaks in February 2017. The PowerPoint discussed societal pressures that the Church felt had led some LDS members to apostasy, which included [[pornography]], the issues agitated for by [[Ordain Women]], and questions regarding [[Mormon history]] such as those promoted in books by lawyer / [[Fundamentalist Mormon]] [[Denver C. Snuffer Jr.|Denver Snuffer]] or in online postings by psychologist [[social critic]] [[John Dehlin]]. MormonLeaks pulled the offending document for a short while, until its attorney, [[Marc Randazza]], sent the LDS Church a letter which said, "At this point, my client is willing to let bygones be bygones. If your client is willing to step back from the brink, and to cease efforts to censor this material, my client is willing to refrain from bringing a claim [of abusing copyright law]."<ref name=mormonleaksreposts>{{citation|access-date=June 16, 2017|work=[[The Salt Lake Tribune]]|url=http://www.sltrib.com/news/lds/5056058-155/mormonleaks-reposts-lds-church-apostasy-presentation|title=MormonLeaks reposts LDS Church apostasy presentation, rebuffs faith’s copyright violation claim|first=Bob|last=Mims|date=March 14, 2017}}</ref><ref name=enemieslist>{{citation|work=[[The Washington Post]]|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/acts-of-faith/wp/2017/03/17/mormonleaks-website-squares-off-with-mormon-church-posts-leaked-enemies-list/|title=MormonLeaks website squares off with Mormon Church, posts leaked ‘Enemies List’|access-date=June 16, 2017|date=March 17, 2017|first= Michael Alison |last=Chandler}} </ref>
==Reception== [[WikiLeaks]] was aware of the foundation under the site's original name of MormonWikiLeaks, and sent them a message on Twitter asking them to change their name.<ref name=mandyvelez /> The founder stated he would retain the name as MormonWikiLeaks, and said a trademark application was pending.<ref name=mandyvelez />
[[University of Tampa]] professor Ryan Cragun said academics were excited to discover more information about the economics behind the LDS Church, as members tithe 10 percent of their earnings and there was not much in the way of transparent documents available to research their holdings and finances.<ref name=chandler /><ref name=":0" /> Cragun said it was unlikely active members of the LDS Church would end up viewing the leaked documents because they were "highly insulated".<ref name=chandler /><ref name=":0" /> However, he notes documents would have a greater impact on someone who is considering leaving the LDS Church: "For someone in the middle of a faith transition, such information is more fuel for the fire."<ref name=chandler /><ref name=":0" />
[[Editor-in-chief]] of ''The Nonprofit Quarterly'', Ruth McCambridge, wrote that the appearance of MormonLeaks was reflective of an increasing trend by individuals to use technology to force nonprofit organizations to be transparent and accountable to the public.<ref name=npq>{{citation|issn=1934-6050|oclc=46351191|publisher=Nonprofit Information Networking Association|location=[[Boston]], [[Massachusetts]]|date=December 21, 2016|journal=The Nonprofit Quarterly|first=Ruth|last=McCambridge|accessdate=December 22, 2016|url=https://nonprofitquarterly.org/2016/12/21/forcing-nonprofit-transparency-mormon-church-ends-wikileaks/|archivedate=December 22, 2016|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161222045913/https://nonprofitquarterly.org/2016/12/21/forcing-nonprofit-transparency-mormon-church-ends-wikileaks/|title=Forcing Nonprofit Transparency: Mormon Church Ends Up with Its Own Wikileaks}}</ref> MormonLeaks has an attorney on staff, which McCambridge notes may be beneficial given the prior litigation history where the LDS Church made a copyright infringement assertion against WikiLeaks for publishing the church's ''[[Handbook (LDS Church)|Handbook of Instructions]]''.<ref name=npq />
Mormon scholar and columnist [[Jana Riess]] was critical of the organization's tactics, stating: "I am very concerned about privacy in our culture more generally. People in the workplace have the right to expect that intraoffice communication and their emails will stay private."<ref name=newwebsiteplans /> She called MormonLeaks "disturbing" and said: "It is not good news for any of us."<ref name=newwebsiteplans /> On a positive note, Riess said it could motivate the upper LDS Church leadership to increase its transparency.<ref name=newwebsiteplans />
Utah attorney and Mormon blogger Steve Evans called MormonLeaks "a rebranding exercise of McKnight's existing practice of posting various confidential items."<ref name=newwebsiteplans /> Evans said MormonLeaks had "an added layer of cybersecurity, which won't necessarily protect the leakers, depending on their methods of obtaining the various stolen documents, videos, etc."<ref name=newwebsiteplans /> Evans was critical of McKnight's encouragement to those who choose to leak information to MormonLeaks: "the leakers are likely either church employees or consultants working for the church. In either of those situations, it's very likely that the leakers are violating their nondisclosure and confidentiality agreements with the church. McKnight is now publicly encouraging people to violate these agreements."<ref name=newwebsiteplans />
==See also== {{Portal|Intelligence|Latter-day Saints}} {{Div col|colwidth=22em}} *[[Criticism of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints]] *[[Mormon Tips]] *[[Digital rights]] *[[Freedom of information]] *[[GlobaLeaks]] *[[Homosexuality and The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints]] *[[Mormonism in the 21st century]] *[[Open society]] *[[Transparency (behavior)]] {{div col end}}
==References== {{Reflist|2}}

Fausett|format = video|author = [[John Dehlin]]}}
