{{Use mdy dates|date=April 2012}} {{Infobox organization | logo = [[Image:USA logo.png|United States Artists logo]] | type = Philanthropic arts organization | key_people = [[Deana Haggag]], CEO<ref>[http://www.unitedstatesartists.org/Public/AboutUnitedStatesArtists/Staff/index.cfm United States Artists Official Website. About]</ref> | name = United States Artists | founded_date = 2005 | founder = | location = Chicago, USA | origins = | area_served = United States | product = | focus = American artists | method = Awards unrestricted grants of $50,000 to 50 artists per annum<ref>Stephanie Strom, [https://www.nytimes.com/2006/09/05/arts/design/05unit.html "New Charity to Start Plan for $50,000 Artists' Grants"], ''The New York Times'', September 5. 2006 ]</ref> | revenue = | endowment = Initial seed funding of (US) $22.6M<ref>Stephanie Strom, [https://www.nytimes.com/2007/10/10/arts/design/10gran.html "An Artist's Grant that Even Pays For Glasses"], ''The New York Times'', October 7, 2007</ref> provided by [[Ford Foundation]], [[Rockefeller Foundation]], [[Prudential Foundation]], and Rasmuson Foundation<ref>[http://www.unitedstatesartists.org/Public/CommonQuestions/index/cfm United States Artists Official Website. Common Questions]</ref> | Non-profit_slogan = | homepage = http://unitedstatesartists.org }}
'''United States Artists''' ('''USA''') is an independent nonprofit and nongovernmental [[philanthropic organization]] based in Chicago and dedicated to supporting the work of living American artists by the granting of cash awards, called [[List of United States Artists (USA) Fellowship recipients|USA Fellowships]].<ref>Editorial, "[http://archive.boston.com/news/globe/editorial_opinion/editorials/articles/2006/09/25/art_for_our_sake/ Art for our sake]," ''[[The Boston Globe]]'', September 25, 2006</ref> It was founded in 2005 with initial funding from the [[Ford Foundation]], the [[Rockefeller Foundation]], The [[Prudential Foundation]], and the Rasmuson Foundation, and the first set of 50 fellowships were announced in 2006.<ref>Patrick Cole, [https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=newsarchive&sid=aV4ZXOmY4AXM "Seminole Filmmaker, Guitarist Awarded $50,000 Grants" (Update1)], [[Bloomberg.com]], December 4, 2006.</ref> The organization is governed by a Board of Directors and receives additional funding from several major American foundations, corporate partners, and private citizens.
== Mission ==
The organization's stated mission is "to invest in America's finest artists and illuminate the value of artists to society."<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.unitedstatesartists.org/about/|title=United States Artists}}</ref> In addition, the organization asserts that "[[List of United States Artists (USA) Fellowship recipients|USA Fellowships]] honor and award an artist’s unique vision as a whole rather than funding a particular project. Artists at different career levels, from emerging to established, are eligible."<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.unitedstatesartists.org/connect#faq|title=United States Artists » Connect|website=www.unitedstatesartists.org|access-date=2018-01-19}}</ref>
== Selection process ==
Prerequisites for consideration include that the artist be 21 or older, a [[US citizen]] or [[legal resident]]. In addition, nominees must be accomplished artists, must have acquired art training, formal or informal, must have tried to derive income from those skills, and must have been "actively engaged in creating artwork and presenting it to the public." To be considered for a grant, an artist must first be nominated by at least one of a group of "nominators" chosen by the organization. This is an anonymous group of arts scholars, critics, and artists from various disciplines; they operate independently of one another. The nominators submit names of artists they believe should be considered for an award.<ref name=":0" />
Once nominated artists have been notified of their nomination, they are then directed to apply for the grant in order to be considered. The awards are announced once a year. The Fellows announcement is made in December of each year.
==Grants==
Grants are awarded annually to artists working in nine disciplines: {{columns-list|colwidth=15em|style=width: 600px;| *[[Design|Architecture & Design]] *[[Craft|Crafts]] *[[Dance]] *[[Literature]] *[[Electronic media|Media]] *[[Music]] *[[Theatre arts|Theater & Performance]] *[[traditional arts|Traditional Arts]] *[[Visual arts|Visual Arts]] }}
== USA Fellows == [[List of United States Artists (USA) Fellowship recipients]]
== References == {{reflist|colwidth=30em}}
== External links == *[http://www.unitedstatesartists.org/ United States Artists website] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20080515215900/http://www.unitedstatesartists.org/Public/EncounterUSAFellows/index.cfm United States Artists grant recipient videos] *[http://www.interiordesign.net/index.asp?layout=preview&articleID=CA6512549/ Nicholas Tamarin, "United States Artists Awards $50,000 Grants," ''Interior Design''] *Mario Rosario Jackson, Florence Kabwasa-Green, Daniel Swenson, Joaquin Herranz, Kadija Ferryman, Caron Atlas, Eric Wallner, Carole Rosenstein: Investing in Creativity: A Study of the Support Structure for U.S. Artists. The [[Urban Institute]], May 2, 2006. [http://www.urban.org/url.cfm?ID=411311]
[[Category:Fellowships]] [[Category:Non-profit organizations based in Chicago]] [[Category:Arts organizations established in 2005]] [[Category:2005 establishments in Illinois]]

The '''Imperial University of [[Constantinople]]''', sometimes known as the '''University of the Palace Hall of Magnaura''' ({{lang-el|Πανδιδακτήριον τῆς Μαγναύρας}}), can trace its corporate origins to 425 AD, when the [[Eastern Roman Empire | Eastern Roman]] ([[Byzantine Empire|Byzantine]]) emperor [[Theodosius II]] founded the '''Pandidakterion''' (Πανδιδακτήριον).<ref> "The Formation of the Hellenic Christian Mind" by [[Demetrios Constantelos]], {{ISBN|0-89241-588-6}}: "The fifth century marked a definite turning point in Byzantine higher education. Theodosios ΙΙ founded in 425 a major university with 31 chairs for law, philosophy, medicine, arithmetic, geometry, astronomy, music, rhetoric and other subjects. Fifteen chairs were assigned to Latin and 16 to Greek. The university was reorganized by Michael III (842–867) and flourished down to the fourteenth century".</ref>
The Pandidakterion was refounded in 1046<ref>John H. Rosser, ''Historical Dictionary of Byzantium'', Scarecrow Press, 2001, p. xxx.</ref> by [[Constantine IX Monomachos]] who created the Departments of [[Law]] (Διδασκαλεῖον τῶν Νόμων) and [[Philosophy]] (Γυμνάσιον).<ref>Aleksandr Petrovich Kazhdan, Annabel Jane Wharton, ''Change in Byzantine Culture in the Eleventh and Twelfth Centuries'', University of California Press, 1985, p. 122.</ref>
At the time various economic schools, colleges, polytechnics, libraries and fine-arts academies also operated in the city of Constantinople.
== History == Byzantine society on the whole was an educated one. Primary education was widely available, sometimes even at village level and uniquely in that era for both sexes. Female participation in culture was high. Scholarship was fostered not only in Constantinople but also in institutions operated in such major cities as [[Antioch]] and [[Alexandria]].<ref>Peter Rietbergen, ''Europe: A Cultural History'', Routledge, 1998, p. 101.</ref>
The original school was founded in 425 by Emperor [[Theodosius II]] with 31 chairs for [[law]], [[philosophy]], [[medicine]], [[arithmetic]], [[geometry]], [[astronomy]], [[music]], [[rhetoric]] and other subjects, 15 to [[Latin]] and 16 to [[Greek language|Greek]]. The university existed until the 15th century.<ref>[http://www.myriobiblos.gr/texts/english/Constantelos_1.html Myriobiblos]</ref>
The main content of higher education for most students was rhetoric, philosophy and law with the aim of producing competent, learned personnel to staff the bureaucratic postings of state and church. In this sense the university was the secular equivalent of the Theological Schools. The university maintained an active philosophical tradition of [[Platonism]] and [[Aristotelianism]], with the former being the longest unbroken Platonic school, running for close to two millennia until the 15th century.
The School of [[Magnaura]] was founded in the 9th century but did not last very long,<ref>{{Citation | last = Markopoulos | first = Athanasios | editor-last = Jeffreys | editor-first = Elizabeth | editor2-last = Haldon | editor2-first = John F. | editor3-last = Cormack | editor3-first = Robin | year = 2008 | title = The Oxford handbook of Byzantine studies | chapter = Education | series = Oxford Handbooks in Classics and Ancient History | publisher = Oxford University Press | publication-place = Oxford | pages = 785–795 | isbn = 978-0-19-925246-6 }}</ref> and in the 11th new schools of philosophy and law were established at the Capitol School. The period of decline began with the [[Fourth Crusade|Latin conquest]] of 1204 although the university survived as a non-secular institution under Church management until the [[Fall of Constantinople]] in 1453, and was re-established by [[Mehmet II]] as a Madrasa (an Islamic theological school) following the conquest of the city.
[[Matthaios Kamariotis]], lecturer of the University, became the first director of [[Phanar Greek Orthodox College]], which was established in 1454.
== Status == A few scholars have gone so far as calling the Pandidakterion the first "[[university]]" in the world, but this view does not take into account that the Byzantine [[Ancient higher-learning institutions|centers of higher learning]] generally lacked the corporative structure of the [[Medieval university|medieval universities]] of Western Europe which were the first to use the [[Latin]] term ''universitas'' for the [[corporation]]s of students and masters that came to define the institutional character of the university thereafter.<ref>[[Robert Browning (Byzantinist)|Robert Browning]]: "Universities, Byzantine", in: ''[[Dictionary of the Middle Ages]]'', Vol. 12, Charles Scribner's Sons, New York, 1989, pp. 300–302 (300): {{quote|Universities, Byzantine. The medieval Greek world knew no autonomous and continuing [[Institution of higher education|institutions of higher education]] comparable to the [[Medieval university|universities]] of the later [[Middle Ages]] in [[Western Europe]].}}</ref><ref name="Loukaki 1997, 1553">Marina Loukaki: "Université. Domaine byzantin", in: ''[[Dictionnaire encyclopédique du Moyen Âge]]'', Vol. 2, Éditions du Cerf, Paris, 1997, {{ISBN|2-204-05866-1}}, p. 1553: {{quote|Le nom "université" désigne au Moyen Âge occidental une organisation corporative des élèves et des maîtres, avec ses fonctions et privilèges, qui cultive un ensemble d'études supérieures. L'existence d'une telle institution est fort contestée pour Byzance. Seule l'école de Constantinople sous Théodose Il peut être prise pour une institution universitaire. Par la loi de 425, l'empereur a établi l'"université de Constantinople", avec 31 professeurs rémunérés par l'État qui jouissaient du monopole des cours publics.}}</ref> Nonetheless, the ''Dictionnaire encyclopédique du Moyen Âge'' tentatively identifies the Pandidakterion of 425 AD as a "university institution".<ref name="Loukaki 1997, 1553"/>
== See also == * [[Byzantine Aristotelianism]] * [[Byzantine university]] * [[Faculty and alumni of the University of Constantinople]]

==External links== * Spyros Panagopoulos, [http://www.eriande.elemedu.upatras.gr/eriande/synedria/synedrio4/praktika1/panagopoulos.htm "Higher Education in Byzantium"] {{el icon}} {{Authority control}} [[Category:Greek culture]] [[Category:Constantinople]] [[Category:425 establishments]] [[Category:Educational institutions established in the 5th century|Constantinople]] [[Category:1453 disestablishments in Europe]] [[Category:Defunct universities and colleges|Constantinople, University of]] [[Category:Education in the Byzantine Empire]] [[Category:5th-century establishments in the Byzantine Empire]]

{{Infobox website | name = WizIQ | logo = Logo wiziq.png | type = [[Privately held]] | foundation = {{start date and age|2007|4}} | creators = Harman Singh | location_city = [[Gurgaon, India]] | collapsible = Yes | language = English, Spanish, Arabic | registration = www.wiziq.com/signup | author = | key_people = Harman Singh (Founder & CEO) | industry = Educational technology | products = {{Collapsible list|WizIQ LMS| WizIQ Virtual Classroom| Virtual Classroom API| Moodle Integration}} | services = | revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = | owner = | num_employees = | parent = authorGEN Technologies Pvt. Ltd. | divisions = | subsid = | caption = | homepage = {{URL|https://www.wiziq.com}} | footnotes = | intl = }} Founded in 2007, '''WizIQ''' is a cloud-based education platform.
==History== Founded by Harman Singh,<ref name="fourth_ref">Srmana Mitra. [http://www.sramanamitra.com/2014/11/19/building-a-global-education-saas-company-from-india-wiziq-ceo-harman-singh-part-1/ Building a Global Education SaaS Company from India: WizIQ CEO Harman Singh]. One Million by One Million Blog. Nov 9, 2014</ref> WizIQ has offices in North America: Apex ; India: Gurgaon and Mohali. WizIQ's Alexa traffic rank for India places it among the top 1800 highest traffic sites, and its global Alexa traffic rank is 10,201.<ref name="sixth_ref">[http://www.alexa.com/siteinfo/wiziq.com Wiziq.com site info]. Alexa website. Retrieved July 7, 2015</ref> WizIQ has been featured on ''TechCrunch'', ''Edsurge'', ''Mashable'', ''The Journal'', ''The New York Times'', ''ZDNet'', ''Yahoo'', ''Business Insider'', ''Learning Solutions Magazine'', ''The New Indian Express'', ''VCCircle'', ''Fast Company'', ''Skilledup'', ''The Edvocate'', and other news sites and blogs.<ref name="fifth_ref">Rohit Koshy. [http://www.newindianexpress.com/education/edex/The-Wizard-of-IQ/2014/07/21/article2337480.ece The Wizard of IQ]. The New Indian Express. July 21, 2014</ref><ref>Natasha Lomas. [https://techcrunch.com/2013/01/24/online-education-platform-wiziq-raises-4m-series-b-to-bolster-user-base-led-by-indian-private-equity-fund-kaizen/ Online Education Platform WizIQ Raises $4M Series B To Bolster User-Base, Led By Indian Private Equity Fund Kaizen]. TechCrunch. January 24, 2013</ref><ref>[https://www.edsurge.com/n/2013-01-24-wiziq-nabs-4m-series-b WizIQ Nabs $4M Series B]. Edsurge. January 24, 2013</ref><ref>Zoe Fox. [http://mashable.com/2013/08/20/online-tutoring-resources/ 9 Dependable Destinations for Online Tutoring]. Mashable. August 20, 2013</ref><ref>Trip Gabriel. [https://www.nytimes.com/2010/11/05/us/05college.html?_r=5& Learning in Dorm, Because Class Is on the Web]. The New York Times. November 4, 2010</ref><ref>Christopher Dawson. [http://www.zdnet.com/blog/education/update-on-wiziqvirtual-classrooms/4340 Update on WizIQ/virtual classrooms]. ZDNet. November 16, 2010</ref><ref>Chris Horton. [https://smallbusiness.yahoo.com/advisor/8-online-resources-sharpen-marketing-technology-chops-153638432.html 8 Online Resources to Sharpen Your Marketing Technology Chops]. Yahoo. May 19, 2014</ref><ref>Sainul Abudheen. [http://techcircle.vccircle.com/2014/05/20/wiziq-launches-online-learning-marketplace-to-offer-live-instructor-led-learning/ WizIQ launches online learning marketplace, to offer live instructor-led learning]. VCCircle. May 20, 2014</ref><ref>Laura Vanderkam. [http://www.fastcompany.com/3034600/hit-the-ground-running/can-people-really-learn-at-their-own-pace Can People Really Learn At Their Own Pace?. Fast Company]. August 22, 2014</ref><ref>Judy Quinn. [http://www.skilledup.com/insights/soaring-growth-in-global-e-learning-market/ The Soaring Growth In The Global E-Learning Market]. Skilledup. September 22, 2014</ref><ref>Matthew Lynch. [http://Whats%20Wrong%20With%20Moocs%20And%20Why%20Aren’t%20They%20Working Whats Wrong With Moocs And Why Aren’t They Working]. The Edvocate. October 6, 2014</ref> WizIQ provides App for iPads and Android devices through the Apple App Store and Google Play.<ref>Sanghamitra Mandal. [http://www.businessinsider.in/Edutech-Firm-WizIQ-Launches-iPad-Android-Apps-For-Teachers/articleshow/27316863.cms Edutech Firm WizIQ Launches iPad & Android Apps For Teachers. Business Insider]. December 14, 2013</ref> The platform also provides Desktop App for Windows.<ref>[http://www.wiziq.com/teachblog/the-wiziq-desktop-app-for-live-and-recorded-classes/ The WizIQ Desktop App- For Live and Recorded Classes]. WizIQ Teach Blog. August 1, 2013</ref>
== Technology == WizIQ is a cloud based education platform to access teaching and training modules through smartphones and laptops.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://techseen.com/2017/09/12/cloud-education/|title=Cloud in education: Benefits for educators, learners and environment|date=2017-09-12|work=TECHSEEN|access-date=2017-09-26|language=en-US}}</ref>
== WizIQ customers ==
WizIQ is being used in enterprises, training organizations, colleges, universities, tutoring and test-prep companies for extended and supplemental learning. Some of the WizIQ customers include: Des Moines Area Community Colleges, ECPI University, Chatham University, Independent Electrical Contractors Rocky Mountains, and Applerouth Tutoring Services<ref>Julie Weed. [https://www.nytimes.com/2014/05/29/business/smallbusiness/how-small-companies-are-using-low-cost-technology-to-increase-sales-overseas.html Small Companies Use Low Cost Technology to Increase Sales Overseas]. The New York Times. May 28, 2014.</ref> in United States. Australia City College in Australia, ICPM University for Science in Egypt, ICICI Securities in India, Jamaica Stock Exchange in Jamaica, Center for Empowerment Coaching, Loud Class in South Korea, are some additional names.
